summary: Paul Merson has restarted his disagreement with Andros Townsend after the Tottenham midfielder was brought on for only seven minutes in a 0-0 draw with Burnley. Merson initially angered Townsend by writing in his Sky Sports column that if Townsend could get into the England team, it "opens it up to anybody." Townsend later scored an equaliser for England against Italy and responded to Merson on Twitter. Merson admitted he was wrong and praised the goal, stating he holds his hands up when he is wrong. However, after Townsend's brief appearance against Burnley, Merson had another "dig" at him on Twitter.

According to FC Tokyo club president Naoki Ogane, Chelsea has made a formal offer to acquire 22-year-old forward Yoshinori Muto in the summer. If the deal, mooted to be Â£4 million, is completed, Muto would be loaned to Chelsea's Dutch partner club, Vitesse Arnhem, for the next season. Muto, a Japan international with 11 caps and one goal, recently graduated from Keio University with an economics degree. He has not yet decided whether to accept the offer but called it an "honour". Ogane stated that the offer is not connected to Chelsea's sponsorship deal with the Japanese company Yokohama Rubber.

A large-scale Finnish study found that babies given antibiotics in the first six months of life are more likely to be overweight as toddlers. The study, published in Pediatrics, compared the weight and height of over 12,000 healthy two-year-olds with their antibiotic prescription records. By age two, one in five boys and one in ten girls were overweight or obese, with those who had taken antibiotics as young babies being particularly likely to be overweight. Repeated prescriptions before age two also increased the odds. Boys seemed more prone to this weight gain and were also slightly taller than boys who had not been given the drugs. While the study doesn't prove causation, researchers suggest antibiotics might kill gut bugs that normally consume some food, freeing up more for the body and potentially increasing appetite. The lead author warned that this effect could play a role in the childhood obesity epidemic and stressed the importance of judicious antibiotic use in infancy.

A Buckingham Palace guard slipped and fell on a manhole cover while taking up his position in a sentry box during the Changing of the Guard ceremony. The incident, which happened in front of hundreds of tourists, was recorded by a holidaymaker named David Meadwell. The embarrassed soldier, who dropped his rifle and knocked his bearskin, quickly got back to his feet. The fall is thought to have been caused by the metal protectors on the soles of his boots. The Ministry of Defence declined to comment on the incident.

A&E networks are remaking the miniseries "Roots," which originally aired in 1977 to over 100 million viewers. The new version is set to air in 2016 and will be simulcast on A&E, Lifetime, and History. It will be co-executive produced by LeVar Burton, who starred as Kunta Kinte in the original. The remake is described as an "original" and "contemporary" version that will draw more from Alex Haley's novel, "Roots: The Saga of an American Family," and will consult with scholars for authenticity. The goal is to bring the story to a new generation of viewers.

Police are investigating claims by a former royal footman, Christopher Lawler, that palace aides tried to force him into an orgy on his first day working at Clarence House in January 1978. Mr. Lawler, then 27, alleges he was pinned to a chair, groped, and threatened after walking into a bedroom. He states he left the job the same day and that his initial complaint was met with an angry response. After hearing about probes into historical abuse, he contacted palace officials again last year, but claims his complaint was ignored for months before being passed to Scotland Yard. A retired royal aide has been interviewed and denied involvement. The Royal Household has stated it will cooperate with the police investigation, which is ongoing.

An Oregon couple, Jesse and Melissa Meek, announced they are expecting a child in a rap video set to the theme from the '90s sitcom 'The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air.' The video, which has been viewed over 1.7 million times on YouTube, was made for loved ones living far away. In the clip, the couple raps about their friends and family asking about parenthood, trying to conceive for two months, and discovering the pregnancy with a positive test. At the end of the video, they share a sonogram of their unborn child. The couple told KPTV it took five takes to film the clip and that another video is a possibility after they find out the child's gender.

A gray jacket and skirt ensemble worn by Vivien Leigh as Scarlett O'Hara in the 1939 film *Gone With the Wind* was sold for $137,000 at a Heritage Auctions event in Beverly Hills, California. The dress, which has faded from its original slate blue-gray color, was worn in several key scenes. It was part of a private collection of over 150 items from the film owned by James Tumblin, who bought the dress for $20 after finding it about to be thrown away. Other items sold included a straw hat worn by Leigh for $52,500, a suit worn by Clark Gable for $55,000, and a bonnet that fetched $30,000. The passage also notes that Hattie McDaniel was the first African-American actor to win an Academy Award for her role in the film.

A two-year-old boy fell 10 to 12 feet into the cheetah exhibit at the Cleveland Metroparks Zoo after his parents dangled him over the railing. The boy's parents rescued him from the pit before emergency services arrived. He was taken to MetroHealth Medical Center in stable condition with minor bumps and bruises from the fall, but was not attacked by the cheetahs. According to zoo officials, eyewitness accounts indicated the child was dangled over the railing, and the zoo plans to press child endangerment charges.

A speed camera in Handsworth, Birmingham, which has not been operational for two years, was found angled directly at a house's front door. All fixed speed cameras in the West Midlands, including this one, were switched off in March 2013 because their technology was obsolete. Since then, speed enforcement has been conducted by mobile units, motorway cameras, and traffic officers. A spokesman for Birmingham City Council confirmed they were aware of the re-pointed camera and an engineer would visit the site, with the possibility of removing it completely. The camera on Wellington Road is not part of a new pilot program for digital cameras.

Usain Bolt, a six-time Olympic gold medallist, will compete for Jamaica at the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas on May 2 and 3. Bolt has stated he is "fit, healthy and ready to run." JAAA General Secretary Garth Gayle expressed pleasure that the "world's fastest man" will be running for Jamaica. The full team list will be announced shortly.

Neymar and Dani Alves attended a Barcelona basketball game, an El Clasico against Real Madrid, which Barcelona won 85-80. Neymar's sister, Rafaella, was also present. Despite the win, Real Madrid remains ahead of Barcelona in their Euro League division on points difference. Previously, Neymar played for Brazil in a 1-0 victory over Chile. Barcelona's football team had also won their recent El Clasico, putting them four points clear at the top of La Liga, and are set to play Celta Vigo next.

From Friday to Monday, 8,480 migrants were rescued by the Italian coast guard. On Tuesday, Save the Children reported fears that 400 migrants could be missing after their ship, carrying 550 people, capsized. The Italian coast guard, however, could not confirm this incident. In the first three months of 2015, Italy registered over 10,000 arriving migrants, with most coming from West Africa, Somalia, and Syria, using Libya as a transit country. The International Organization for Migration (IOM) states that at least 480 migrants have died crossing the Mediterranean since the start of the year, often due to bad weather and overcrowded vessels.

Arsenal manager Arsene Wenger is unsure why Alexis Sanchez chose to join Arsenal over Liverpool but is happy with the decision. Wenger acknowledges that Liverpool's interest in Sanchez could have been used as leverage in the Luis Suarez transfer to Barcelona. Sanchez, who cost Â£32 million, has made an instant impact, scoring 19 goals so far. Wenger praises Sanchez's qualities, such as his efficiency and work rate, and his ability to revitalise the team. The Arsenal manager also played down any speculation linking the club with Liverpool's Raheem Sterling and praised Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers for how he has developed his team.

Sir Bradley Wiggins, a four-time Olympic champion and 2012 Tour de France winner, will attempt to break cycling's hour record on June 7 at London's Olympic Velodrome (Lee Valley VeloPark). Wiggins, who recently finished his career with Team Sky, considers the hour record a "holy grail for cyclists." The current record is 52.491km, set by Australian Rohan Dennis in February. Before Wiggins's attempt, Briton Alex Dowsett will also try to break the record on May 2 in Manchester. Wiggins's attempt will be in front of a potential 6,000-person crowd, with tickets going on sale on April 19. The event will be broadcast live on Sky Sports.

Serena Williams, the world number one, defeated Sara Errani 4-6 7-6(3) 6-3 in a Fed Cup singles match, which she described as an "eye-opener." Williams stated she was not as prepared for the clay-court season as she had thought and needed to adjust her mindset from playing on a hard court. Despite her singles win, the US team was beaten 3-2 by Italy after Williams and Alison Riske lost their doubles match 6-0 6-3 to Errani and Flavia Pennetta. This loss meant the US was relegated to World Group II. US captain Mary Joe Fernandez said the team needs to "work harder" to get back into the World Group.

River Plate are keen to sign their former striker, Radamel Falcao, who is currently on loan at Manchester United. The club's vice president, Matias Patanian, stated, "We dream of Falcao Garcia. The doors are open," but admits a deal is complicated. Falcao, who has struggled at Manchester United, previously played for River Plate, scoring 34 goals in 90 appearances after joining them at age 15. It is uncertain if Manchester United will keep him or if he will return to his parent club, Monaco.

X Factor finalist and pop star Ella Henderson has been announced as the official face of dry shampoo brand Batiste's 2015 'Ready For It' campaign, marking her first brand collaboration. The international campaign, which was put together by the MILES agency, launched with a TV advertisement featuring Henderson's single, "Mirror Man." Campaign images show the 19-year-old singer with various hairstyles against a blurred city background. Henderson has expressed her excitement about the partnership, stating she regularly uses the product. Mark Hargreaves, CEO of Crown Talent & Media Group who manage Henderson, also commented on the collaboration.

A billboard featuring Officer Pablo Torres, who fatally shot 26-year-old Aaron Siler on March 14, has been erected in Kenosha, Wisconsin. The billboard, paid for by the Kenosha Professional Police Association, thanks the community for its support. Siler's family and friends are in shock, calling the billboard "disrespectful" and asking for it to be taken down. Siler, who had an active felony warrant, was shot after a vehicle and foot pursuit where he reportedly "armed himself with a weapon." Officer Torres is on leave pending an investigation into the shooting. This was the second shooting involving Torres in 10 days; he had previously shot and wounded 66-year-old Terry Knight, an incident which was later deemed justified. The investigation into Siler's death is ongoing.

Eight Iranian border guards were killed in clashes with militants near the border with Pakistan in the southeastern town of Negur. Three militants were also killed by Iranian forces. According to Ali Asghar Mirshekari, the deputy governor of Iran's Sistan-Baluchestan province, the militants crossed into Iran from Pakistan. A militant group called Jaish al Adal claimed responsibility for the attack. The Pakistani government condemned the attack and stated that its security agencies are investigating the incident.

In response to a question from lawmaker Antonio Inoki, Japan's Defense Minister Gen Nakatani stated that the country's Air Self Defense Force (ASDF) has never encountered an extraterrestrial unidentified flying object. Nakatani explained that while fighter jets are scrambled to investigate unidentified objects that could violate airspace, they have only found birds or other non-aircraft objects, never anything believed to be from another planet. The question was posed during an Upper House Budget Committee meeting by Inoki, a former wrestler, who asked if jets were scrambled for extraterrestrial threats and if research was being done on alien visitors. This is not the first time Japanese politicians have discussed alien visitors; in 2007, then-Defense Minister Shigeru Ishiba considered the legal ramifications of defending against an alien invasion.

A 35-year-old passenger, Jin Pai, was hospitalized with deep cuts on his leg and buttocks after a toilet he was squatting on broke at Hefei Xinqiao International Airport. He was standing on the toilet rim because he was worried the seat was not clean. The porcelain toilet tipped over and shattered, causing the injuries. The man was found bleeding on the floor after calling his companions for help. He received dozens of stitches at a Hefei hospital. He initially told friends he was squatting but later told police he was sitting, possibly to avoid paying compensation. Authorities considered the incident an accident.
DID NOT RECIEVE A STRING TYPE FROM OUTPUT

Japanese photographer YÃ»ki Aoyama has created a series of images for his latest book, which translates to "Daughter and Salary Man," featuring fathers leaping into the air next to their daughters. In the photos, the daughters, dressed in casual clothing, look directly at the camera while their fathers, wearing sharp suits, pull energetic and sometimes pained-looking poses. The photographer's website suggests the images allow the fathers to express their fun side. While little else is known about why the pictures were created, they are generating interest online.

Following the dismissal of Paul Downton as England's managing director, focus has shifted to the county championship season and Kevin Pietersen. Pietersen, who was controversially axed by Downton in 2014, has rejoined Surrey in an attempt to force his way back into the England Test team. He was photographed at a Surrey team photo shoot at the KIA Oval, appearing both in deep thought and in a jovial mood, joking with teammates and photographers. Surrey is set to begin their campaign at Glamorgan on April 19.

Romanian club Ceahlaul Piatra Neamt have sacked Brazilian coach Ze Maria for the second time in a week. He was initially fired on Wednesday but reinstated the next day by owner Angelo Massone. However, after Ceahlaul lost 2-0 to FC Botosani on Saturday, Ze Maria was fired again. The result left the club 16th in the standings. Ze Maria, who had replaced Florin Marin in January to become the club's third coach of the season, will be replaced by Serbian Vanya Radinovic.

According to his former Monaco teammate Nabil Dirar, Radamel Falcao must be regretting his failed loan move to Manchester United. Falcao, who was reportedly not happy in Monaco, moved to Old Trafford on a season-long loan but has struggled, scoring only four goals. Dirar believes Falcao would have been better off staying at Monaco, where he could have played in the Champions League. Due to his performance after a serious knee injury, it is unlikely that Manchester United will pay the Â£46 million required to make his transfer permanent.

New Zealand police are seeking public assistance to identify a "very tall" man who robbed a Christchurch dairy. The man, wearing a "distinctive" cartoon mask and a fluoro orange sweatshirt, took the dairy's till and approximately $1500 in cash on Saturday at about 12:30 pm. He demanded cash from the owner's daughter before throwing the cash register to the ground and fleeing with the till drawer. No weapons were reported, and the robber remains at large. Police are asking anyone with information to contact Crimestoppers or message them online.
DID NOT RECIEVE A STRING TYPE FROM OUTPUT

A video, viewed over half a million times, shows a large crocodile swimming through a marina in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, with a dead pet dog in its jaws. The dog, which belonged to a local bike shop owner, was wearing a red collar. According to tourist Tim Weston, who witnessed the event, the dog had approached the water's edge out of curiosity. The crocodile held the dog in its mouth for hours. Crocodiles are a common sight in Puerto Vallarta, as the resort is built amongst their natural mangrove habitat, and they are also regularly seen at a nearby sanctuary and on the resort's golf course.

Following a 2-0 defeat to Southampton, Hull City manager Steve Bruce remains confident he can keep the team in the Barclays Premier League. Despite an initial target of 10 wins, Hull has only achieved six, and Bruce now hopes eight or nine will be sufficient. The loss, which came from a James Ward-Prowse penalty and a Graziano Pelle strike, leaves Hull two points above the relegation zone with six games remaining, including difficult matches against Liverpool, Arsenal, Tottenham, and Manchester United. Bruce attributes the team's struggles to long-term injuries to key players like Michael Dawson, Nikica Jelavic, and Robert Snodgrass.

A teacher, Ian Guffick, from Mitton Manor Primary School in Tewkesbury, was banned from the classroom for at least two years. He allowed pupils to change their SATs exam answers after the exam session had finished and also altered some answers himself. An investigation was launched after a tip-off, which led the Department for Education to annul all SATs results for the entire school for that year. Guffick admitted the allegations, stating he asked pupils to make their answers more legible, not to change them. A conduct panel found his actions dishonest but not fraudulent, noting he may have felt under pressure to achieve good results. He was given 28 days to appeal the decision.

Manchester United goalkeeper Anders Lindegaard enjoyed a day off with his wife, Misse Beqiri. The couple, who have a son together, have been dating since 2012 and married last year in a beach wedding in Mauritius. Beqiri is a Swedish model with Albanian roots who regularly posts pictures on her Instagram account. Lindegaard, who signed for Manchester United in 2010 from Aalesunds, has struggled for playing time, making only 19 league appearances in five seasons. He is now third-choice goalkeeper behind David de Gea and Victor Valdes and has been told he can leave the club.

The 13 glowing blue letters that were on top of Yankee Stadium from 1976 until 2008 failed to sell at a Sotheby's auction. The letters were expected to sell for $300,000 to $600,000, but they received no bids. The current owner is Yankee Hall of Famer Reggie Jackson, who purchased the 10-feet-tall letters for an undisclosed amount after the stadium's final game in 2008. At the same auction, a New York Mets bullpen car, estimated at $20,000 to $30,000, sold for $112,500.

Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers has spoken to players Raheem Sterling and Jordon Ibe about their professional responsibilities after they were pictured with shisha pipes. Sterling was also exposed for inhaling nitrous oxide. Rodgers will not discipline the players and wants to move on from the matter. For the upcoming FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa, Daniel Sturridge is injured, but Steven Gerrard is available after a three-match suspension. Rodgers has not confirmed if Gerrard will play.

Mesut Ozil posted a picture on Twitter of himself relaxing at home with his dog after returning to London from international duty. He had been in fine form for Germany in their 2-0 win against Georgia in a Euro 2016 qualifier. Ozil, who missed Arsenal's last game against Newcastle due to illness, is expected to start against Liverpool. Since returning from injury in January, he has recorded four assists and three goals. He also stated that he is adjusting to English football and fits in "perfectly" because he prefers playing in many matches.

Barcelona club president Josep Maria Bartomeu has stated that the La Liga leaders have no plans to replace manager Luis Enrique, saying they are "very happy" with him. Bartomeu noted that Enrique has a contract until 2016 and has impressed since taking charge last summer. He also mentioned that Barcelona is still capable of winning three trophies. The team recently defeated Valencia with goals from Luis Suarez and Lionel Messi.

Liverpool's vice-captain, Jordan Henderson, has agreed to a new long-term contract with the club, which is expected to be worth around Â£100,000 per week and will run until 2020. Henderson, who was signed from Sunderland in June 2011 for Â£16 million, is the third player in Brendan Rodgers' squad to agree to a contract extension, following Daniel Sturridge and Philippe Coutinho. He is being considered for the role of club captain when Steven Gerrard leaves for LA Galaxy. Talks with Raheem Sterling are not expected to resume until the end of the season.

Filipe Luis has stated his desire to stay at Chelsea until his three-year contract ends, despite speculation that his former club, Atletico Madrid, is considering re-signing him. Luis, who has struggled to secure the left-back position, says he is happy at Chelsea. He also mentioned that manager Jose Mourinho is keeping the team focused for the nine remaining Premier League games, which he describes as "really difficult." Luis recently played for Brazil in friendly matches against France and Chile.

Wasps No 8 Nathan Hughes had his three-match ban overturned on appeal. The ban was initially given after he was shown a red card for accidentally knocking out George North with his knee while scoring a try for Northampton on March 27. The disciplinary panel had ruled the act 'reckless' but accepted there was no intent. The red card has now been rescinded.

The incident was the third time North had been knocked out in two months, and he was advised to take a month off from playing. Hughes's initial ban was met with an outcry from players like James Haskell, Andy Goode, Austin Healey, and Joe Marler. After Wasps lodged an appeal, the appeal panel heard the matter afresh with new evidence and concluded that no act of foul play took place, as the incident was accidental. Hughes, who missed one match while suspended, is now free to return to action.

A fiery, deep reddish sunset was observed in Washington.
*   **Who documented it?** Seattle native Tim Durkan photographed the sunset.
*   **What was the cause?** The stunning sunsets were the result of smoke from raging wildfires in Siberia.
*   **How did the fires start?** The fires were started by farmers burning grass in southeastern Siberia and grew out of control due to strong winds.
*   **How did the smoke travel?** Atmospheric winds carried the smoke from Siberia across the Pacific Ocean to the Pacific Northwest, affecting parts of Oregon, Washington, and British Columbia.
*   **Why the red color?** Smoke particles filter out shorter wavelength colors (greens, blues, yellows, purples) from sunlight, allowing colors like red and orange to penetrate the air unfiltered. The effect is more intense at sunrise and sunset.
*   **What is the outlook?** As the smoke dissipates, air quality will improve, and the sunsets will lose their reddish hue.

Becky Schoenig of St. Louis, Missouri, had her new 2015 Ford Fusion stolen from her driveway. Police found the car on April 1 after a man named Mick Sexton recognized it and provided a tip. The car was returned to Schoenig with new red rims, red detailing, and orange accents on the steering wheel. Instead of being upset, Schoenig posted on Facebook, thanking the thieves for "pimping out" her vehicle. She is having the car professionally cleaned due to the smell of cigarettes and marijuana and is creating a smoothie at her restaurant, The Hot Pot, called "The Sexton on Wheels" to honor the man who found her car.

Manchester City players, including Sergio Aguero, David Silva, Joe Hart, and Yaya Toure, stand to lose Â£500,000 each in bonuses if the team fails to qualify for the Champions League. These incentivised contracts are in place to help the club adhere to financial fair play rules. The total amount at risk for the squad is around Â£12 million.

Following a loss to Manchester United, City is in fourth place in the Premier League. The top three teams qualify automatically for the Champions League, while the fourth-place team must win a qualifying round. Manager Manuel Pellegrini admitted the team has performed badly in the last three months, and this poor form could also impact their ability to sign world-class players like Paul Pogba.

Manchester United's Under 18s team defeated Manchester City's Under 18s team 1-0 in a 'mini-derby' match. The game was played at Moss Lane, Altrincham's home ground, in front of nearly 1,000 spectators, and entry was free. The matchwinner was Callum Gribbin, who scored with a free-kick just before the hour mark. The result leaves United two points behind the league leaders, Middlesbrough, with a game in hand, while City have lost both of their matches in the end-of-season play-off series. The passage notes that 13 of the 22 starting players were English, with 10 being Mancunian.

England goalkeeper Joe Hart, who earned his 50th cap, described fellow goalkeeper Gianluigi Buffon as a "legend of the game" and an inspiration. Buffon, aged 37, claimed his 147th cap in the 1-1 draw against England. Hart stated that he is still learning and looks up to Buffon. He also expressed pride in reaching 50 caps and his desire to continue playing for his club and country to earn more.

Mexican restaurant Chipotle is partnering with the Postmates app to offer food delivery in 67 cities for online and mobile orders. This service will include a nine percent service charge, with Postmates' delivery fees starting at $5. Postmates uses independent contractors who drive their own cars, similar to Uber. Other franchises like Starbucks, Taco Bell, McDonald's, and Burger King are also entering the delivery market. The passage also notes that presidential candidates Hillary Clinton and Marco Rubio have been seen at Chipotle restaurants.

The parents of 8-year-old Martin Richard, the youngest victim of the Boston Marathon bombings, have publicly asked the Justice Department to take the death penalty off the table for the convicted bomber, Dzhokhar Tsarnaev. In an opinion piece in The Boston Globe, Bill and Denise Richard stated that in exchange for Tsarnaev spending the rest of his life in prison with no possibility of release or appeal, they would support dropping the death penalty. They explained that doing so would prevent years of appeals, which would prolong their family's pain and allow them to move forward. Tsarnaev was found guilty on all 30 charges related to the 2013 bombings, which killed three people, including the Richards' son, and injured over 200 others.

A Boeing 747 jumbo jet, which would normally carry up to 600 passengers, has been converted into a luxury home for a single mystery billionaire. The customisation is believed to have cost Â£400 million and took three years to complete. The aircraft includes bedrooms, multiple lounges, a conference room, an onboard restaurant with an adjoining kitchen, and an 'aeroloft' with eight full beds for guests. The owner has a master bedroom and a main suite. The plane was designed to fit the owner's exact specifications and can accommodate dozens of guests.

On Tuesday, SpaceX launched a Falcon 9 rocket from Cape Canaveral, Florida, carrying an uncrewed Dragon cargo spacecraft to the International Space Station (ISS). The ascent was successful, but the attempt to land the rocket stage on a floating barge was not; the rocket landed too hard and tipped over. This was the second attempt to land a Falcon 9 on the drone ship. The goal of landing and reusing rockets is to reduce the cost of space access.

The Dragon spacecraft is delivering over 4,300 pounds of supplies, including an espresso maker, to the ISS. After about five weeks, it will be filled with over 3,000 pounds of experiments and trash to return to Earth, splashing down in the Pacific Ocean. This was the sixth SpaceX mission to the ISS and the second launch attempt for this particular mission, as the first was scrubbed due to weather.

Priscilla Presley will be a witness at the first wedding held at the new Elvis Presley's Graceland Wedding Chapel in Las Vegas. She collaborated with NBC's Today show on a contest for an Elvis-obsessed couple to win this "ultimate wedding." The winning couple will be married on Thursday, April 23, at the chapel, which is located inside the Westgate Hotel, formerly the Las Vegas Hilton where Elvis performed over 830 shows. The prize includes a free wedding reception, a hotel suite for two nights, airfare, and tickets to the Elvis Experience theater show. Priscilla Presley, who was involved in the chapel's design, has stipulated that there will be no Elvis impersonators, stating, "This is all first-class...This is not a joke." To enter the contest, couples must submit a video or photos explaining why they should win.

Liverpool vice-captain Jordan Henderson believes his side can catch Manchester City in the Premier League, who are four points ahead. Henderson and goalkeeper Simon Mignolet played their 47th game of the season in a 2-0 win over Newcastle United. Raheem Sterling scored the first goal in the ninth minute, and Joe Allen scored the second with 20 minutes remaining. Allen admitted that Newcastle had a "good shout for a penalty" that was not given.

Roma defeated Napoli 1-0 in a Serie A match, ending a four-month winless streak at home. Miralem Pjanic scored the only goal in the 25th minute from a counter-attack. Roma's goalkeeper, Morgan de Sanctis, made several saves in the second half to secure the victory. The win moved second-place Roma four points ahead of Lazio. For Napoli, the loss extended their winless streak to five matches, and they remained in fifth place. Security was high for the match, with 1,000 police officers and a ticket ban for residents of the Campania region, but no problems were reported.

Doncaster Rovers' uninspired season in League One continued with a 0-0 goalless draw against Fleetwood Town at the Keepmoat Stadium. The match offered so little action that the club's media team created a highlights video for their YouTube channel that was only 27 seconds long, featuring just 14 seconds of match play which included the kick-off, a goal kick, and the final whistle.

A man named Roland Giroux has a remarkable relationship with his pet blood parrot cichlid. He interacts with the fish by placing his hand in the tank, where the fish allows him to cup it, stroke it, and massage it. The fish, which initially moves away, repeatedly returns to the man's hand and even swims up his arm and circles his fingers. Mr. Giroux developed this bond after removing two other fish that were bullying his pet. He started by hand-feeding it frozen blood worms and noticed it becoming more sociable. Now, he plays with the fish for at least 15 minutes daily, and the fish becomes frustrated if he doesn't. The blood parrot cichlid is a hybrid of the midas and redhead cichlid, first bred in Taiwan around 1986.

Ben Stokes is known as a fiery and aggressive character in the England cricket team. He once broke his wrist punching a locker at Kensington Oval after being dismissed. During the second Test against the West Indies, he clashed with Marlon Samuels but responded positively after a talk with England coach Peter Moores. The passage suggests that while Stokes's aggression needs to be channelled correctly and man-managed, it should not be completely quashed, as it is part of what makes him an exciting player who can produce runs and wickets. England is keen for Stokes to play as much as possible to help him grow and reach his full potential.

Wales' Euro 2016 qualifier match against Belgium, scheduled for June 12 at the Cardiff City Stadium, is a 33,000 sell-out. Both teams are at the top of Group B with 11 points each, though Belgium leads on goal difference. Following Wales' 3-0 victory over Israel, there is high expectation that they can secure an automatic qualifying spot for the 2016 finals in France. The Football Association of Wales (FAW) confirmed the sell-out was due to overwhelming demand. Despite speculation about moving the match to the larger Millennium Stadium, this was not possible due to UEFA rules. It is also understood that the Wales squad, including Gareth Bale, prefers playing at the Cardiff City Stadium.

England coach John Peacock has named his squad for the UEFA European Under-17 Championship in Bulgaria. England, the defending champions, qualified with a 100 per cent record and are in Group D with Holland, Italy, and the Republic of Ireland. Their first match is against Italy on May 7. The squad includes players like Jay Dasilva (Chelsea), Chris Willock (Arsenal), and Stephy Mavididi (Arsenal), with Mavididi receiving his first call-up. Liverpool's Herbie Kane and Trent Arnold have been recalled to the squad.

Manchester City are interested in signing 14-year-old Anderlecht playmaker, Evangelos Patoulidis. He is considered a top talent from Anderlecht's youth system and has also drawn interest from Arsenal and Barcelona. Patoulidis previously turned down a move to Barcelona at age 12 to continue his studies. City have discussed a compensation package with Anderlecht's chairman.

A 33-year-old Mexican national named Vanessa Santillan, who worked as a transgender escort, was found strangled and beaten to death in a flat in Fulham, south west London, at the end of March. Her body was discovered on March 28 after the London Ambulance Service was called to the scene. A 23-year-old man was arrested in connection with her death but has been bailed pending further questioning. Police are appealing for anyone who had contact with Miss Santillan in the hours before her death to come forward.

A woman named Dawn, who has had seven miscarriages, appeared on The Jeremy Kyle show.
*   She accused her housemate and family friend, Jamie, a convicted burglar, of stealing Â£207.
*   The money was being saved for a Â£500 gravestone for her baby, Daniel James.
*   A lie detector test revealed that Jamie had stolen the money.
*   Jamie had also sent a Facebook message to Dawn confessing to taking the money but blaming his girlfriend, Carol.
*   Upon learning the truth, Dawn burst into tears and expressed feeling betrayed.

On Wednesday, ISIS released over 200 Yazidis, a minority group they had previously captured in northern Iraq. Most of those freed were women, children, the ill, or the elderly. According to Rassol Omar, a Peshmerga commander, Arab tribal leaders helped coordinate the release. The freed Yazidis were received by the Peshmerga and sent to Irbil. The exact number of released individuals is disputed, with one official, Nuri Osman, stating 217 and Omar reporting 228. This is not the first time ISIS has released Yazidis, having previously freed children and the elderly. The Yazidis, a pre-Islamic religious group of Kurdish descent, were targeted by ISIS last summer, leading to killings, captures, and displacement, particularly after the conquest of Sinjar.

Tottenham and England striker Harry Kane, who has had a remarkable season, is the subject of a new animation. The video, created by Copa90, uses still photographs to showcase some of his best goals and celebrations from the season, including his long-range strike against Chelsea, a headed goal against Arsenal, and his debut goal for England. The animation is titled 'Harry Kane - PFA Player of the Year?' and has been released ahead of the awards ceremony. Kane is nominated for both the PFA Player and Young Player of the Year awards.

Jamie Carragher believes Brendan Rodgers should continue as Liverpool's manager despite a season with no trophies and a likely finish outside the top four. Carragher, a former Liverpool defender, stated that Rodgers' future should not be determined by one game and noted that the new players have not fully settled in. He believes Rodgers, the players, and staff will aim to win a trophy and get back into the top four next season, emphasizing that the right signings will be crucial. Separately, Carragher received a Beacon Award in London for his community work on Merseyside through his 23 Foundation, which provides coaching in schools in deprived areas.

Four-year-old James Hayward had his plastic nerf gun confiscated at East Midlands Airport while travelling to Lanzarote with his parents. The toy, which fires sponge darts, was in his hand luggage and was identified by X-ray machines. Security staff also frisked the child. The boy's father, Phil Hayward, described the security checks as "ludicrous" and "over-zealous." East Midlands Airport apologised for the inconvenience, stating that the safety of passengers is their first priority and that government regulations prohibit any items that resemble a prohibited item, such as replica or model guns. The airport also noted they had offered to post the toy back to the family's home. James was bought a replacement toy gun after returning from the holiday.

A 31-year-old man from Humpty Doo, Northern Territory, who identifies as "Rich," posted an advertisement on Gumtree seeking a girlfriend or wife. The ad lists his requirements for a partner, including being a non-drinker and non-smoker, fit, attractive, honest, loyal, a good cook, and good with her hands. She must also enjoy the outdoors but also be "a princess when need to be." In return, he offers potential benefits such as accommodation, a company car, phone, laptop, and a free gym membership. Rich describes himself as 31 years old, with an athletic build, heavily tattooed, a non-smoker, non-drinker, and financially successful, owning his own property. He also states that former partners need not apply and that "all reasonable offers will be considered." Daily Mail Australia was unsuccessful in its attempt to contact him.

Football Association chairman Greg Dyke has received the backing of five former England managers (Graham Taylor, Glenn Hoddle, Kevin Keegan, Sven-Goran Eriksson, and Steve McClaren) for his proposed changes. Dyke wants to increase the minimum number of home-grown players in club squads from eight to 12 and redefine "home-grown" as having trained in England for three years before age 18, instead of 21. He is facing opposition from the Premier League. The former managers signed a letter warning that failing to implement these proposals risks England falling further behind other top football nations, citing a shrinking pool of English talent at the top level. They state that while promising young players are emerging, they are not being given enough opportunities.

In an upcoming episode of Poldark, Demelza Poldark will give birth to a baby daughter with Ross Poldark. The passage notes that the timeline of the pregnancy is unconvincing, as Demelza is eight months pregnant at the start of the episode and gives birth just minutes later, having announced the pregnancy in the previous episode. This fast-paced pregnancy has been noticed by fans on Twitter. The passage also mentions that Ross Poldark, played by Aidan Turner, is a heartthrob whose heart is "well and truly off the market."

Leicester boss Nigel Pearson has urged his team to stay focused on their own games and ignore their relegation rivals. After back-to-back wins, including a 3-2 victory at West Brom where Jamie Vardy scored an injury-time winner, the Foxes are three points from safety but remain bottom of the Premier League. Pearson stated that their future is in their own hands and that while it's helpful other teams are being "dragged into it," results only matter if Leicester does their own job. He also warned against becoming "overly optimistic."

A North Pacific gray whale named Varvara completed the longest recorded mammal migration, swimming nearly 14,000 miles (22,500 kilometers). Tracked by scientists from Oregon State University, Varvara traveled from her feeding ground off Russia's Sakhalin Island, across the Pacific Ocean, and down the West Coast of the United States to Baja, Mexico. This journey surpassed the previous record held by a humpback whale. The trip suggests that Varvara, previously thought to be an endangered western gray whale, might actually be an eastern gray whale, as she visited three major breeding areas for that population. This finding could mean the number of western gray whales, estimated at only 150, might be even lower.

A 1,000ft stretch of seabed was forced to the surface overnight on the east coast of Japan's Hokkaido Island, near the town of Rausu on the Shiretoko Peninsula.

*   **How big is it?** The new landmass has risen as high as 50ft above sea level, measures roughly 1,000-1,640ft long, and 100ft wide.

*   **What caused it?** Geologists believe the emergence is the result of a nearby landslide, where melting ice and snow caused a section of land to drop, pivoting the underwater area into the air.

*   **Was there any warning?** No. Local residents reported they did not hear any sounds or feel any tremors when the land appeared.

*   **Is it related to earthquakes?** It is not believed to be related to the 7.8 magnitude earthquake in the Kathmandu Valley. An official stated, "Our understanding is that this is different from earthquakes."

Gregory van der Wiel has denied claims he is leaving Paris Saint-Germain in the summer, stating that he is "genuinely happy" at the club and wants to sign a new contract. This is despite a recent falling out with manager Laurent Blanc after being dropped for a Champions League match against Chelsea. Van der Wiel reiterated his love for the club, city, and teammates, saying there is "absolutely no reason" for him to leave. However, the passage notes that PSG's reported interest in Barcelona's Dani Alves may mean Van der Wiel has no choice in the matter.

Carlos Tevez, a striker for Juventus, has been told he must terminate his contract with the club to return to his former club, Boca Juniors, in Argentina. Although Tevez's contract with Juventus expires at the end of next season, he has reportedly told the club he wants to leave this summer. Boca Juniors' president, Daniel Angelici, has confirmed they are close to a deal but stressed that Tevez must first end his contract with Juventus. Tevez is the league's top scorer with 17 goals, and while Juventus is reluctant to lose him, they have accepted his desire to leave and are looking for replacements. Tevez's international manager, Tata Martino, stated that a move to Boca Juniors would not be a "step down" and would not affect his future with the Argentina national team.

During a Champions League match against Porto, Bayern Munich manager Pep Guardiola ripped a hole in his trousers, exposing his underwear. He joked afterwards that he would need to buy new ones. Bayern Munich won the match 6-1, with goals from Thiago Alcantara, Jerome Boateng, Thomas Muller, Xabi Alonso, and two from Robert Lewandowski. This victory secured Bayern a place in the Champions League semi-finals, overturning a 3-1 deficit from the first match.

A multi-vehicle crash involving ten people, including four children, occurred on the Brisbane Valley Highway near Fernvale. Three vehicles collided, resulting in several injuries. A 40-year-old man and a five-year-old boy were flown to Princess Alexandra Hospital with chest and shoulder injuries. A 27-year-old woman and a six-year-old girl were also airlifted to a hospital for arm and abdominal injuries. Six other individuals, including an infant and two young girls, were taken to Ipswich Hospital with minor injuries. The highway was closed with diversions in place.

Arsenal playmaker Mesut Ozil received a new Apple Watch, which he compared to the watch from the TV show *Knight Rider*. The watch, which ranges in price from Â£299 to Â£13,500, was released for general sale on Friday. Ozil is expected to start in Arsenal's upcoming match against Chelsea. Meanwhile, club legend Ray Parlour has stated that Jack Wilshere is the "future of the club" but questions if he can stay fit, citing his injury record over the last few seasons. Wilshere, who has been out for five months with an injury, was on the bench for Arsenal's recent FA Cup semi-final win.

Mark Clattenburg has been appointed to referee the upcoming Manchester derby at Old Trafford. This season, Clattenburg has sent off three players from both teams: City's Vincent Kompany during an international match, and United's Tyler Blackett and Luke Shaw in the Premier League. These are the only two red cards he has shown in the league this season. The derby has added significance as United, on a five-game winning streak, have moved one point above City, with the match potentially deciding who finishes second. Clattenburg's assistants will be Simon Beck and Jake Collin, with Jonathan Moss as the fourth official.

Outspoken MP Bob Katter accused the Queensland Government of believing that embattled MP Billy Gordon was "a little black puppet on a string." Mr. Gordon, who was forced to quit the Queensland Labor Party after being accused of domestic violence and withholding his criminal history, announced he would remain in parliament as an independent. Mr. Katter, who is of Lebanese descent, said he sympathised with Mr. Gordon's position, having been subjected to racist attitudes himself. He questioned why it was assumed Mr. Gordon would resign when other MPs in similar situations had not. The statement drew criticism on social media for its terminology. Mr. Katter defended his use of the phrase "black puppet," stating he used it deliberately based on his personal experiences of being "dark" and to highlight what he saw as racial overtones from the government.

Dayna Dobias, a 19-year-old from Illinois with cerebral palsy, creates dancing videos to inspire others and challenge stereotypes about disabilities. She aims to show that despite her condition and facing bullying, she is the same as everyone else and can do things like drive and attend college. Dobias, who was told she might never walk, has also started motivational speaking at local schools.

MLS team Orlando City, which has a large Latin-American fanbase and is coached by Adrian Heath, has expressed interest in Manchester United's Javier Hernandez. Hernandez, who has been on loan at Real Madrid, is also being pursued by eight European clubs, including Southampton, Stoke, West Ham, Everton, Wolfsburg, AC Milan, Lazio, and Inter Milan. Manchester United is willing to sell the 26-year-old for around Â£8 million.

Additionally, Manchester United has made a revised contract offer to 19-year-old Andreas Pereira. After Pereira rejected the first offer, clubs such as Paris St Germain, Juventus, PSV Eindhoven, and Feyenoord have contacted his father.

At a 76 gas station in South Los Angeles around 12:15 am on Saturday, a gang of at least three people poured gasoline on a white Dodge Charger and set it on fire. The incident occurred after the driver had an argument with the suspects, who, according to the driver's grandmother, had attempted to carjack him at gunpoint. Although the driver and two passengers inside the car were not hurt, the vehicle was completely ruined. The Los Angeles County Fire Department is investigating the incident as an arson, and the suspects are still at large.

Charles Manuel, a chiropractor in Lamoni, Iowa, has surrendered his state license after being accused of accepting sex as payment for his services and performing exorcisms on patients. He signed an agreement with the Iowa Board of Chiropractic, admitting to his misdeeds, which also included recommending patients stop taking prescribed medication. Manuel pledged not to apply for license reinstatement for at least 10 years. Despite these actions, he received a perfect five-star rating for patient satisfaction on HealthGrades.com based on three survey responses.

A Russian SU-27 fighter jet intercepted a U.S. RC-135U reconnaissance plane over the Baltic Sea in what the U.S. described as an "unsafe and unprofessional manner." The Pentagon stated the incident occurred in international airspace north of Poland and that the Russian pilot performed "aggressive maneuvers" in close proximity and at a high rate of speed.

According to Russian state news, the U.S. plane was flying toward the Russian border with its transponder off, a claim a U.S. European Command official called false. The U.S. plans to file a complaint with Russia through diplomatic channels. This is not the first such incident; a year ago, a Russian jet flew within 100 feet of a U.S. RC-135U over the Sea of Okhotsk.

An FBI agent's sniper rifle was stolen from his car in a Salt Lake City Marriott Springhill Suites parking lot on March 27. The rifle, which was in a hard case and secured with padlocks and chains to a truck safe, was stolen overnight just a week before President Obama's visit to Utah. Police believe the thief broke the rear passenger-side window and used another vehicle to forcefully rip the rifle case out of the car. The agent's gear bag, backpack, clothing, and tools were also stolen, though some bags and clothing were later found at a nearby hotel. The hotel did not have surveillance cameras. The rifle has not been recovered, but its serial number has been entered into the National Crime Information Computer. The Secret Service was notified of the theft before the President's visit.

Luigi Costa, 71, is accused of killing his neighbour, Terrence Freebody, in Canberra in July 2012. A jury heard that Costa allegedly stomped on Freebody's head, cut his throat, and stabbed him. Forensic psychiatrist Professor Paul Mullen testified that he believes Costa was suffering from dementia and alcohol abuse at the time, which led to a confused state where he might not have understood his actions. The prosecutor suggested Costa might be feigning his memory loss. Costa's state of mind is critical to the case, as the jury can return a not guilty verdict if his unstable mindset at the time of the attack can be proven.

Everton manager Roberto Martinez defended Ross Barkley after he missed a 10th-minute penalty in their 1-0 win against Burnley. The penalty was awarded for a foul on Aaron Lennon by David Jones. Barkley took the kick instead of Leighton Baines, who has a record of scoring 15 out of 16 penalties in the Premier League. This incident was reminiscent of a previous one in January when Kevin Mirallas took a penalty from Baines and missed. Martinez stated that Barkley was within his rights to take the penalty, and that Baines was happy to give him the responsibility. The penalty was saved by Burnley's goalkeeper, Tom Heaton. The miss did not prove costly, as Mirallas later scored the only goal of the game in the 29th minute.

Two passengers were found dead in their stateroom on the Holland America Line cruise ship, the ms Ryndam, while it was in San Juan, Puerto Rico. The cruise line stated that the deaths appear to be a murder-suicide. The cabin was secured, and the FBI is investigating the incident. The ship had departed from Tampa, Florida, on March 29 for a 14-day cruise. The deceased passengers were discovered by the ship's cleaning staff.

Patrick Kluivert, former Holland forward and assistant coach, has made a winning start as the coach of Curacao in the World Cup qualifiers. His team advanced to the second qualifying round for the 2018 tournament by defeating Montserrat 4-3 on aggregate. Curacao won the first leg 2-1 and drew the second leg 2-2, with Charlton Vicento scoring the decisive goal in the 87th minute of the second match. Curacao will face Cuba in the next round. Kluivert's mother is from Curacao, and he was previously an assistant to Louis van Gaal at the 2014 World Cup.

Esteban Cambiasso, a decorated player who has won 15 trophies with Inter Milan and also played for Real Madrid and River Plate, believes that keeping Leicester City in the Premier League would be as significant as winning a trophy. At the time of the article, Leicester City is at the bottom of the table, seven points adrift with eight games left. Despite this, Cambiasso remains convinced they can avoid relegation. He signed a one-year deal with the Foxes in the summer, leaving Inter Milan after ten years, and has become a key player. He is happy in the East Midlands and may stay beyond his current contract.

A 23-year-old mother-of-two named Gemma is at risk of being banned from seeing her children by her own mother, Debbie. Gemma handed over her two children, who are under five, to Debbie when they were four months old. Debbie, who is 52, is threatening the ban because Gemma refuses to stop drinking and partying, has a penchant for the legal high MKat, and is suspected of stealing. Debbie claims Gemma stole an iPad from one of the children to fund her lifestyle, though Gemma denies this. However, Gemma does admit to stealing money and other items from her mother in the past. Debbie, who stepped in to care for the children after social services threatened to intervene, says Gemma's children call her "mum" and that she will ban Gemma from her home to protect the children and their possessions.

During a match between Chelsea and Manchester United, Eden Hazard scored to give Chelsea a 1-0 lead. The goal was preceded by a challenge from Chelsea's John Terry on Manchester United's Radamel Falcao. Terry's challenge from behind sent Falcao to the ground, and Cesc Fabregas collected the loose ball, which eventually led to Hazard's goal. Sky Sports pundits Thierry Henry, Jamie Redknapp, and Graeme Souness all agreed during their half-time analysis that Terry's challenge was a foul and play should have been stopped. Souness described it as a "decent forearm smash," Henry stated he would have wanted a foul "all day long," and Redknapp, while feeling Falcao could have been stronger, still believed it was a foul.

On Thursday morning, a tour bus belonging to Lady Antebellum singer Hillary Scott caught fire on Interstate 30 near Dallas, Texas.
*   **Who was involved?** Hillary Scott, her husband, the tour manager, and the driver were on board. All were evacuated safely. The other two band members, Charles Kelley and Dave Haywood, were not on the bus.
*   **What caused it?** The fire started after a rear tire blew out.
*   **What was the outcome?** The bus was charred, and everything in the back lounge was destroyed, except for Scott's Bible. The band is still scheduled to perform at the 50th Academy of Country Music Awards in Arlington, Texas.

Dr. Adrian Quarterman of Dundee University is developing a space laser system to convert sunbeams into energy. Satellites covered in mirrors would orbit the earth, harvest sunlight, convert it into laser light using semi-conductors, and then shoot the energy back down to earth. This could boost the energy solar panels receive, making solar power viable even in places like Scotland or restoring power to disaster areas.

Initial trials in Scotland were successful, and Dr. Quarterman hopes to move them to Portugal. He states the lasers will not be powerful enough to blind a pigeon, but acknowledges one might have to worry about who controls the satellites.

This system is different from a proposal by Tokyo researchers to use a laser on the International Space Station to shoot down small pieces of space debris.

Stephen Munden, a 54-year-old convicted paedophile, has gone on the run after vanishing from a psychiatric unit near Hook, Hampshire. He was last seen leaving the hospital at 6:15 pm on Tuesday. Munden was detained under the Mental Health Act following a conviction for sexually touching a three-year-old girl on a bus. He had also admitted to ten offences related to possessing indecent images of children. Described as having a "fanatical obsession" with young girls, Munden is about 5ft 8ins tall, of a heavy build, has dark hair, and suffers from learning difficulties. Police have released images of him with and without a beard, as they believe he may have shaved it off before leaving.

A Los Angeles judge has ordered V. Stiviano to repay over $2.6 million in gifts to Donald Sterling's wife, Shelly Sterling. Shelly Sterling had sued Stiviano, accusing her of targeting wealthy older men and claiming that Donald Sterling used the couple's money to purchase gifts for Stiviano, including a Ferrari, two Bentleys, a Range Rover, and a $1.8 million duplex. Stiviano countered that there was nothing wrong with receiving gifts from Donald Sterling. Shelly Sterling's lawyer called the decision a "victory for the Sterling family." Donald Sterling's racist remarks, made in an audio recording with Stiviano, led to him being banned from the NBA and fined $2.5 million.

Thierry Henry has criticised Arsenal's transfer dealings and urged them to buy four top players: a goalkeeper, a centre back, a defensive midfielder, and a striker. Speaking as a Sky Sports pundit after Arsenal's goalless draw with Chelsea, Henry stated that while Olivier Giroud is doing well, Arsenal cannot win the Premier League with him as their first-choice striker. He used Chelsea's purchases of Thibaut Courtois, Nemanja Matic, Cesc Fabregas, and Diego Costa as an example of what Arsenal needs to do to win the league.

A young woman, who was a victim of abuse by Bega Cheese boss Maurice Van Ryn, told a court about the severe impact it has had on her life. Van Ryn, a wealthy NSW businessman, has pleaded guilty to 12 sex offences, including persistent sexual abuse of a child. The victim stated that she is scared for her future relationships and that Van Ryn stole her right to share her body with someone for the first time. She did not speak about the abuse until she heard he had been caught. Since then, she has suffered from depression, been hospitalized for self-harm, and attempted suicide. Van Ryn sat calmly in the dock and did not look at her as she spoke in Sydney's District Court. The hearing is ongoing.

Serge Gnabry, a 19-year-old Arsenal midfielder, is feeling "better and better" as he prepares to return after over a year out with a serious knee injury. His last first-team appearance was in March 2014 against Bayern Munich. Gnabry has now played 90 minutes for the Arsenal Under 21s against Reading and says he is over his injury worries.

A 23-year-old accountant named Jacob Phillips died after falling 70ft from a cliff. The incident occurred when he and his friends ran from a taxi to avoid paying the fare after a night out in December. Mr. Phillips, who was in the seaside town of Penarth, South Wales, leapt over a fence in the dark and fell down the cliff. The taxi driver, Dave Sidaway, gave chase but stopped as he couldn't see. Mr. Phillips' body was found the next day on a rocky beach at the base of the cliff by a dog walker. The coroner recorded a verdict of accidental death, stating that Mr. Phillips was likely disorientated and unaware of the danger.

During last summer's passport delay fiasco, thousands of holidaymakers did not receive compensation. The passport agency, which made a Â£42 million profit during this period, awarded managers bonuses up to Â£3,500. The problems began when HM Passport Office struggled with 3.6 million applications, leading to a backlog of over half a million passports by mid-June. Despite calls for compensation led by Keith Vaz, chairman of the Home Affairs Committee, ministers rejected a blanket refund. Between April of last year and January of this year, only 2,191 compensation applications were approved, with a total payout of Â£203,066. The Passport Office could not state how many claims were rejected due to a "system failure of our customer complaint database."

A three-bedroom, semi-detached "timewarp" home in Horfield, Bristol, which has remained unchanged since the 1930s, is for sale. The property has a guide price of between Â£200,000 and Â£250,000 and will be auctioned on April 30 at the County Ground in Bristol.

Original features include:
*   Stained-glass windows depicting ships and coats of arms
*   A wood-panelled hallway
*   The original bathroom with a mint green and black colour scheme
*   The original kitchen with 1930s cupboards and a dated sink
*   A brick open-face fire
*   Oil-fired central heating
*   Retro jars and tins of produce like Cadburyâs Marvel dried milk, Tate and Lyle sugar, and Colmanâs Mustard

While the house is double glazed, auctioneers believe the potential cost of renovations could deter developers. The house is considered a "collector's paradise" and could be a perfect family home for those with a passion for antiques.

Colin Kaepernick started his career as a backup quarterback for the 49ers. He became the starter during the 2012 season after Alex Smith was injured. Kaepernick then led the team to the Super Bowl, where they lost to the Baltimore Ravens.
Soul Food is a 1997 American comedy-drama film. It was produced by Kenneth "Babyface" Edmonds, Tracey Edmonds, and Robert Teitel, and released by Fox 2000 Pictures.

Anne Rice was born in New Orleans and later lived in Texas and San Francisco. Route 495 is a 3.45-mile freeway in Hudson County, New Jersey, connecting the New Jersey Turnpike to the Lincoln Tunnel in Weehawken.
Telemundo is an American Spanish-language terrestrial television network owned by Comcast through its NBCUniversal division, NBCUniversal Telemundo Enterprises.

Damon Albarn was raised in Leytonstone, East London, and Colchester, Essex. He attended Stanway School, where he met Graham Coxon and formed the band Blur. Blur's debut album, "Leisure," was released in 1991 to mixed reviews. Albarn's other band, influenced by alternative rock, trip hop, hip hop, electronica, dub, reggae, and pop music, released its self-titled debut album in 2001 to worldwide success. His debut solo album, "Everyday Robots," was released on April 28, 2014, and featured collaborations with Brian Eno, Natasha Khan, and the Leytonstone City Pentecostal Mission Church Choir, as well as samples of Lord Buckley.
Mogadishu, known locally as Hamar, is the capital and most populous city of Somalia, and it is where many of the nation's important institutions are based.
"Happiness in Slavery" is a song by the American industrial rock band Nine Inch Nails, featured on their 1992 debut extended play (EP), Broken.
Andrew Kevin Walker is an American BAFTA-nominated screenwriter who was born on August 14, 1964.

The 2007 film "Shooter" follows Force Recon veteran Bob Lee Swagger (Mark Wahlberg), who is framed for murder. The "Shooter" TV series stars Ryan Phillippe as Bob Lee Swagger, an expert marksman who returns from exile to stop a plot to kill the president.
*House* (also known as *House, M.D.*) is an American television medical drama that aired on the Fox network for eight seasons, from November 16, 2004, to May 21, 2012.

In 1971, Charles Manson was found guilty of first-degree murder and conspiracy to commit murder for the deaths of seven people, including actress Sharon Tate. The murders were carried out by members of his group at his instruction. Manson was also convicted of the first-degree murders of Gary Hinman and Donald "Shorty" Shea. After he was charged, recordings of songs he had written and performed were released commercially.

Sean Justin Penn is an American actor, filmmaker, and political activist born on August 17, 1960. His acting career began with a television appearance in a 1974 episode of *Little House on the Prairie*, directed by his father, Leo Penn. After his 1981 film debut in *Taps*, he gained critical attention for roles in films like *At Close Range* (1986) and *Carlito's Way* (1993). He received his first Academy Award nomination for *Dead Man Walking* (1995) and later won the Best Actor Oscar for *Mystic River* (2003) and *Milk* (2008).

Sir Donald George "Don" Bradman, an Australian cricketer born on August 27, 1908, and who died on February 25, 2001, was known as "The Don" and is widely regarded as the greatest batsman of all time. After retiring, he remained a prominent figure in cricket for three decades, working as an administrator, selector, and writer.
L.A. Reid has served as the chairman and CEO of Epic Records, the president and CEO of Arista Records, and the chairman and CEO of the Island Def Jam Music Group.

Brad Wilk is a drummer, best known for his work with the rock bands Rage Against the Machine (1991â2000; 2007â11) and Audioslave (2001â07). He began his career in 1990 with the band Greta and co-founded Rage Against the Machine in August 1991 with Tom Morello and Zack de la Rocha. As of 2016, he plays in the band Prophets of Rage. The passage also mentions that Rage is a German heavy metal band formed in 1984 by Peter "Peavy" Wagner.

The multi-camera series "The Millers" aired on CBS from October 3, 2013, to July 18, 2015. It ran for 34 episodes over two seasons. CBS announced the show's cancellation on November 14, 2014, four episodes into its second season.

Dorothy Ann Willis Richards (1933-2006) was an American politician who served as the 45th Governor of Texas from 1991 to 1995. A Democrat, she first gained national attention as the Texas state treasurer when she gave the keynote address at the 1988 Democratic National Convention. She was the second female governor of Texas and was defeated for re-election by George W. Bush. The passage also mentions Ann Richards (1935-1982), an American jazz singer and wife of pianist Stan Kenton.
In 2011, Drake Bell independently released an EP titled "A Reminder."

"Boardwalk" is a 1979 American drama film written by Stephen Verona and Leigh Chapman, and directed by Verona. Janet Leigh was an American actress, singer, dancer, and author who wrote four books, including two novels, between 1984 and 2002.

SimoÌn JoseÌ Antonio de la SantiÌsima Trinidad BoliÌvar y Palacios, also known as El Libertador, was a Venezuelan military and political leader born on July 24, 1783, and died on December 17, 1830. He played a leading role in establishing Venezuela, Bolivia, Colombia, Ecuador, Peru, and Panama as sovereign states, independent from Spanish rule.

The Bermuda Triangle, also known as the Devil's Triangle, is a loosely-defined area in the western North Atlantic Ocean where several aircraft and ships have reportedly disappeared under mysterious circumstances.

Colin Kaepernick started his career as a backup quarterback for the 49ers, taking over as the starter in the middle of the 2012 season after Alex Smith was injured. He led the team to a Super Bowl appearance that season, where they lost to the Baltimore Ravens. In his first full season as a starter in 2013, he helped the 49ers reach the NFC Championship, where they lost to the Seattle Seahawks.
Marnie is a 1964 American psychological thriller film directed by Alfred Hitchcock.

Advertising is an audio or visual form of marketing communication that uses an openly sponsored, nonpersonal message to promote or sell a product, service, or idea. Unlike personal selling, it is not directed at a specific individual. Advertising is communicated through various mass media, including old media like newspapers, television, and radio, as well as new media such as search results, blogs, and websites.
*Private Lives* is a 1930 three-act comedy of manners by NoÃ«l Coward and also a 1931 American Pre-Code comedy film directed by Sidney Franklin.

Maurice Harold Macmillan, 1st Earl of Stockton, was a British Conservative politician who served as the Prime Minister of the United Kingdom from 1957 to 1963. He was born on February 10, 1894, and died on December 29, 1986.

Aristotle was an ancient Greek philosopher and scientist born in Stagira, Chalkidice. At age seventeen or eighteen, he joined Plato's Academy in Athens, where he stayed until he was thirty-seven. After Plato's death, Aristotle left Athens and, at the request of Philip II of Macedon, began tutoring Alexander the Great in 343 BC.

David Mordechai Packouz, born February 16, 1982, is an American former arms dealer, musician, inventor, and entrepreneur. He invented a guitar pedal drum machine called the BeatBuddy and is the current CEO of the music technology company Singular Sound.

Magic Johnson was a point guard for the Lakers for 13 seasons. He was the first overall pick in the 1979 NBA draft and won a championship and an NBA Finals MVP award in his rookie season. He won four more championships with the Lakers in the 1980s. After a four-year retirement, he returned in 1996 at age 36 to play 32 games before his final retirement. In 2009, Ebony magazine named him one of America's most influential black businessmen. He has numerous business interests and was a part-owner of the Lakers for several years.

Tenacious D is an American comedy rock duo formed in Los Angeles, California, in 1994. The duo consists of Jack Black (lead vocals and guitarist) and Kyle Gass (lead guitarist and vocalist). Sheikh Ali Salman, leader of the al-Wefaq opposition, told the BBC that for national dialogue to be meaningful, the government must offer "concrete solutions" and have someone who can speak for the royal family. He identified Crown Prince Salman al-Khalifa as a reformist with whom the opposition had previously agreed on a seven-point plan for a constitutional monarchy, but this dialogue was ended by the arrival of GCC troops.

Sheikh Salman stated that hardliners, including the Prime Minister, oppose the dialogue process, fearing concessions will encourage more demands. Despite this and a loss of faith among some young protesters, he insisted dialogue with reformists in the royal family is the only way forward.

He expressed hope that the new US Secretary of State, John Kerry, would apply more pressure for human rights and democracy than his predecessor. He was more critical of the UK, urging its government to "speak out publically" against human rights abuses, as private conversations have been ineffective.

Sheikh Salman confirmed al-Wefaq would continue calling for peaceful demonstrations, despite a ban, as it's the only way to pressure the government. He also called for the release of 13 imprisoned opposition leaders, stating that without their participation, any dialogue would fail.

Christopher Hogwood, an influential conductor and exponent of the early-music movement, died at his home in Cambridge after a several-month illness. In 1973, he founded the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM), which he directed for 30 years, recording over 200 CDs, including the first complete cycle of Mozart symphonies on period instruments. His 1980 recording of Handel's Messiah was named one of the top 20 recordings of all time by BBC Music Magazine. Hogwood held various positions, including artistic director for multiple festivals and societies, and was a professor at several universities, including Cambridge and Harvard. His funeral will be private, with a memorial service to be held later.

In the year to the end of March, 57 homicide victims were recorded, a decrease of five from the previous year and the lowest number since 1976. A sharp instrument was the most common method of killing, accounting for 51% of cases, with most of these involving a knife. As of March 31, 2016, only one homicide case from 2015-16 remained unresolved. Justice Secretary Michael Matheson found the continued fall encouraging, while Scottish Labour's justice spokeswoman Claire Baker urged caution, noting that the previous year's figures were revised upwards from 59 to 62.

Bournemouth, known as "The Cherries," lost 2-1 to Sunderland, who had not won a Premier League game this season. Dan Gosling scored Bournemouth's first goal in three games, giving them the lead. Mr. Abbott stated that stopping boats is the only way to prevent deaths at sea. Australia's policy involves detaining migrants who arrive by boat and taking them to offshore camps for resettlement elsewhere. The New York Times described this policy as "brutal," "inhumane," and of "dubious legality." Mr. Abbott also commented on the "very sad" image of Alan Kurdi, a Syrian three-year-old who died at sea, reiterating his stance to "stop the boats." Additionally, Mr. Abbott angered Australian Jewish groups by saying that the Islamic State (IS) was worse than the Nazis because IS militants "boast about their evil." The Executive Council of Australian Jewry called the comment "injudicious and unfortunate," highlighting the difference between terrorism and a state-implemented genocide. Mr. Abbott later stood by his comments but said he was not in the "business of ranking evil."

The United States has suspended its talks with Russia regarding the Syrian ceasefire. Washington blames Russia and the Syrian government for intensifying attacks on civilians, targeting critical infrastructure like hospitals, and preventing humanitarian aid from reaching those in need in Aleppo. State department spokesman John Kirby stated that Russia failed to meet its commitments and was unable or unwilling to ensure the Syrian regime did the same.

In response, Russia expressed regret over the US decision. Russian foreign ministry spokeswoman Maria Zakharova accused Washington of failing to fulfill the key condition of improving the humanitarian situation in Aleppo and of trying to shift the blame. She also noted that the US had not separated jihadist groups from the moderate opposition.

Despite the suspension of these specific talks, the two countries will continue to communicate to avoid clashes during counter-terrorism operations in Syria.

A report by the think tank Policy Exchange, backed by Downing Street, proposed selling high-value social homes as they become vacant. This could raise Â£4.5 billion a year, enough to build between 80,000 and 170,000 new social homes. The think tank's director, Neil O'Brien, stated that while social housing would still exist in expensive areas, there would be "less of it," and that the scheme could reduce the social housing waiting list by about 500,000.

Labour opposed the idea, with shadow housing minister Jack Dromey arguing it would drive "hard-working families on low wages from whole neighbourhoods." Critics, including the National Housing Federation and Labour MP Karen Buck, warned the move would create segregated communities and push the least well-off out of expensive areas.

The prime minister's official spokesman noted that councils can already choose to do this and should use their housing stock efficiently. Housing Minister Grant Shapps supported the sell-off, mentioning government reforms to get Britain building and reduce waiting lists.

Gareth Colfer-Williams, 25, died at his home in Swansea.
*   **What happened?** He died during a measles epidemic that has reached 942 cases in the city. Laboratory tests confirmed he had measles, but an examination could not establish if it was the main cause of his death.
*   **Timeline:** He was recently treated for asthma at Morriston Hospital. After being discharged, he became unwell, developed a rash, and saw an out-of-hours GP on April 17th. He was found dead the next morning.
*   **Investigation:** An inquest will be opened to allow for further tests to determine the cause of death.
*   **Context:** Since the outbreak began in November, 83 people have required hospital treatment. Mr. Colfer-Williams' family does not know how he contracted measles, as no close family members have it.

Vincent Hudson, 54, of Loweswater Avenue, Whitehaven, has been charged with a historical offence on a boy under the age of 16, which was reported to have taken place in 2001. According to a Cumbria Police spokesman, Mr. Hudson is scheduled to appear before North Cumbria Magistrates' Court.

Bristol Sport Ltd, the owner of the football club, plans to redevelop the stadium by replacing two stands to increase capacity. This plan is an alternative to building a new stadium at Ashton Vale. Majority shareholder Steve Lansdown stated that after signing a section 106 agreement and a six-week judicial review period, the redevelopment plans will proceed, starting in May, if no judicial review is filed.

Cuadrilla, a firm conducting shale gas drilling (fracking), has suspended its operations. This decision was made as a precaution after a 1.5 magnitude tremor occurred, the second in two months. The British Geological Survey (BGS) confirmed this tremor shared a "similar location and mechanism" to a previous one on April 1st. Cuadrilla will now analyze data with the BGS before deciding whether to resume, a process expected to take several weeks. The BGS stated that injecting pressurized water into rocks, as is done in fracking, can cause earthquakes. The latest tremor was felt by at least one person and its epicentre was located within 2km of the Preese Hall drill site at a depth of approximately 2km.

Angus Carpenter, a 62-year-old bagpiper from Liverpool, was found guilty of one count of fraud after playing with a Hillsborough Justice Campaign banner on his bagpipes in April 2015. Carpenter's defense was that he was busking and the banner was a tribute, not for collecting funds. Kenneth Derbyshire, the campaign's chairman, confirmed he gave permission for the banner's display but not for fundraising. Carpenter will be sentenced in January.

The win moved Ipswich up to 14th place, while QPR slipped to 15th. Ipswich manager Mick McCarthy credited the second goal as the key to the comprehensive win, while QPR boss Ian Holloway called the goal a "calamity" and stated his players needed to be "mentally tougher."

Wells, aged 23, scored 373 runs at an average of 28.69 and a strike rate of 138.66 in last season's T20 Blast. He stated that the club is "going in the right direction" and that the environment created by the coaches is one of "elite performance."

The Reds, who are fifth in National Two South, defeated third-placed Chinnor 29-12, marking their second consecutive win. According to Churcher, who spoke to BBC Cornwall, Tommy Phillips, Ben Priddey, and Craig Williams were key leaders in the victory, with the front row and front five making over 70 tackles. The Reds' upcoming schedule includes matches against seven teams ranked below them and one against the league leaders, Old Elthamians. Churcher stated that the performance against Chinnor was "dogged" but not "complete," and emphasized the need for the team to build on this win.

Nazrul, also known as Nazu, a 28-year-old alleged Bangladeshi citizen, has been arrested in Kolkata for the rape of a 74-year-old nun. This is the sixth arrest in the case, with police having identified eight suspects in total, two of whom remain untraced. The five previously arrested suspects named Nazrul as the rapist. Police acted on a tip that Nazu, who had fled to Bangladesh after being identified from CCTV footage, was returning to Kolkata by train.
