The attack occurred on March 14 in Ranaghat town, during which money was stolen from a convent school, the building was ransacked, and the nun was raped. The incident led to outrage and street protests across India. Another arrested individual, Milon Sarkar, was described by police as the leader of the gang.

This passage describes an interactive video featuring Robert Opie, the founder of the Museum of Brands, Packaging and Advertising. The video outlines reasons why consumer buying habits change, citing the arrival of domestic freezers, washing powder, and cheaper imports as factors. The interactive elements also explore changes in the ownership and ranking of the UK's biggest brands. The passage notes that the video may not work on older browsers and provides links to a non-interactive version of the content.

Two women, one from Sandyhills and another from Stranraer, have lost substantial sums of money in separate incidents. In both cases, a caller claiming to be from BT technical support gained remote access to their computers and took cash. The Sandyhills incident occurred on September 15th, and the Stranraer incident happened seven days later. PC Siobhan Pellett warns about the ease with which scammers gain access to victims' computers and advises people to be very careful with cold calls. The police message is to never give out banking details or account numbers over the telephone, as reputable businesses, banks, and building societies will not ask for this information.

Duffy, 37, has joined the third-placed Championship side Featherstone on a one-year contract after leaving Swinton Lions. The Scotland assistant coach will lead Featherstone in their final league game against Toulouse before the Super 8 Qualifiers. Duffy, who previously played for Leigh, Widnes, and Salford, has been replaced at Swinton by his former assistant, Stuart Littler.

At 12:50 GMT on Sunday, a Porthcawl RNLI crew, a medic, and the coastguard search and rescue helicopter were dispatched to Sker Beach. A horse rider with head injuries was found unconscious and very cold on the wet sand. After receiving treatment, she was flown to the University Hospital of Wales in Cardiff.

At a UN conference in Geneva, representatives from over 160 countries decided to dedicate part of the radio spectrum to a global flight tracking system. This new system will enable satellites to receive automatic dependent surveillance-broadcast (ADS-B) transmissions from aircraft, allowing for real-time tracking anywhere in the world. The decision was made in response to the disappearance of flight MH370, which exposed weaknesses in the current ground-based radar system that leaves about 70% of the world's airspace uncovered. The UN's International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO) has set a November 2016 deadline for adopting new tracking guidelines, which will require aircraft to report their position at least every 15 minutes.

Julian Hernandez, who disappeared at age five in 2002, has been found at the age of 18 living in Cleveland with his father, Bobby Hernandez. The father was arrested after the FBI received a tip on October 30th when Julian encountered problems applying for college. Bobby Hernandez is being held in an Ohio jail on $250,000 bail and is also charged with tampering with records to obtain a driver's license in 2012. Julian's mother has been notified of his recovery.

A fire occurred at a site in Duncan Street on 2 March, leading to several days of firefighter presence, reduced train services, and travel delays. The Environment Agency (EA) suspended Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited from accepting waste after the fire and has since decided to revoke their environmental permit, effective 7 August, subject to appeal. The firm, whose site was run by Asset and Land Group, was described by the fire service as "broadly compliant" with fire safety law. The Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service (GMFRS) had visited the site nine times in the last 12 months and raised concerns to the EA in February about the potential impact of a fire. The company is required to remove all waste from the site, and the cause of the fire is undetermined.

The pro-Kremlin party, A Just Russia, has put forward two bills related to the situation in Ukraine, where pro-Russian feelings are strong in the Crimea region.

One bill would change Russia's existing law, which requires a treaty with a neighboring state to allow part of its territory to join the Russian Federation. The new provisions would allow a referendum or a plea from a territory's leaders to be sufficient. Mikhail Yemelyanov of A Just Russia stated the existing law was for "peaceful times" and not for situations where a state is "disintegrating."

The second bill would speed up the process for Ukrainians to get Russian passports. Applicants would not need to pay a state tax, have previous residence in Russia, have sufficient funds, or give up their Ukrainian citizenship. The bill's preamble says it aims to support the "fraternal people of Ukraine" against the "'brown threat'". Under this bill, Ukrainians could apply at Russian diplomatic missions before August 1st and become citizens in two months instead of the current one-year wait.

The plan for the fast-track passport procedure was announced in Sevastopol by A Just Russia leader Sergei Mironov. Several Russian MPs and celebrities have also gone to Crimea.

The McLaren Formula 1 team, despite having two world champions as drivers, has fallen from its past greatness. The team's history includes 182 grand prix wins, 12 drivers' world championships, and eight constructors' titles. The current slump began in 2013 with chassis design issues, and now the problem lies with the Honda power-unit. This is a stark contrast to their most successful era with Honda in 1988, when drivers Ayrton Senna and Alain Prost won 15 of 16 races.

McLaren's history is a cycle of triumph and decline. After titles in 1974 and 1976, the team slipped until Ron Dennis took control, leading to periods of domination. More success came with Mika Hakkinen and Mercedes engines in 1998-99, but the last constructors' title was in 1998. The team was disqualified from the constructors' championship in 2007 due to a scandal involving Ferrari's technical information and faced another scandal in 2009.

Despite the current predicament, Ron Dennis insists success will return and that McLaren will be the team to break Mercedes' dominance. Driver Fernando Alonso returned in 2015, believing the renewed Honda partnership was his best chance for a third title. The team believes their car is among the best and that Honda's engine will improve, allowing them to deliver championships again.

Thomas Baker, a 44-year-old from Everton, was found badly injured at Stanley Meat Market in Liverpool on 27 January after being shot in the head and chest. He later died in the hospital. The shooting occurred as he was getting into his car after leaving Phoenix Gym. Detectives believe the attackers waited outside the gym for about an hour. Three men from Liverpool have been arrested and remain in police custody. Police are searching for a silver VW Polo that left the scene at speed and are appealing for witnesses captured on CCTV to come forward.

The passage describes five ways to experience a more spiritual Christmas online. These include:

*   **Everyday Church Online:** A UK-based virtual church that streams recorded sermons and hosts live chats for a global congregation. Its Christmas theme is Star Wars, with sermons titled "The Hope Awakens."
*   **Guardians of Ancora:** A free-to-play fantasy game for 8 to 11-year-olds where players become "guardians" who rediscover lost Bible stories to bring light back to the world of Ancora. Special Christmas content includes quests about the birth of Jesus.
*   **Nativity Videos:** The passage highlights two videos: "The Digital Story of Nativity," which tells the story through social media updates and has nearly six million views, and "Christmas Starts with a Baby's Giggle," which shows a modern couple transforming into Mary and Joseph.
*   **Manga Messiah:** A company called Next Manga has launched its Japanese-style cartoon versions of Old Testament stories, including the nativity, in app and e-book form. The books are available in 33 languages, with copies sent to Syrian and Libyan refugees.
*   **Social Media:** Christian groups and churches use platforms like Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram to connect with communities, share spiritual thoughts, and encourage people to "consider things that are a bit more spiritual."

An eight-day hearing in Ebbw Vale is examining a request to take over 250 hectares of common land for a circuit. Backers have offered around 320 hectares of replacement land. The inquiry has heard conflicting expert accounts regarding the project's impact on habitats and plant life. Natural Resources Wales stated it was "difficult to conclude" the replacement land was of equal value but did not oppose the development. A report from the developers claimed a "net gain" in biodiversity, a point disputed by the Gwent wildlife trust. The Planning Inspectorate for Wales will make a recommendation, with Welsh government ministers making the final decision.

On April 1st, the newspaper *Novaya Gazeta* reported that over 100 people suspected of being homosexual had been detained in Chechnya, with at least three killed. The Russian LGBT Network confirmed the report, stating that detainees were tortured with electric shocks and beatings at a prison near Argun. In response, Chechen Muslim clerics met on April 3rd, issuing a resolution stating the report insulted their faith and that "retribution will catch up with the true instigators." *Novaya Gazeta* interpreted this as a call for reprisals against journalists. Chechnya's leader, Ramzan Kadyrov, and his spokesman denied the allegations, claiming there are no gay people in Chechnya. The LGBT Network is helping people flee the persecution and has stated it will take the case to the International Criminal Court if Russia fails to act.

Investing Solutions, a letting agent, and Fresh Start Housing, a charity, were both set up by Samir Patel and are based in the same building. Investing Solutions receives housing benefit payments by finding properties for single homeless men, many of whom are referred by Fresh Start Housing. The letting agent generates profit by housing multiple unrelated people in one property and charging housing benefit for each individual, resulting in a total benefit payout that is higher than the rent paid to the property's landlord.

Investing Solutions is one of the UK's largest recipients of housing benefit, receiving over Â£2.1m from Wandsworth Council alone in the past two years. A tenant, Nigel McCann, described being housed in unsuitable properties with issues like rats, damp, and no heating. A homeless group called the relationship between the company and the charity "a new low."

Samir Patel stated that Fresh Start is an independent charity and that the "bulk" of rents are passed to private landlords. Fresh Start said it has housed 788 homeless people since its founding and refers clients to both Investing Solutions and private landlords.

In a final warm-up match before their Eurobasket qualifying campaign, Great Britain (GB) lost to the Netherlands. London 2012 Olympian Andrew Lawrence scored 14 points, and NBA player Ben Gordon added 13. GB led for most of the first three quarters, but the Netherlands, led by Worthy De Jong's 18 points, scored the first 10 points of the fourth quarter to take a 71-60 lead and held on for the win. Coach Joe Prunty stated that the key to the upcoming qualifiers will be "completing on every play" and going hard on both ends of the floor. He was pleased with the contribution of Gordon, who hit three three-pointers in a row in the third quarter. GB's Eurobasket qualifying campaign begins with a game in Hungary.

A waiver for the use of 8oz gloves instead of the regulation 10oz gloves for the 154 lbs fight was submitted by the former five-weight world champion to the Nevada Athletic Commission (NAC) just before the deadline. The NAC, which sanctioned the bout, will debate the matter on August 16. NAC executive director Bob Bennett stated that the commission's primary policy is the health and safety of the fighters.

Bennett also explained the reasoning for approving the fight, citing McGregor's power demonstrated against Nate Diaz, his "granite-like chin," his youth, and his height and reach advantage. He noted that Mayweather has not had a significant knockout in ten years. Bennett has reviewed videos of McGregor's progress and stated, "He's good to go." McGregor's camp hired Hall of Fame referee Joe Cortez, who oversaw a sparring session between McGregor and Paulie Malignaggi.

The Dundee-based Sunday Post is closing its London office, marking the departure of the last two journalists, Gavin Sherriff and Darryl Smith, from Fleet Street. For decades, Fleet Street was the center of British journalism, home to nearly every national paper. The first British daily newspaper, the Daily Courant, was published there in 1702. Former journalists recall its heyday, characterized by smoke-filled newsrooms, the sound of typewriters, numerous pubs filled with reporters, and a heavy drinking culture. The decline began in 1986 when Rupert Murdoch moved his papers to Wapping, leading other newspapers to follow by 1988, adopting cheaper, computerised printing technology. The buildings that once housed newspapers have since been converted for other uses.

J.K. Rowling has stated that comments she receives remind her that there are more decent people in the world than not. The Harry Potter author, who believes in standing up to bullies, previously said her "personal line [had] been crossed" by some abusive comments on Twitter. She faced criticism after donating Â£1m to the No vote campaign in the Scottish independence referendum, having previously donated the same amount to the Labour party in 2008. Rowling revealed she had been called "a traitor" for her political views and blocked some abusive Twitter users she believed were supporters of the Scottish National Party (SNP). However, she also responded to "really nice SNP supporters" and discussed what she had in common with them politically. When a user suggested her books be burned, she joked she would "bring marshmallows." The passage concludes by noting the SNP won 56 of 59 seats in Scotland in the recent election, becoming the UK's third-largest party.

A study by the University of Edinburgh found that children from deprived backgrounds are twice as likely to face police action and five times more likely to be placed on statutory supervision than better-off children who commit the same crime. Household poverty was identified as an exacerbating factor for youth offending, and people in extreme poverty were more likely to be both victims and perpetrators of crime. The study also found that boys were three times more likely than girls to engage in violent acts. A history of police trouble was the strongest predictor of a young person not being in education, employment, or training by age 18.

Another report published in Scottish Justice Matters showed that the recent fall in crime rates in Scotland has not benefited the most deprived communities, where crime remains highly concentrated. The Scottish government responded by stating that Scotland is becoming a safer place, with crime at a 41-year low, and that they are tackling poverty and inequalities.

Mr Haugh, 25, was stabbed in a laneway in the Marian estate on a Sunday morning and later died in hospital. Robbie Walsh has been charged with assault causing serious harm to Mr Haugh and has been remanded in custody. It is alleged that Mr Walsh and two other men entered the estate looking for Mr Haugh, leading to a fight where weapons, including knives and golf clubs, were used. Mr Haugh received a stab wound to his back. Two other men arrested were released without charge. Police recovered knives, golf clubs, a knife handle, and a blood-stained blade at the scene.

In May 2014, Fermanagh MLA Phil Flanagan posted a tweet questioning if Tom Elliott would "reveal how many people he harassed and shot as a member of the UDR." Mr. Elliott, who served in the UDR from 1982 to 1992 and has a clear MoD record, was alerted to the tweet by Ann Travers and Arlene Foster. The tweet was deleted within an hour. In a High Court case, Mr. Flanagan was ordered to issue an apology on Twitter, stating the tweet was "untrue and wholly without foundation." Mr. Elliott stated he felt "totally vindicated" by the outcome. The judge reserved judgement on the amount of compensation, and it was noted that the insurance firm for MLAs has refused to cover Mr. Flanagan for compensation and costs in this case, a decision he is challenging separately.

Hawick Knitwear, which employs over 230 staff, has increased its weekly sweater production from 7,500 to 9,500 to meet a surge in demand. This growth is driven by better-than-expected sales of its new Hawick Knitwear-branded range launched in January, as well as its established business of supplying private label clients. The company, which dates back to 1874, was purchased by managing director Benny Hartop in November of the previous year. Hawick Knitwear sells to various countries in Europe, as well as the USA, Canada, Mexico, and Japan.

Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old lollipop lady, suffered serious head injuries after being struck by a car outside Bedford Road Lower School in Kempston. The driver, Brian Wright, 55, told Luton Crown Court he was blinded by the setting sun. He denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving, although he accepts he struck Mrs Blackburn. The court heard that Mr Wright's VW Golf failed to stop for a red light as Mrs Blackburn was escorting a woman and child across the road. Mr Wright expressed his sorrow for the incident, stating he was in "total shock" and could not remember the colour of the traffic lights. Mrs Blackburn is now in residential care. The trial is ongoing.

A NATO anti-submarine warfare exercise, named "Dynamic Mongoose," is taking place in response to the growing threat from Russian submarines. In the exercise, 10 NATO warships, including the USS Vicksburg and HMS Portland, are hunting a German U-boat, U33, which is acting as the enemy. The exercise highlights the difficulty of locating submarines, which has been likened to finding a needle in a haystack.

The training is seen as important due to recent reports of Russian submarine activity near Sweden, Finland, and the UK. Russia has been heavily investing in its military, now possessing a fleet of around 60 submarines, which are described as technologically advanced and the "quietest and most challenging adversary in the world."

The exercise also reveals a significant gap in Britain's defences, as it no longer has its own maritime patrol aircraft and has had to rely on NATO allies for surveillance. This vulnerability is a cause for concern, as a Russian submarine could potentially track the UK's nuclear deterrent. The exercise demonstrates that some nations, like Britain, cannot conduct anti-submarine warfare alone.

United Nations officials are now using the terms "genocide" and "ethnic cleansing" to describe the violence in South Sudan. Since July, 340,000 people have fled into neighbouring Uganda, a number greater than those who fled Syria in 2016. Refugees report killings, rape, and the targeting of civilians along ethnic lines. The civil war, which began as a dispute between the Dinka President and the Nuer former Vice-President, has spread to the Equatoria states. Uganda has been coping well, providing refugees with land and supplies to build shelters and plant crops, but with nearly a million refugees, it is beginning to struggle. Bidi Bidi, once a village, is now one of the world's largest refugee settlements, home to over a quarter of a million people. Aid agencies are calling on the international community to pressure South Sudanese leaders to stop the violence.

McKenzie, 38, is a former footballer who became a professional boxer in 2013. He is scheduled to fight Jahmaine Smyle for the English super-middleweight championship on 12 November at York Hall. His boxing record is eight wins and one draw from nine fights. He is the son of former champion Clinton McKenzie and is trained by his uncle, Duke McKenzie.

A new Bridgwater Community Hospital is being funded as part of a Â£330m investment for new NHS facilities. The total cost of the project is Â£33m, with the balance being paid for by NHS Somerset and Somerset Partnership NHS Foundation Trust. The new hospital will have 30 inpatient beds, a midwifery-led maternity unit, a minor injury unit, X-ray facilities, and space for mobile scanners. It is intended to replace the current hospital, which was built in 1813 and is now considered outdated, cramped, and in need of constant maintenance. Somerset PCT hopes to build the new hospital on land at Bowers Lane, with the aim of it being finished by autumn 2014.

A man was fatally injured from a gunshot wound to the chest outside a property on Daniel Hill Terrace, Upperthorpe. He was found by officers at about 13:35 GMT and was either in or near a black Mercedes he had been driving. The victim was taken to Northern General hospital but died. Local residents stated the man was a member of a family living near the scene and that relatives were gathering for a celebration when the attack happened. This incident follows several other recent shootings in Sheffield, though those occurred in the north of the city, in areas such as Shiregreen, Southey Green, and High Green.

The passage describes the activities of three prominent virtual warrior groups involved in the Russia-Ukraine conflict: the Ukrainian Cyber Troops, Cyber Berkut, and Anonymous International.

*   **Ukrainian Cyber Troops:** Led by Yevhen Dokukin, this pro-Ukrainian group claims to have hacked Russian interior ministry servers and police email accounts. They use distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks to make rebel websites inaccessible, disrupt separatist funding on platforms like PayPal, and hack CCTV systems to monitor troop movements. They have also claimed to hijack network printers to print pro-Ukrainian messages.

*   **Cyber Berkut:** This anti-Western group's goal is to thwart Ukraine's military plans. They have hacked Ukrainian government websites, claimed to retrieve confidential documents from a US official's mobile device, and used electronic billboards in Kiev to display anti-Ukrainian messages. They also claim to have disrupted election systems, leaked Ukrainian defence ministry data, and hacked a conversation related to the downing of flight MH17.

*   **Anonymous International (Shaltay Boltay):** This Russian activist group focuses on Russia's domestic affairs but has also published material related to Ukraine. They leaked a letter from a Russian fighter suggesting a lack of local support for separatists and emails from a key rebel commander. It is unclear if they obtain their material through hacking or from insiders.

Presiding Officer Tricia Marwick became emotional during the farewell speeches of veteran Labour MSP Duncan McNeil and former First Minister Alex Salmond, both of whom are standing down. Mr Salmond stated that Scotland was "not divided, but diverse" and welcomed the transfer of powers to Holyrood, though he felt the Scotland Bill did not fulfill referendum pledges. He concluded his speech by saying, "goodbye from me... for now". Mr McNeil, who has served since 1999, warned that Holyrood needed to learn from Westminster's committee system to ensure accountability and scrutiny. Former Scottish Conservative MSP Annabel Goldie is also stepping down.

Sarah Rochira, the Older People's Commissioner for Wales, is conducting a review into the quality of life and care for older people in residential care in Wales. She will gather evidence from pensioners, their friends, and families to develop recommendations for care providers and public bodies. The review will highlight both good and poor care, addressing what Ms Rochira calls "unacceptable variations" across Wales. The review will examine factors like physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment. While Care Forum Wales supports the review's aims, its chair, Mario Kreft, expressed disappointment that the main advisory panel does not include a provider expert, such as someone who has lived in, worked in, managed, or owned a care home.

In the year ending June 2016, Aberdeenshire-based Harbro Group's pre-tax profit increased by Â£800,000 to Â£3.5m, despite turnover falling by Â£1m to just over Â£100m. The company, which manufactures and supplies animal feeds and operates 19 Country Store shops in Scotland, saw growth in international sales. While acknowledging that the outlook for agriculture is difficult to predict and that the industry has faced challenging times, the company's board is confident it is well-positioned to handle any challenges brought about by Brexit.

A man in his 70s was found dead at a house in Nettleden Road, Little Gaddesden, and police are treating the death as murder.
*   **Who is involved?** A man in his 80s was taken to hospital. Police want to question 55-year-old Ian John McLoughlin (also known as Ian John Baker) in connection with the offence and have warned the public not to approach him.
*   **What is the suspect's description?** He is described as white, about 6ft tall, of average build, with straight, greying, collar-length hair. He was believed to be wearing sunglasses, blue jeans or three-quarter length trousers, and a checked short-sleeved shirt.
*   **What are the police doing?** Police are conducting additional patrols in the area and have urged anyone with information to contact them or Crimestoppers.

David Lipton, the second in command at the IMF, stated in a speech that the IMF's latest reading of the global economy shows a weakening baseline and that "we are clearly at a delicate juncture." His comments followed weaker-than-expected trade figures from China, where exports plunged by a quarter from a year ago. The IMF has indicated it will likely downgrade its current 3.4% global growth forecast in its next release of economic predictions in April. This situation has ongoing ramifications for businesses and industries that have bet on China's growth.

A new chain ferry has experienced several issues since its launch, including breaking down, running aground, being suspended due to "training issues," and causing damage to cars. In response, council leader Dave Stewart announced the crossing at Cowes would be free until 2 July and that a project review had been ordered. A local shopkeeper, Angie Booth, expressed concern about the loss of trade and asked about compensation for businesses. Transport councillor Ian Ward stated that compensation was "up for discussion" and described the issues as "teething problems" for a "prototype." He mentioned that electrical problems had been rectified, ramp extensions were authorized to prevent vehicle damage, and grounding issues were related to seamanship which had been resolved.

A multi-vehicle crash occurred on the southbound carriageway near the Hindhead tunnel at Bramshott at approximately 07:30 GMT on Thursday. A 32-year-old man was pronounced dead at the scene. A 33-year-old man from Waterlooville was arrested on suspicion of causing death by driving without due care and attention. The road was closed between Thursley and Liphook until early evening for investigation.

Matching Models, an international temp agency, advertised for a personal assistant with "a classic look, brown long hair with b-c cup". The Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) called the ad "appalling, unlawful and demeaning to women" and stated it would be writing to the agency to clarify its hiring practices. Women's equality campaigners, including Sam Smethers of the Fawcett Society, said the ads were "straight out of the 1970s" and likely violate equality legislation.

The agency's founder, Nathalie Jansen, defended the practice, stating, "Our clients are important to us - and looks are important." She cited a client who wanted a specific cup size for a Christian Dior outfit and another who hired six blonde, blue-eyed Greek women. Another ad on the agency's site sought a "sexy female driver" for a Porsche.

Employment lawyer James Lynas called the driver ad "clearly unlawful" and noted that an employment tribunal could find phrases like "beautiful and attractive" to be discriminatory code for "young". He also stated that a male applicant rejected for the driver job could sue for sex discrimination, for which compensation is unlimited.

The agency's website says it understands the importance of having "attractive" people represent a company. The EHRC's chief executive, Rebecca Hilsenrath, responded that first impressions are not about hair colour and that the agency should "consign this type of sexism to the history books." The passage notes that under the 2010 Equality Act, it is illegal to discriminate based on factors like sex, age, or disability. Matching Models' clients include MTV, Louis Vuitton, and Harrods.

A shooting occurred at a hostel for the Pragati Residential School in Bangalore. The alleged gunman, Mahesh, who worked as an office assistant at the school, is accused of shooting two students. On Tuesday evening, he allegedly entered the room of 18-year-old Gautami and shot her in the head with a pistol. He then shot another student, Sirisha, who was severely injured but is out of danger. Mahesh was arrested on Wednesday after a manhunt and has been remanded until 12 April. Gun crime incidents in Indian schools are very rare, though a large number of feuds are settled with firearms. In a separate incident in 2007, a 14-year-old was shot dead by two students near Delhi.

Based on its "Where We Are on TV" study of shows from June 2016 to May 2017, the advocacy group Glaad counted 278 regular and recurring LGBT characters. The number of transgender characters increased from seven to 16. However, Glaad noted that over 25 lesbian and bisexual female characters died, including Poussey Washington in *Orange is the New Black* and Bea Smith in *Wentworth*. The report also found a record high percentage of black characters on broadcast television. Glaad's president, Sarah Kate Ellis, stated that while progress is "heartening," the numbers are "only part of the story."

David Mackintosh, the Conservative MP for Northampton South, has announced he will not seek re-election. This decision came before a local party meeting where his candidacy was expected to be opposed. Mr. Mackintosh faced criticism over a Â£10.25m loan made by the borough council to Northampton Town Football Club while he was council leader. The loan, intended for stadium rebuilding, is now missing, and the football stand remains half-built. The matter is subject to a police investigation into "alleged financial irregularities." Mr. Mackintosh has denied any wrongdoing. A majority of his party's local executive council had indicated they would vote to deselect him.

Roy Oliver, a 37-year-old policeman, fired a rifle into a car of teenagers driving away from a party in Balch Springs, killing 15-year-old Jordan Edwards. Police were at the party responding to reports of underage drinking when they heard what they believed to be gunshots. Oliver fired into the car as it was driving away. Police initially claimed the car reversed "aggressively" towards the officer, but footage showed the car was driving forward and away from him. Oliver was sacked for policy violations and charged with murder and four counts of aggravated assault. He faces five to 99 years in prison on the murder charge and is currently free on bail. No trial date has been set.

Based on the text provided, here is a concise summary:

Melania Trump and her son, Barron, will not immediately move to the White House, waiting instead for Barron to finish his school year. This decision has drawn both criticism and support on social media. Historically, it is rare for a First Lady not to live in the White House, with only two previous exceptions: Martha Washington, as the White House wasn't built, and Anna Harrison, whose husband died before she could move in. However, a historian notes it is not unusual for presidential children to finish a school year before moving. The role of the First Lady is described as ceremonial but vital to the public's perception of the president, with modern First Ladies often taking on active public roles and supporting specific causes. The passage also notes that other presidential family members, like Ivanka Trump or Chelsea Clinton, have sometimes taken on First Lady duties.

A 72-year-old man died in a sheltered housing complex in Inverness on 27 October. The Police Investigations and Review Commissioner (Pirc), Kate Frame, has been instructed by the Crown Office and Procurator Fiscal Service (COPFS) to investigate the initial police response to the man's call. Police Scotland is "fully engaging" with the investigation. A report on the findings will be submitted to the COPFS.

A yellow wind warning has been issued for gusts up to 75mph (120kmph), particularly west of the mountains. The unusual easterly direction of the wind could increase its impact. Travel disruption on roads and at sea is likely in the counties of Conwy, Anglesey, Gwynedd, Pembrokeshire, Carmarthenshire, Ceredigion, and Powys. A fallen tree on Anglesey has closed Telford Road in Menai Bridge, with the closure expected to last most of Monday for clean-up.

In a hockey game between the Giants and the Nottingham Panthers, the Giants scored first with a short-handed goal from Derrick Walser, but the Panthers' Jeff Dimmen tied the game. In the second period, Mike Forney's powerplay goal put the Giants ahead 2-1, followed by an equalizer from Andy Bohmback. Mike Radja and James Desmarais then scored to make it 4-2 for the Giants. Nottingham's David Ling scored to make the final score 4-3. The teams will play again on Saturday. Nottingham leads the league with 28 points, followed by Sheffield Steelers with 27 and Belfast with 25.

The race was incident-packed, particularly on the first lap, which led to the introduction of a safety car. World champion Hamilton started from the back, broke his front wing on lap one, and made five pit stops. Ferrari's Sebastian Vettel finished second after colliding with his teammate Kimi Raikkonen on the first lap. Raikkonen recovered to finish fifth. The Red Bulls of Daniil Kvyat and Daniel Ricciardo finished third and fourth, respectively. Ricciardo had initially taken the lead from pole-sitter Rosberg but suffered a puncture on lap three, allowing Rosberg to pass and drive off into the distance. Hamilton's car sustained damage in a first-lap incident with Sauber's Felipe Nasr, which affected its aerodynamic performance and his progress through the race.

In an interview with the newspaper Die Zeit, footballer Thomas Hitzlsperger announced he was gay to advance discussion on a topic he felt was "simply ignored" in German football. He is the most prominent footballer to publicly reveal his homosexuality.

His announcement received praise and support from former teammates like Lukas Podolski and Arne Friedrich, as well as from German football administration figures such as former German Football Association president Theo Zwanziger and Bundesliga president Reinhard Rauball. Support also came from Gary Lineker, Joseph Barton, John Amaechi, and Bayern Munich.

The announcement is considered a "watershed moment" in Germany, where homophobia in football has been an issue. In 2011, Germany captain Philipp Lahm had advised gay footballers against coming out. The last German player to come out was Marcus Urban in 2007.

German Chancellor Angela Merkel's spokesman, Steffen Seibert, praised Hitzlsperger, stating that in Germany, "nobody should be worried about making his sexuality known." Politician Volker Beck and former FA president Theo Zwanziger expressed hope that this would break down taboos and lead to greater openness in football.

Steve Sidwell, a 34-year-old midfielder, has made 32 Championship appearances for Brighton this season, helping them achieve promotion to the top flight for the first time in 34 years. His one-year contract is set to expire, and he hopes to sign a new deal to be part of the team in the Premier League. Sidwell believes he has played well and given himself every opportunity to earn a new contract. Brighton's promotion was confirmed after a win against Wigan, and they are now aiming to win the league title. Sidwell previously played for Brighton on loan from Stoke in 2015-16 before signing his current deal in June 2016.

The football match between Blackpool and Colchester United ended in a 1-1 draw. Blackpool scored first after 12 minutes when Jamille Matt turned the ball home from three yards, following a chip into the area from Nathan Delfouneso. Colchester equalised five minutes later from a corner, with Kurtis Guthrie prodding the ball in from close range after a goalmouth scramble. Both teams had chances to win, with Blackpool's Tom Aldred heading wide from eight yards and Colchester's Kurtis Guthrie heading against the bar from two yards. Colchester finished the game with 10 men after substitute Sean Murray received a straight red card for a bad tackle on Jim McAlister in injury time.

A 29-year-old player named Reid has joined the U's. Last season, he made 37 appearances for the Sky Blues, who were relegated from League One. Reid has also played for Charlton, Bradford, and Preston. He might make his debut for the U's in an EFL Cup match against Aston Villa on Wednesday. Colchester's season began with a 3-1 loss to Accrington.

A permanent memorial for police officers and staff is being built at the National Memorial Arboretum in Alrewas, Staffordshire. The murder of PC Keith Palmer in March prompted a "greater emphasis" on the need for this memorial. The UK Police Memorial Trust appealed for Â£1.5m towards the Â£4m project, with the government committing Â£1m. The memorial will bear the names of over 1,400 officers and staff who have lost their lives over the past 250 years. It will feature a brass screen with leaf shapes cut out, which will be given to the families of fallen officers as a personal memorial. The project is expected to be completed by 2019.

Following a 1-0 victory at Sunderland, Manchester United are 15 points clear at the top of the table with eight games remaining. Manager Ferguson noted that the players have set a record with 25 wins in their first 30 matches. Their next league game is against Manchester City. Ferguson plans to make changes for the upcoming FA Cup quarter-final replay at Chelsea due to injuries sustained by Rafael, Anderson, and David De Gea during the Sunderland match. He mentioned that players like Ryan Giggs, Javier Hernandez, and Rio Ferdinand will be available for the Chelsea game.

Mr. Schmidt stated that Google's tax payments are what is "legally required" and that it is the government's responsibility to change the tax system if they want companies to pay more. He said Google paid Â£10m in UK corporate taxes between 2006 and 2011. Margaret Hodge, head of the Parliamentary Public Accounts Committee, suggested a new committee be established to oversee the tax arrangements of major firms, potentially hearing evidence in secret. Google has been criticised for minimising its UK tax payments by routing most of its UK sales through Ireland. EU leaders have agreed to tackle tax avoidance through an "automatic information exchange between tax authorities." Mr. Schmidt has previously argued that corporate taxes should be levied where a company conducts economic activity and has called for a debate on international tax reform.

The regulator, NHS Improvement, wants more progress in reducing the NHS agency staff bill, which is behind schedule. Last year, Â£3.6bn was spent on agency staff, and the regulator aims to reduce this by Â£1bn by the end of the financial year. A cap introduced in October, limiting payments to 55% above normal shift rates, has saved Â£600m so far. Despite this "promising" progress, NHS trusts are still 10% behind their target. NHS Improvement plans to publish "league tables" on trust spending and collect data on the highest-earning agency staff, as some hospitals are still being quoted rates double the capped amount.

The Longford Town Centre, once a symbol of the Celtic Tiger, now represents Ireland's economic crash. However, local traders like Matt O'Brien are seeing a slow turnaround in business, which they have encouraged by diversifying their offerings. The main opposition party, Fianna FÃ¡il, criticizes the government for neglecting the area, citing a lack of investment from the Industrial Development Authority (IDA) and suggesting funds be spent on broadband instead of water meters. The government points to the planned Center Parcs development, which hopes to employ 1,000 people, as evidence of its commitment, though it still requires planning permission. Local traders believe more could be done, such as providing free parking to attract more people to the town. The overall message is that while an economic recovery is beginning in the midlands, more action is needed.

The competition, which finishes on 29 May, involves eight teams playing each other twice. The top four teams will qualify for the play-offs. The leading run-scorers are Warner (294), Kohli (267), and De Villiers (249). Warner and De Villiers have the most sixes with 12 each. The highest score in an innings is 108 by De Kock. The leading wicket-takers are McClenaghan (9), Kumar (8), and Rahman (7). Four current or former England players are participating: Eoin Morgan, Jos Buttler, Sam Billings, and Kevin Pietersen. A schedule of fixtures is provided from Monday, 25 April to the final on Sunday, 29 May.

According to a study by the Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs, the number of plastic carrier bags has increased by 200 million since 2013. These bags, many of which cannot be recycled, are often thrown away after a single use, ending up in rubbish dumps and rivers, which causes environmental problems. To address this, people in England will be charged 5p for plastic bags from October to encourage reuse. This charge is already in place in Wales, Scotland, and Northern Ireland, where supermarkets have seen a decrease in bag usage. Campaigners hope the charge in England will reduce the number of bags being thrown away.

High winds in Wales caused a school roof to be partially ripped off in Rhosgadfan, power cuts to hundreds of homes, and travel disruption.
*   **Travel Impacts:** Train services experienced delays and speed restrictions, particularly between Llandudno Junction and Holyhead. Irish Ferries cancelled six fast sailings between Holyhead and Dublin. Major bridges like the A55 Britannia Bridge and the M48 Severn Bridge had temporary speed and lane restrictions.
*   **Other Effects:** The National Trust closed Erddig Hall and Chirk Castle. Rhyl's Boxing Day Dip was postponed by 24 hours.
*   **Weather Details:** A yellow "be aware" warning for wind was in effect until midnight on Friday. The highest gusts were recorded at Mona on Anglesey. The winds eased by Friday evening.

Michael B. Jordan told The Hollywood Reporter he was "super excited" for a new film and wanted "to put a different spin on it," but did not say what his role would be. The film will reunite him with his Creed director, Ryan Coogler. Jordan said he was looking forward to working with Coogler again and also with Lupita Nyong'o and Chadwick Boseman. Jordan previously played the Human Torch in the Fantastic Four reboot. Nyong'o played Maz Kanata in Star Wars: The Force Awakens, and Boseman is currently playing Black Panther in Captain America: Civil War. The Black Panther film is set to be released in February 2018.

The theatre at Alexandra Palace, founded in 1875, is part of a larger east wing restoration project. The project also includes repairing and refurbishing the BBC studios. The goal is to transform the palace into a new cultural destination, with the theatre hosting performances, cinema, comedy, and music, and the glazed east court becoming a public and exhibition space. The total cost for the east wing refurbishment is Â£26.6m, funded by an Â£18.8m contribution from the Heritage Lottery Fund (HLF), Â£6.8m from Haringey Council, and a final Â£1m to be raised by the Alexandra Park and Palace Charitable Trust. If fundraising is successful, the theatre, which has been unused for decades but retains original decor and machinery, is hoped to reopen in 2018.

The former Manchester City man, aged 30, won 61 caps for England after his 2009 senior debut. He was a squad member at two World Cups and two European Championships. He holds the record for the most England Under-21 caps with 46. His only international goal was in a 5-0 victory over Moldova during the 2014 Fifa World Cup qualifiers.

Marcy Smith's house in Glovertown, Newfoundland and Labrador, was destroyed by a fire. Her son, David, woke her up, allowing the family to escape, though their dog and cats did not survive. David was awake because he was on FaceTime with his father and saw the flames. The fire, which started from rubbish burned in a wood stove, spread so quickly that the fire alarm did not go off. The family escaped in their pyjamas, but the community has provided them with donations of clothes, shoes, and a bike for David. Mrs. Smith credits her son with saving her and her daughter's lives.

It was reported that an energy drinks giant was considering a Â£200m offer for the Premier League club, West Ham. The club's majority stakeholders, Sullivan and Gold, who bought their stake in 2010 in a deal valuing the club at Â£105m, now own over 85% of the club. West Ham has also been linked with takeovers from Qatari and Chinese groups since moving to London Stadium. Last year, Sullivan stated that a minority shareholding might be sold to clear debts, but he and Gold intend for the ownership to be passed on to their children.

The passage describes an awards ceremony that is different from the Oscars, featuring fan-voted categories like "best kiss" and "best shirtless performance," which was won by Efron. The ceremony also served as a promotional platform for upcoming summer blockbusters, showing clips from films like the *Pitch Perfect* sequel, *Trainwreck*, and *Ultron*.

The big winner of the night was *The Fault in Our Stars*, which won best movie. Its star, Shailene Woodley, won best female performance, the Trailblazer Award, and best kiss. Other winners included:
*   Bradley Cooper for best male performance in *American Sniper*.
*   Channing Tatum for best comedic performance in *22 Jump Street*.
*   Meryl Streep for best villain in *Into the Woods*.
*   Kevin Hart, who received the comedic genius award.
*   Robert Downey Jr., who accepted the Generation Award, presented by his *Avengers* co-stars.

Jennifer Lopez, Jennifer Lawrence, Seth Rogen, and Rose Byrne were also among the winners.

Cammy Smith, 21, was loaned by the Dons to United in July and has scored five goals this season. A Scotland Under-21 cap, Smith made his Aberdeen debut in 2012, scoring four times in 89 appearances. St Mirren boss Jack Ross described him as a "brilliant acquisition" and a "really good player" who will provide another option in the attacking area. St Mirren, who are at the bottom of the Championship, are set to host Falkirk on Saturday.

Northumberland County Council is using Jetpatcher machines to fill 145 potholes daily over the next four months, as the weather is now warm enough. Additionally, extra staff will repair drainage systems and clear debris from gutters.

In December 2016, six Wood Group contractors were exposed to low levels of naturally occurring radioactive material (NORM) while working on EnQuest's Thistle platform, off Shetland. Rigging supervisor Steve Innes stated that the workers were not wearing the proper personal protective equipment (PPE) because they had been told the area was clear. He said the workers now face cancer fears and are undergoing blood tests.

EnQuest confirmed the incident, stating the exposure level was less than 1% of the reportable level to the Health and Safety Executive (HSE), but that they had advised the HSE at the time. EnQuest said it has since taken "additional precautionary steps". Wood Group stated that employee safety is its top priority and that it had downmanned the employees for medical assessments. The HSE was made aware of the incident but said it was not reportable under the RIDDOR system and no investigation was carried out.

In 2007, the Asian Civilisation Museum (ACM) purchased an artwork for $650,000 from New York dealer Art of the Past. The dealer's manager later admitted to selling stolen Indian antiquities, including the bronze sculpture of the Hindu goddess Uma Parameshvari, which is believed to have been stolen from a temple in Tamil Nadu, India. Allegations against the firm emerged in a 2012 court case. Following discussions with the Archaeological Survey of India (ASI) and an official request in May, the ACM decided to return the sculpture. The museum noted the dealer's confession, even without conclusive proof of the theft. The sculpture was one of 30 items purchased from the dealer, and the museum intends to take legal action for compensation.

A magnitude-4.8 earthquake struck at a depth of 15.5km, 35km north of Lucca, with its epicentre in Garfagnana. The tremor, which occurred at 15:48 (14:48 GMT), was felt as far away as Milan, Florence, Bologna, and Modena. There were no immediate reports of injuries or damage, but as a precaution, schools were evacuated. In the Garfagnana area, phone lines were down and power supplies were cut. Several aftershocks of lower magnitude were also felt.

The passage also references previous earthquakes in Italy:
*   In May of the previous year, two earthquakes in the same area killed over 20 people.
*   In 2009, a quake in L'Aquila killed almost 300 people. Following this, six scientists and an ex-official were convicted of multiple manslaughter for providing a falsely reassuring statement about the danger of tremors before the deadly quake.

On 8 September 2016, Austin Grant, a 62-year-old grandfather from Sheffield, expressed his joy after successfully growing a fruit, which was still attached to the plant and not yet ripe. He had previously been dubious about the suitability of South Yorkshire's climate for growing it.

Rockstar has delayed the release of their game until 24 March, moving it from the original 27 January date to allow for extra testing and polish. The company also announced that online heists will be available on consoles before the PC release. The PC version will support 1080p at 60fps, up to 4K resolution, and triple monitor configurations. Minimum PC specifications have been published.

A 76-year-old artist named Simpson won the Â£25,000 John Moores Painting Prize for his work, Squint (19).
*   **What is the painting?** The painting depicts a "leper squint," which were holes in medieval churches for "undesirables" to view the service. Judge Ansel Krut described it as "extraordinary" and "difficult to look at." The painting is about 7ft (2.1m) high.
*   **Artist's reaction:** Simpson, who was previously shortlisted in 1991, said winning was "very nice indeed" and that the prize money would be spent on art materials like canvas and paints.
*   **About the prize:** The John Moores Painting Prize, established in 1957, is one of Britain's oldest art awards. Previous winners include David Hockney and Peter Doig, and Sir Peter Blake is its patron.

The offices of the daily newspapers Yeni Safak and Yeni Akit were attacked by masked assailants with gunfire and Molotov cocktails. The attacks happened at almost the same time early on Thursday, despite the offices being 20km apart. No casualties were reported, but windows were shattered, and a fire at the Yeni Safak building was extinguished. Police found numerous spent bullet casings at both scenes and are hunting for the assailants. Both papers support the governing AK Party. No group has claimed responsibility for the attacks.

A 24-year-old player, who was under contract with the Stags, is joining Marcus Bignot's side on a free transfer. He was previously on loan at Crawley, where he scored three goals in 23 appearances. The ex-Burton player will officially join on 1 January and is Bignot's first signing for the Mariners.

ArsÃ¨ne Wenger, whose contract runs until the summer, has been linked with the England manager job but stated he is focused on his current role. He believes Gareth Southgate, who succeeded Sam Allardyce in September, has the experience and competency for the position. Southgate has two upcoming matches to persuade the Football Association to give him the job permanently. Wenger also announced that Arsenal will offer a new contract to defender Hector Bellerin, dismissing speculation linking him to Barcelona and Manchester City, and stated that Bellerin's long-term future is with the club. Additionally, midfielder Aaron Ramsey is expected to miss another one or two games due to a hamstring injury.

A local man, who worked at Fruehauf on Houghton Road, is believed to have fallen from a cherry picker at approximately 13:45 GMT on Thursday. Lincolnshire Police and the Health and Safety Executive are conducting a joint inquiry, and the company is cooperating fully with the investigation.

A new charter arrangement will end a dispute over seafarers' pay on two freight boats, the Hellier and Hildasay, which serve the Northern Isles. The RMT union had claimed some workers were paid less than Â£4 an hour. The services, previously operated by Seatruck under contract to Serco Northlink, will return to Serco Northlink next month. Transport Minister Humza Yousaf confirmed that under the new arrangement, all crew members will be paid at least the minimum wage.

Ken Dickie, 64, died in hospital on 14 May, six days after an incident at the Rockley Park site in Poole. Jamie Mitchell, 35, admitted intervening in an argument between Mr. Dickie and his mother, Samantha Mitchell. The two men had a confrontation outside the holiday park bar after drinking alcohol. Mr. Mitchell pleaded guilty to common assault. He and his mother also admitted to attempting to pervert the course of justice by initially lying to the police about the events. They will be sentenced on 6 February.

Rod Temperton, a songwriter nicknamed "The Invisible Man" due to his low profile, died in London at the age of 66 after a brief battle with cancer. His private funeral has already taken place.

Temperton was known for writing hits for Michael Jackson, including "Off The Wall," "Rock With You," "Thriller," and "Baby Be Mine." He also wrote "Boogie Nights" for his own band, Heatwave. His songs were recorded by other artists such as Anita Baker, Donna Summer, and Aretha Franklin.

Born in Cleethorpes, Temperton attributed his songwriting ability to his father putting a transistor radio in his crib. After working in a frozen food factory, he joined the disco group Heatwave in the 1970s. His work caught the attention of producer Quincy Jones, leading to his collaboration with Michael Jackson on the albums *Off The Wall* and *Thriller*. Temperton won a Grammy Award in 1990 and was nominated for two Oscars in 1986 for his work on the soundtrack for *The Color Purple*. Tributes were paid by figures like Nile Rodgers, LaToya Jackson, and Mark Ronson.

A team of researchers, including Dr Neil Loader and Emeritus Prof Alayne Street-Perrott from Swansea University, have found ancient earthworks, possibly 2,000 years old.

*   **Where?** The discoveries were made in Acre state in the western Brazilian Amazon.

*   **What?** Over 450 large geometrical "geoglyphs" (ditched enclosures) were found, concealed for centuries by rainforest until modern deforestation.

*   **Purpose?** The function of the sites is not fully understood. They are unlikely to be villages or for defense. It is thought they were used sporadically, perhaps as ritual gathering places.

*   **Environment?** Analysis of soil samples indicates the geoglyphs were constructed amongst taller vegetation and were likely not visible above the forest canopy.

*   **Human Impact?** The research suggests that instead of burning large tracts of forest, people transformed their environment by concentrating on economically valuable trees, creating a "prehistoric supermarket." This indicates the Amazon was not a pristine ecosystem free from human influence before Europeans arrived.

In a 53-minute match, Australian tennis player Nick Kyrgios, 21, defeated world number 29 Sam Querrey 6-4 6-4, advancing to the second round. Kyrgios, who is ranked a career-high 12th, stated he felt tired and "a bit bored at times" during the match, attributing his fatigue to his recent Japan Open win and the travel involved. He mentioned a lack of sleep and the long ride to the Qi Zhong Stadium as contributing factors. The passage also notes that Kyrgios was fined $1,500 at the same tournament the previous year for a foul-mouthed outburst.

Scientists and charities are calling for the human papilloma virus (HPV) jab to be rolled out to protect against head and neck cancers, stating that the number of cases is increasing. HPV is sexually transmitted, and currently, girls aged 12 and 13 receive the vaccine to protect against cervical cancer. Charities, BMA Cymru, and Cardiff University's HPV research team are delivering a letter to the Welsh government urging them to vaccinate boys. Dr Mererid Evans noted a change in demographics over the last ten years, with younger people, three-quarters of whom are men, being affected. The Welsh government has stated it is waiting for advice and recommendations from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation before considering any changes to the HPV vaccination programme.

Jak Trueman, a 15-year-old with a rare form of blood cancer called gamma delta T-cell lymphoma, has died. His mother, Allison, announced his death on his Facebook page, "Jak's Journey." Jak, a pupil at West Calder High School, had been documenting his life and treatment on social media since his diagnosis in August. He briefly attended a school prom held in his honour, where he was greeted by former Rangers captain Barry Ferguson. At the party, his family collected his Bronze Duke of Edinburgh Award and the Kerry MacGregor Memorial Trophy. Doctors had recently informed Jak and his family that the cancer had spread and they would not be pursuing further treatment. In his final days, Jak's family urged people to donate to a fundraising page for Leukaemia & Lymphoma Research.

In a largely uneventful game, Egypt defeated Uganda 1-0. The winning goal was scored by Abdallah El Said in the 89th minute, assisted by Mohamed Salah. Uganda had a goal disallowed for offside earlier in the match. The victory means Egypt will play Ghana for the top spot in Group D, while Uganda has been eliminated from the tournament.

Lancashire County Council has identified land on the former Glenburn Sports College and Skelmersdale College as the preferred location for a new railway station in Skelmersdale. This decision was made after a comparative study by Network Rail. The council, which owns the Glenburn site, is working in partnership with Merseytravel and West Lancashire Borough Council. The plans could provide two direct trains to Liverpool per hour. The chosen location is large enough for future expansion and has good highway access and connectivity. The council will now begin the process of acquiring the necessary land. Skelmersdale's original station closed to passengers in 1956, and it is one of the largest towns in the north west of England without a railway station.
During a search of a warehouse near Ashbourne on Saturday morning, plants were discovered in what police described as "an elaborate grow house." A man in his late 40s was arrested at the scene.

A 28-year-old woman was found with serious injuries on a pavement in Hamelin, Lower Saxony, after being dragged by the neck through several streets. She underwent an emergency operation and was flown to a specialist clinic. The woman's ex-partner, a 38-year-old man from Bad Muender, later handed himself in to authorities and is now in custody. Both the victim and the suspect are German citizens of Kurdish origin. According to a spokesman for Hannover prosecutors, the motive is not yet clear. Police have secured the area and are seeking witnesses.

A study by the Cass Business School and the universities of Warwick and Wisconsin, which looked at 4,600 workers, found that women are as likely as men to ask for a pay rise. The research found "no support" for the "reticent female" theory. When comparing like-for-like workers, men were 25% more likely to get a pay rise when they asked. The study, which used data from the 2013-14 Australian workplace relations survey, also found no evidence that women were reluctant to ask for fear of upsetting their boss. One of the researchers, Professor Andrew Oswald, concluded that there is "some element of pure discrimination against women." However, the study also found that women and men under 40 were asking for and receiving pay rises at the same rate, which could suggest that negotiating behaviour is changing.

Oxford City Council has been searching for a new burial site for many years as its two remaining cemeteries, in Wolvercote and Botley, are expected to be full by 2018 and 2021. Money has been used for "ground investigations of possible sites," but all council-owned sites have been discounted due to size, ground conditions, high water tables, or restrictive covenants. The council has stated it has run out of suitable land within Oxford but is "still exploring options." Once the current cemeteries are full, only reopening family plots, using reserved plots, and interring ashes will be possible. The last time burial space was increased in Oxford was in 1932.

Visitors to the Hebridean Celtic Festival will be able to use an app to trigger online information, such as videos and band interviews, from items like signs and posters. The festival, taking place in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis from 19 to 22 July, will feature acts including The Waterboys, Imelda May, and Dougie MacLean. According to director Caroline Maclennan, this augmented reality experience is an extra feature for visitors and will also allow people worldwide to interact with the festival. The app will be updated before and during the event, enabling users to access information, interviews, and buy tickets.

Many Clouds, a 10-year-old Irish-bred horse, collapsed and died after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day. The British Horseracing Authority (BHA) confirmed the cause of death was a "severe pulmonary haemorrhage." The horse had previously shown symptoms of post-race ataxia, where he would overheat and "wobble," but had never collapsed before and showed no such symptoms on the day he died. The BHA's acting chief veterinary officer stated that such episodes are rare and can occur in horses with no underlying health issues. A report concluded that the horse's death was due to a haemorrhage rarely seen on the racetrack and was not linked to his previous condition.

In the autumn of 2004, a 15-year-old girl met a man named David Ayrton in a Portsmouth garage. The defendant, now 34 and named Davina Ayrton, was charged with raping the teenager while two others were asleep in the garage. The victim stated she had drunk a can and a half of Foster's, clearly recollected the events, and had shouted at Ayrton to stop.

Ayrton, who has learning difficulties and attempted suicide last summer, denied the charge. During the trial, she spoke about her sexuality, stating she had not made physical changes to her body or taken medication. She changed her name in 2012. In 2014, she told a care home worker about the attack.

Judge Ian Pearson remanded her into custody at a male prison, citing a risk of her harming herself or failing to attend sentencing. She is scheduled to be sentenced on March 4.

The Serbs, including world number one Novak Djokovic, lost 6-4 6-4 to Brazilians Marcelo Melo and Bruno Soares in Rio. This loss followed Djokovic's singles knockout by Argentine Juan Martin del Potro. The 29-year-old had also experienced a third-round defeat at Wimbledon in July to American Sam Querrey. Before the Olympics, the 12-time Grand Slam winner won his 30th Masters title in Toronto.

More than 20 competitors from various countries, including Scotland, England, Ireland, continental Europe, Canada, and the US, are scheduled to participate in a carving event in Carrbridge on Saturday. Participants are only allowed to use chainsaws to carve logs into animal and human shapes. Last year's winner, Pete Bowsher, will be returning to defend his title and the Claymore Trophy.

Rhys Webb, a 27-year-old rugby player, is recovering from a serious foot injury sustained in a World Cup warm-up with Italy in September. He is now "back up and running" and hopes to return to play in early February, potentially ahead of schedule, giving him time to get fit for the Six Nations. Webb has renewed his national dual contract with Ospreys and the Welsh Rugby Union, turning down other offers to stay with his home region.

On Tuesday morning, five miles east of Sumas, Washington, US border agents interrupted an attempt to smuggle MDMA (ecstasy) from Canada to San Francisco. Agents encountered two men with backpacks and ordered them to halt. One man, Jeffrey Laviolette, was taken into custody. The other man fired a weapon at the agents and fled. This man, Canadian citizen Nathan Hall, was later arrested in British Columbia. The backpacks contained a total of 58lb (26kg) of ecstasy and a California driver's license with William Nickerson's name but Nathan Hall's picture. Two others, Kali Henifin and her boyfriend Ryan Lambert, were also arrested. They allegedly planned to pick up the men and transport the drugs to San Francisco for a payment of $11,000. The three defendants in US custody face conspiracy, drug possession, and distribution charges.

In the past year, the NSPCC's Childline service counselled over 4,500 children for online abuse, an increase from about 2,400 in 2011-12. The charity reported that online trolls caused misery for thousands of children, with some as young as seven being tormented. Dame Esther Rantzen, Childline's president, stated that cyber-bullying can follow children home, becoming a persecution they cannot escape. She called for intervention from adults, parents, and teachers, and urged schools to take the problem seriously. The report was released at the start of Anti-Bullying Week, coordinated by the Anti Bullying Alliance, which works with parents and schools to combat the issue.

A vote by the Jerusalem Planning and Housing Committee to authorize 492 new homes in the settlements of Ramat Shlomo and Ramot was postponed. According to committee member Hanan Rubin, the postponement followed a request from Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's office to avoid further straining relations with Washington ahead of a speech by US Secretary of State John Kerry.

This follows the US's decision not to veto a UN Security Council resolution that called for an end to settlement construction. The resolution stated that settlements have "no legal validity" and are a "flagrant violation under international law." In response, Mr. Netanyahu summoned ambassadors, recalled Israeli ambassadors from New Zealand and Senegal, cut aid to Senegal, and cancelled a visit from Ukraine's prime minister. Mr. Netanyahu's spokesman accused the White House of helping to draft the resolution, a claim a US state department spokesman denied.

On the eve of her 90th birthday, the Queen was praised by Prince William in a BBC interview as a "guiding example" of a good monarch. To mark the occasion, a picture of the Queen with the Prince of Wales, Prince William, and Prince George was released for a new set of stamps.

The Queen's birthday events began with a visit to Windsor's Royal Mail delivery office to mark the 500th anniversary of the postal service. She also attended a ceremony to open a new bandstand.

In his interview, Prince William also addressed recent criticism of being "work-shy," stating that he takes his duty very seriously but is focused on finding his own way into the role at the right time. He confirmed he has the support of his father and grandmother in this approach.

Birthday celebrations will include the Queen lighting a beacon, leading to over 900 beacons being lit across the UK and the world. She will also have lunch with US President Barack Obama and First Lady Michelle Obama.

West Ham United beat Cheltenham Town 2-0 in an EFL Cup match. The Premier League side scored two quick goals before half-time, with Diafra Sakho scoring from a Sam Byram pass and Andre Ayew adding the second moments later. Cheltenham, a League Two side, had chances from Harry Pell and Jordon Forster but did not sufficiently test the West Ham goalkeeper, Adrian. West Ham made seven changes for the match, while Cheltenham were unchanged. The result ended League Two's representation in the EFL Cup. The final score was Cheltenham Town 0, West Ham United 2.

Aidan McNicholl, a 36-year-old hospital radiographer, died in a collision on the A5 at Cerrigydrudion. Andreas Werner, 46, of Leipzig, caused the fatal crash when he turned his VW Transporter right and failed to spot the motorcyclist. Werner pleaded guilty to causing death by careless driving and was fined Â£1,000 and banned from driving in the UK for two years. The victim's family stated they saw no value in a jail sentence, accepting it was a "momentary lapse." Werner's defense said he was remorseful and offered no explanation for the crash.

Imran Khawaja, 27, from Southall, west London, is described as one of the most dangerous British jihadists to return from the conflict in Syria. Known online as Abu Daigham al-Britani, he was a public fighter who joined the group Rayat al Tawheed, which is affiliated with Islamic State. This group was known for producing propaganda videos and posters to recruit young British Muslims. Khawaja was featured in videos and a gruesome picture where he held a bag containing a head.

In June of last year, Khawaja decided to return to the UK. He faked his own death online and had his cousin, Tahir Bhatti, drive to Bulgaria to pick him up. Upon their arrival at Dover, police were waiting and arrested them. Khawaja has since admitted to four offences and was held in a special unit for high-risk terrorism suspects. His cousin pleaded guilty to assisting an offender.

Kayden Jackson, 22, has signed for Barnsley, becoming their third signing for the next season. Last season, he scored four goals in 36 appearances for Wrexham, who finished eighth. Jackson, who turned down a new contract from Wrexham, is described by caretaker boss Paul Heckingbottom as having "pace to burn" and being a good fit for the team's style of play.

Bottles, believed to be 'Vanish', have been washing up on Poldhu Cove on the Lizard since Sunday, with other nearby coves also affected.
*   **Who is involved?** National Trust volunteers are clearing the bottles. The Maritime and Coastguard Agency, Cornwall Wildlife Trust, and Cornwall Council are also involved.
*   **What is the suspected source?** It is believed a container went overboard from a ship, possibly the MV Blue Ocean which lost a container near Land's End in May. However, the Maritime and Coastguard Agency states the evidence linking the bottles to this specific ship is currently circumstantial.
*   **What is the risk?** The bottles pose a risk to wildlife, and conservationists are "highly concerned" about the impact of the detergent on the marine environment. Some bottles have leaked, but most are sealed.
*   **What is the advice?** The public is advised to keep children and dogs away from the bottles and not to attempt to recover them.

An incident occurred on the A9 north of Berriedale in Caithness at about 14:00, resulting in minor injuries to several people. The road was closed with diversions put in place, and police inquiries are ongoing.

Dorian Dervite, a 28-year-old French centre-back, made 14 appearances last season, helping Wanderers secure promotion by finishing second in League One. Having joined Bolton from Charlton in 2014, he has made 83 appearances in total. Manager Phil Parkinson praised his "excellent contribution." Dervite has signed a new contract, following teammates David Wheater, Gary Madine, and Jem Karacan.

The Liberal Democrats and the Labour Party, who had previously collaborated to defeat the government on Brexit issues like EU citizens' rights and parliamentary approval, have had a falling out. The disagreement arose after MPs rejected their joint amendments. The Lib Dems wanted to insist on the amendments, while Labour was prepared to defer to the Commons.

Lib Dem Lord Oates accused Labour of conceding everything, while Labour's Baroness Smith accused the Lib Dems of giving people "false hope". A Labour source called the Lib Dem stance "fairly obvious grandstanding" for campaign leaflets. In response, the Lib Dems' Baroness Ludford accused Labour of "waving through the government's plans" and "lining up with the Conservatives".

Despite a history of forming alliances on other issues like higher education and housing, a Labour source predicted "residual tensions" between the two parties. However, Baroness Ludford stated that the Liberal Democrats would continue to work with peers from across the House on issues they agree on.

Despite a consensus that the world is becoming more dangerous, defence is a low priority for most political parties and the electorate in the current election. The UK has been making significant cuts to its armed forces, with the regular army being reduced from 102,000 to 82,000, the Royal Navy having only 19 warships, and the RAF reduced to seven front-line fast jet squadrons.

The UK's defence spending has fallen from fourth to sixth in the world and is projected to drop below the 2% of GDP commitment set by NATO. While the Conservatives and Labour manifestos are short on detail, the Conservatives have committed to replacing Trident, increasing the equipment budget, and making no further cuts to the army's size. Labour and the Liberal Democrats are considering reducing the number of submarines for the nuclear deterrent, while the SNP and Greens would scrap it entirely.

There are concerns that the military is becoming a "hollow force," with new equipment like two large aircraft carriers but insufficient personnel and jets to operate them effectively.

Barcelona paid Â£48.6m for Santos striker Neymar, with his parents receiving Â£34m of that fee. The total cost of the player to the club, including fees, wages, and a recent tax payment, is estimated at Â£106.8m. Following accusations of misappropriating money related to the transfer, Sandro Rosell resigned as Barcelona president, though he denies wrongdoing. A judge in Spain ruled there was sufficient evidence to continue investigations into the transfer. In response to potential interpretations of the contracts, Barcelona made a "complimentary tax declaration" of â¬13,550,830.56, while maintaining they had not committed any offence and that their original tax payment was correct. It is not yet confirmed if the case will be dropped following this payment.

Michael Luciw, 27, was a passenger in a van and died when it was hit by a car driven the wrong way on the motorway by Albert Kenneth Newman, who also died. The crash occurred at 02:00 GMT on 12 October near Kegworth, Leicestershire.

Mr. Luciw's family and the driver of the van, Andy Harrington, believe retired or older people should undergo regular driving or medical tests. Mr. Luciw's brother suggested a test with an instructor, noting that free bus passes are available for those in their 60s.

Currently, UK drivers over 70 must self-declare their fitness to drive every three years without a mandatory medical or driving test. The DVLA stated it has no plans to restrict licensing based on age, as evidence does not show older drivers are more likely to cause serious accidents. Age UK commented that it is "vital" for older people to be able to drive for as long as possible to maintain their independence.

An independent expert, Professor Alison Britton, will examine the final report on transvaginal mesh implants after two patients on the original review group quit in protest. The report concluded that the procedures should not be offered routinely for pelvic organ prolapse and recommended that patients be offered a range of treatments to make "informed choices." It also stated that reporting adverse events should be mandatory. The health secretary, Ms Robison, confirmed these recommendations would be implemented but said the government could not ban the procedures, as that power lies with the UK's regulatory body. The review's chairwoman, Tracey Gillies, apologised for failing to unite the panel around the final report. Two patients, Olive McIlroy and Elaine Holmes, quit the review group, and a consultant also resigned over concerns about the report's final draft. Over 400 women are currently taking legal action in Scotland regarding mesh implant surgery.

Laura Muir, aged 23, broke Liz McColgan's 25-year-old 5K record with a time of 14 minutes, 49.12 seconds at the Emirates Arena in Glasgow. McColgan initially raised concerns about whether the race met the criteria for a record, as Muir was the only competitor to finish the 5K in a mixed 3K race and she questioned if drug testing was in place. However, British Athletics confirmed the time is expected to be ratified as official, and rules state that doping control is not required at the event for a record to be set. McColgan expressed excitement that Muir, a fellow Scot, broke her record and believes Muir has the ability to run even faster and win world medals. Muir also broke the British 1500m record in August and reached the 1,500m Olympic final at Rio 2016.

Jung won the event riding Sam, a late replacement for Fischertakinou. Astier Nicolas from France won the silver medal, and Phillip Dutton from the USA won bronze. Great Britain's William Fox-Pitt finished 12th after a disappointing cross-country phase, despite a faultless performance in the final show-jumping phase. Fox-Pitt was competing 10 months after being in an induced coma. Jonty Evans of Ireland finished ninth.

Andy Murray, aged 30, defeated 29th seed Fabio Fognini with a score of 6-2 4-6 6-1 7-5 in a match lasting two hours and 39 minutes. Fognini had five set points to force a fifth set, but Murray won five consecutive games to secure the victory. This win places Murray in the last 16 for the 11th time, where he will face Benoit Paire. Fellow Briton Johanna Konta also advanced to the second week after beating Maria Sakkari 6-4 6-1. Murray described the match as "up and down" and was pleased to finish in four sets as it was getting dark.
