Paramedics were called to a sudden death at Joe's Bar in Dungiven on 6 October 2014. Police found people still at the bar, and till receipts showed alcohol was served as late as 04:49 BST. Colleen O'Neill, the license holder, was charged with two counts of allowing liquor consumption outside licensing hours and fined Â£3,000. James Thomas was charged with one count of the same offence and fined Â£1,000. The judge noted Ms O'Neill's "appalling record" and ordered the bar to be closed for three months.

At the launch of the Ulster Unionist party's manifesto, leader Mike Nesbitt stated, "Domination doesn't work, partnership does." While the party intended the election to be a referendum on the Renewable Heat Incentive debacle, the focus shifted to Mr. Nesbitt's comments. He denied regretting his remarks and said he would "rather go in with the SDLP" than Sinn FÃ©in after the election. He also noted that he was confident in his position despite other candidates taking different stances on vote transfers. The manifesto, titled 'Real Partnership', calls for action on waiting lists, increasing PSNI numbers, prioritising the York Street interchange, supporting the LGBT community, and ensuring no group is worse off due to Brexit. It also includes a section on 'Cleaning Up Stormont'. Mr. Nesbitt described the election as being about "incompetence, arrogance, cronyism and the strong whiff of corruption".

Justice Minister Claire Sugden has confirmed a motion will go before the assembly to pardon gay and bisexual men for now-abolished sexual offences. This move aims to bring Northern Ireland in line with England and Wales, where similar plans, dubbed 'Turing's Law', were announced. The motion is expected to allow for both posthumous pardons and for living men to apply for a pardon. The minister has secured executive agreement for the motion and stated it will be brought in "as soon as possible" to ensure equal treatment and to "right the wrongs of the past."

Laura Muir, a 23-year-old from Kinross, finished second in a race behind Kenyan Faith Kipyegon with a time of four minutes, 19.12 seconds. This performance broke Yvonne Murray's 1994 Scottish record and placed Muir second on the British all-time list. Muir, who now holds the Scottish 1500m and mile records, expressed her pleasure with the new record and her performance in her first race of the season at this distance. She recently won an 800m race in France and will compete next in a 1500m race in Stockholm. Muir, who is also a veterinary student, hopes to secure a place for Great Britain in the Rio Olympics at the upcoming British trials.
Based on the text provided, the passage is a caption for pictures from 26 beaches in Scotland that have been ranked as having the "most excellent" water quality.

Met Police barrister Richard Horwell QC stated that the Russian state was the likely sponsor of the plot to kill Mr. Litvinenko, who died in a London hospital in 2006 after drinking tea containing polonium-210. The two suspects, Dmitry Kovtun and Andrei Lugovoi, who deny wrongdoing, allegedly met with Mr. Litvinenko and left a "trail of polonium" behind them. Mr. Horwell said the use of polonium indicates Russian state involvement and that Mr. Litvinenko had been poisoned twice. He also noted that the risk to the London public from the polonium exposure will never be known. Attempts to extradite the suspects from Russia have failed.

Steve Smith, 26, has been appointed as the new captain of the Australian Test team, succeeding the retiring Michael Clarke. Smith already leads the one-day side and will also captain the Twenty20 team. David Warner, 28, has been named vice-captain. National selector Rod Marsh stated that Smith is highly regarded and that the decision was straightforward following Clarke's retirement announcement. Warner's appointment comes despite a history of disciplinary issues, with Marsh noting that he has matured and will respond well to the responsibility. Smith and Warner will lead the team in the limited-overs matches following the final Ashes Test.

Mr. Farron, who beat Norman Lamb for the leadership, refused to directly answer whether he believed homosexual sex was a sin, instead stating, "my firm belief is we are all sinners." He told the BBC's Andrew Marr Show that he is "passionate about LGBT-plus rights" and that defending and extending equal marriage, including for transgender people, would be "at the top of my agenda." When asked why he voted against the 2007 Equality Bill, he said he is a liberal who supports equality but the Lib Dems had concerns about "protection of individual liberties." He did not specify what those concerns were.

Accord Healthcare is taking over a drug manufacturing site in Fawdon that was closed by Sanofi in 2015, a closure which resulted in the loss of 450 jobs. Accord hopes to fill many of the new positions with ex-Sanofi staff. The investment is expected to have a positive impact on the local economy and strengthen Newcastle's reputation in the science and healthcare sector. Accord Healthcare develops, manufactures, and distributes over 130 pharmaceutical products to about 60 countries.

Richard Ellis, the council's former interim director of corporate governance and acting deputy chief executive, is leaving at the end of his contract on Friday. Ciaran Monaghan, head of the chief executive's office, and Ewan Sutherland, head of human resources and customer services, are both leaving under a voluntary redundancy and early retirement scheme. Stephen Flynn, the opposition SNP group leader, stated these departures indicate the council's inability to retain senior staff and expects more to follow. Council chief executive Angela Scott thanked the three for their service.

Militants armed with guns and grenades attacked the Sardar Daud hospital. One attacker detonated explosives at a gate, allowing the others to enter and open fire on staff and patients.

*   **Who was responsible?** The Islamic State (IS) group claimed the attack. The Taliban denied involvement.

*   **What was the outcome?** Commandos landed on the hospital roof and killed all four attackers after several hours of fighting. More than 50 people were wounded.

*   **What was the reaction?** President Ashraf Ghani condemned the attack, stating it "trampled all human values."

*   **What is the significance?** The attack marks a change in approach for IS in Afghanistan, as it was the first time they had directly engaged with security forces in the capital. This suggests they may have the resources and training to expand their attacks.

The English rider, Martin, has stated he has no plans to do any more road racing on the Hondas this year. This follows a crash at this year's TT and mechanical problems with the Fireblade bike. Martin did not race at the North West 200 and will not compete in the Ulster Grand Prix. He described the TT as a "bloody disaster" and felt he was acting as a "test rider". He informed the team that the bike would not be competitive at the Ulster Grand Prix, and they subsequently withdrew him from the event. Martin says he has "no unfinished business" and wants to race "classics and oddball stuff."

In Nigeria's gubernatorial elections, the All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 of the 28 declared governor posts, marking the biggest defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since 1999. The PDP, which also lost the presidential poll the previous month, won eight governorships, mostly in the south-east. The APC's victories included key northern states like Katsina and Kaduna, as well as Nigeria's commercial hub, Lagos. However, the PDP held on to Rivers State, and the APC failed to win in any of the five oil-producing states. One result in Taraba is still outstanding, and the election in Imo state was declared inconclusive. The elections were marred by 66 reported violent incidents, but were considered more peaceful than in previous years.

A report by the US environmental group Mighty has made claims against the agricultural commodities trader Olam. The report accuses Olam and its main stakeholder, Singapore's state-owned investment company Temasek, of turning a blind eye to unsustainable palm oil trading practices that may contribute to haze caused by fires in Indonesia.

Key points from the passage include:
*   **Allegations:** Mighty's report claims Olam created a "secretive market for rogue palm oil companies" and could be encouraging unsustainable practices. It also alleges that Olam is clearing rainforests in Gabon for palm oil plantations.
*   **Olam's Response:** Olam rejects the allegations, stating it has a "very vigorous sourcing policy" with "zero tolerance for burning." The company says it buys 99% of its palm oil from third-party suppliers and accounts for less than 1% of the global market. Olam has released the names of its 14 suppliers and stated that any who do not comply with its sustainable principles will be removed from its supply chain. Regarding Gabon, Olam stated its partnerships are responsible and transparent.
*   **Temasek's Response:** Temasek also dismissed the allegations, stating it supports no-burn policies. It clarified that as a matter of governance, it does not direct the business operations of its portfolio companies like Olam.
*   **Broader Context:** The passage notes that the palm oil industry has a troubled track record, often accused of deforestation and illegal practices. It also mentions the regular haze in Singapore and Malaysia caused by slash-and-burn practices in Indonesia.
A restaurant started serving "puppy platters" after a new law was introduced that allows dogs to eat at restaurants, provided they are outdoors.
Fernando Forestieri is a doubt due to a knee injury. Derby County's David Nugent may return from a groin injury. Jacob Butterfield is hoping for a recall after scoring in the previous game.

Pakistan's telecoms regulator has lifted its ban on YouTube, which was imposed by the Supreme Court in 2012 after the film "Innocence of Muslims" was uploaded. The ban was lifted because Google has launched a Pakistan-specific version of the site. According to Pakistan's ministry of information technology, the Pakistan Telecommunication Authority (PTA) can now make requests directly to Google to block offending material for users within Pakistan. However, a YouTube spokeswoman stated that government requests for content removal would not be automatically granted and would be subject to a thorough review against their community guidelines and local laws. These requests will be recorded in YouTube's Transparency Report. While many young Pakistanis have welcomed the lifting of the ban, some activists are calling for more transparency regarding the terms of the deal between Google and the government.

Domenico Scala, the Swiss-Italian head of Fifa's Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee, is facing a call to withdraw from his position by LFA boss Musa Bility. The demand is based on a potential conflict of interest, as Scala shares Swiss-Italian nationality with presidential candidate Gianni Infantino. Bility cites Article 7.4 of the Electoral Regulations and points out that Scala previously excused himself from the 2015 elections for sharing nationality with candidate Sepp Blatter. Bility has threatened to go to the Court of Arbitration for Sport if Scala does not withdraw.

A spokesman for Scala, Andreas Bantel, stated that sharing a nationality with a candidate does not constitute a conflict of interest under Fifa regulations. He clarified that Scala's previous withdrawal was a voluntary, precautionary measure because the candidate was the incumbent president, which is not the case in the current election with five candidates. The election to replace Sepp Blatter is scheduled for 26 February.

Daniel Timbers, 29, and Barry Joy, 56, were killed while working at Harford Attachments in Spar Road on Monday morning. The incident is believed to have been a flashover explosion in a paint-spraying area, caused by a build-up of toxic fumes and an ignition source. A forensic search has been carried out, and the Health and Safety Executive is gathering evidence.

Tunisia faced expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations after lodging complaints against the Confederation of African Football (Caf) following a controversial quarter-final loss to Equatorial Guinea in the 2015 tournament. The Tunisian Football Federation (FTF) states it never accused Caf of corruption but contested the referee's appointment and performance. After a meeting between FTF and Caf president Issa Hayatou, Tunisia apologised and had its participation in the 2017 tournament confirmed.

Morocco was also initially banned from the 2017 Nations Cup after refusing to host the 2015 tournament due to Ebola fears. However, the Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas) overturned this ban and reduced a $1m fine to $50,000.

Following the draw, Tunisia is in Group A with Togo, Liberia, and Djibouti, while Morocco is in Group F with Cape Verde, Libya, and Sao Tome.

Following a mass fracas in the 95th minute of a game that Chelsea won 3-1, both Manchester City and Chelsea have been charged with failing to control their players. City's Sergio Aguero received a four-match ban for a challenge on David Luiz, and Fernandinho was given a three-match ban for clashing with Cesc Fabregas. Fabregas will not face any further action. Both clubs have until 18:00 GMT on 8 December to respond to the charge.

Mae gan Gymru a rhannau eraill o'r DU rai o'r cyfraddau goresgyn canser gwaethaf yn y byd datblygedig. Mae cynllun peilot yng Nghwm Cynon a Chastell-nedd yn canolbwyntio ar gleifion y mae eu meddygon teulu yn amau sydd Ã¢ chanser ond sydd heb symptomau brys. Mae hyn yn dilyn ymweliad meddygon Ã¢ Denmarc i weld eu systemau diagnostig, a wnaeth wella cyfraddau goresgyn canser yno.

Y pryder yw bod cleifion yng Nghymru heb symptomau clir yn aros yn rhy hir am ddiagnosis oherwydd nad ydynt yn ffitio llwybr triniaeth penodol, gan arwain at oedi a diagnosis pan fo'r canser wedi datblygu.

Bydd clinig tebyg yn cael ei sefydlu yn Ysbyty Castell-nedd Port Talbot. Os bydd y cynllun peilot chwe mis yn llwyddiannus, bydd byrddau iechyd eraill yn cynnig y gwasanaeth.

England won the cricket match against Pakistan at Old Trafford, leveling the series. England declared at 589-8 and 173-1, securing their second-biggest run victory over Pakistan. Joe Root was named man of the match for scoring 254 and an unbeaten 71, as well as taking four catches and one wicket. Captain Alastair Cook also scored 105 and 76 not out. Pakistan was bowled out for 198 and 234. Pakistan's captain, Misbah-ul-Haq, expressed disappointment, citing a lack of confidence and poor shot selection. The third Test will begin on August 3rd at Edgbaston.

Warren Gatland, the head coach for the British and Irish Lions in New Zealand, has appointed interim coach Rob Howley to his backroom team. Consequently, forwards coach Robin McBryde will take on head coach duties for Wales for the third time, leading the summer tour. The Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) is in the process of appointing assistant coaches to support McBryde and expects to confirm the full management team next week. Union chairman Gareth Davies believes the involvement of Welsh coaches with the Lions will benefit the national team in the long term.

In a football match, Hull City defeated Southampton 2-1. Southampton initially led with a 6th-minute penalty from Charlie Austin. Hull, who lost strikers Abel Hernandez and Will Keane to first-half injuries, turned the game around in the second half. Substitute Robert Snodgrass scored and then provided an assist for Michael Dawson's header within a two-minute span. Despite late pressure from Southampton, Hull's goalkeeper David Marshall made several key saves, and Sam Clucas made a goalline clearance in the final minute. The victory ended Hull's six-game losing streak.

A motorcyclist was killed in a collision with a tractor at about 14:15 BST on the B1191 at Thornton, near Woodhall Spa. The motorcyclist was a local resident, and the tractor driver was not injured. Lincolnshire Police are appealing for witnesses. The B1191 was closed in both directions between the B1192 Tattershall Road junction and the A158 Jubilee Way junction.

Macedonia's President Ivanov cancelled an investigation into claims of abuse of power, which were revealed by covert recordings, stating he wanted to "put an end to the agony" before early elections. This decision was condemned by the opposition and EU officials. Opposition leader Zoran Zaev called the move illegal and urged protests, while EU Commissioner Johannes Hahn said the action was not in line with the rule of law and put Macedonia's EU membership ambitions at risk. The crisis began in 2015 with the release of covert recordings that allegedly show ministers planning vote-rigging and a murder cover-up. Mr. Zaev, who has been releasing the recordings, accuses the government of wiretapping 20,000 people and widespread corruption. The government denies these accusations and accuses Mr. Zaev of attempting to destabilize the country.

Following the sacking of manager Bob Bradley, Curtis and assistant manager Paul Williams will take charge of Swansea's match against Bournemouth. The club wants to appoint a new boss as soon as possible, with ex-Derby manager Paul Clement being the first choice. Curtis stated that the club needs someone to get them out of trouble, expressing concern that if they are relegated to the Championship, it would be tough to get back up. He believes Swansea has lost its way since Michael Laudrup left in 2014, with frequent management changes and a failure to adequately replace key players diluting the "Swansea Way" of playing. Despite this, Curtis thinks the current squad is good enough to stay in the Premier League and reminds new players of the club's history and the importance of avoiding relegation for both the club and the local area.

Dagenham & Redbridge, also known as the Daggers, were relegated from League Two to the National League after a defeat. Goals from Jamie Cureton and Clevid Dikamona were not enough to secure a victory. The winning goal was scored by Armand Gnanduillet, which kept Orient's play-off hopes alive. Dagenham's manager, John Still, who previously took the club from the Conference to League One, has committed to helping the team gain promotion from the National League next season. The Daggers have League Two's worst goal difference. The victory for Orient came four days after their player-manager Kevin Nolan was removed from his managerial role.

Steven Gerrard, the 36-year-old former Reds captain, is set to return to his former club as a youth coach in February, which will be his first job since retiring as a player. Klopp described the appointment as "wonderful news" after a "good long chat" with Gerrard, adding that Gerrard wants to be a manager in the future and is ready to learn. Gerrard, who retired in November after a 19-year career, previously turned down the manager's job at MK Dons, saying it was "too soon." He is currently working towards his Uefa A coaching licence.

McManus scored the first goal for Morton, and Ross Forbes added a second. Kyle McAusland scored for Alloa before half-time. In the second half, McManus scored his second goal, and Denny Johnstone also scored, securing a win for Morton.

Ofsted has found evidence of children being taught in squalid conditions in three places in Birmingham, which have now been closed. A total of 18 unregulated schools, mainly in Muslim communities in the Midlands, have been visited as part of an investigation. The owners of the three closed Birmingham locations are being investigated on suspicion of running an illegal school, which could lead to a jail term of up to 51 weeks. Sir Michael Wilshaw, Chief Inspector of Schools, expressed concern that children were at risk of abuse or radicalisation and believes these cases are the "tip of the iceberg." Ministers are consulting on plans for more regulation of places teaching for more than 6 to 8 hours a week. The government has funded a team of six inspectors to investigate illegal schools, and the Education Secretary has asked Ofsted to prepare cases for prosecution.

Lilliard Gin is based at the Born in the Borders visitor centre in Jedburgh and is produced in one of the UK's smallest production stills, located in a cowshed. Lead distiller Kate Macinnes states that the gin aims to capture the local flavour of the Teviot valley by using wild food from the area. The distillery is considered a natural companion to the Scottish Borders Brewery on the same site. The gin's name comes from Lilliard, the heroine of the 1545 Battle of Ancrum Moor, chosen to reflect the landscape and the strong female production team.

In August 2013, Harry Whitlam was killed at Swithens Farm in Rothwell when Gary Green reversed a vehicle into him. Green was more than two times the legal driving limit, having consumed the equivalent of 13 pints of beer before 02:00 BST. The incident occurred around 09:15 on 9 August in a closed-off area of the farm. Green was prosecuted under health and safety legislation because the event took place on private land. He admitted to failing to ensure the safety of others and was jailed for 16 months and two weeks. Harry's mother, Pam Whitlam, stated her family has been "changed forever" and that it is not acceptable for anyone to be drunk behind the wheel, whether on public or private land.

Uruguayan striker Luis Suarez, 27, can now train and play in friendly matches for his new club, Barcelona, following a ruling by the Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas). The Cas ruling upheld the sanctions imposed by Fifa for biting Italy's Giorgio Chiellini but deemed the ban from all "football-related activity" to be "excessive." Suarez will join Barcelona's training on Friday and be publicly presented on Monday. He is still banned for eight more competitive international games and his competitive debut for Barcelona is expected to be on October 26 against Real Madrid. He can, however, play in Uruguay's upcoming friendlies. The world players' union, Fifpro, expressed disappointment that the sanctions were not further reduced.

Richard Blake-Smith and his partner Anna won a race, beating Vytautas Kirkliauskas of Lithuania and his wife, Neringa Kirliauskiene. The 380-metre course involved hurdling haystacks, climbing a steep slope, and dodging water pistols. Competitors included men carrying women, men carrying men, and one woman carrying a woman; participants do not need to be married. Richard and Anna will now compete at the World Championships in Finland in July.

In October, the paper system for car tax discs will be scrapped and replaced with an electronic system, which will allow people to pay by monthly direct debit. Stephen Hammond, the minister, stated that this change would likely lead to a natural reduction in refunds and the withdrawal of the tax disc, resulting in changes to job roles at the Driving and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA). He assured that any reduction in the number of people needed for these activities would be managed through redeployment to other growth areas of the business, not redundancies. Swansea East AM Mike Hedges welcomed these assurances, believing they would "give comfort" to the concerned DVLA employees.

Hungary's government, represented by Mr. Szijjarto, has stated it will not backtrack on three controversial issues: tight controls on asylum seekers, a higher education law, and a draft law on non-governmental organisations (NGOs). He considers these "domestic issues" and believes the EU should not interfere. Hungary has secured backing from Poland, which has promised to veto any EU move to strip Hungary of its voting rights.

The EU objects to these laws. The higher education law could force the closure of the Central European University (CEU). The asylum seeker policy involves housing them in secured shipping containers. The draft NGO law is seen by human rights groups as a way to stigmatise them as "foreign-backed." Thousands of Hungarians have protested these laws, and the EU has warned of potential action if there are no positive developments.

The film, a live-action version of "Beauty and the Beast," has cast an unnamed star as Mrs. Potts, Kevin Kline as Maurice, Emma Watson as Belle, Dan Stevens as the Beast, Luke Evans as Gaston, and Josh Gad as LeFou. Directed by Bill Condon, the movie begins filming at Shepperton Studios in May and is set for release in US cinemas on March 17, 2017.

Sunday Times columnist Adrian Gill has died from cancer. His editor, Martin Ivens, described him as "a giant among journalists" and the "heart and soul" of the paper. Gill, who had dyslexia, was known for dictating his copy and his writing often caused controversy. His final column, about his diagnosis, will be in the next Sunday Times. He is survived by his partner Nicola Formby and his four children.

Mongolian rapper Amarmandakh Sukhbaatar, also known as Amraa, was allegedly attacked by a Russian diplomat in Ulan Bator. The attack, which reportedly involved being hit with a bottle and kicked in the face, left him in a coma for about 10 days with a serious brain injury. The incident occurred after Sukhbaatar performed wearing a red deel (a Mongolian robe) embroidered with a swastika. His father and lawyer emphasized that the swastika is a traditional symbol of eternity in Mongolia, pre-dating the Nazis, and not a hate symbol. The Russian embassy stated it was investigating "distorted" press reports. A police spokesman confirmed the suspect is a Russian diplomatic officer and the case is under investigation, adding that the suspect was not detained because the injury was not considered serious.

Campaigners from the action group Plane Stupid staged a demonstration on the northern runway at 03:30 BST on Monday, in opposition to the airport's expansion plans. The men and women involved have been charged with aggravated trespass and entering a security restricted area of an aerodrome. They are scheduled to appear in court on August 19th. The Metropolitan Police stated that airport security would be reviewed.

In a cricket match between Glamorgan and Gloucestershire, Nick Selman scored his second first-class century with 101 runs, dominating Glamorgan's total. Despite Selman's performance, Gloucestershire seamers Matt Taylor and Craig Miles ensured wickets fell regularly. Aneurin Donald's 36 was the next highest score for Glamorgan. In response, Gloucestershire's batsmen struggled to survive in the evening gloom. The day ended evenly balanced. Glamorgan was led by Michael Hogan for the first time, as Jacques Rudolph was absent with a neck problem.

Craig Hughes, 33, of Flint, was arrested after telling the Hope Line Crisis Centre in Tennessee that he planned to ambush and shoot police officers on the Dee Estuary. He admitted to two charges at Mold Crown Court and will be sentenced next week. The threats were made on two occasions while Hughes was drunk. The court was told he had a previous conviction for possessing a firearm in 2009. His legal team stated he would not have carried out the threats.

After being reduced to 8-2, a partnership of 130 between Davies and Ben Foakes (90) helped their team post a score of 255-7. Yorkshire's run-chase was undermined by Stuart Meaker, who took three wickets in nine balls, including Jonny Bairstow and Gary Ballance. Despite Tim Bresnan's 68, Yorkshire were all out for 236. Yorkshire had an ideal start, with Dominic Sibley and Kumar Sangakkara out in the first three overs. However, Matthew Waite dropped Davies on 43. Davies went on to score more runs before being dismissed by Waite, who finished with figures of 3-48. Meaker's bowling spell (3-61) was pivotal, removing Bairstow (13), Ballance (32), and Jack Leaning. Bresnan and Waite (38) attempted a recovery, but Bresnan was the last to fall with seven balls remaining.

At 07:00 BST, the crew of a 56ft (17.1m) converted trawler, located 6 miles (10 km) west of South Stack, radioed coastguards because a pump on board could not handle the amount of water coming in. An RNLI lifeboat crew responded by placing a pump on the vessel and towing it to Holyhead.

Laura Muir will not compete in the Commonwealth Games on Australia's Gold Coast due to a scheduling conflict with her veterinary medicine exams in May. The 24-year-old middle-distance runner, who is returning to her final year of university studies, expressed disappointment but prioritized getting her degree. Muir finished fourth in the 1500m and sixth in the 5,000m at the World Athletics Championships, setting a new outdoor personal best in the 5,000m with a time of 14 minutes 52.07 seconds. She considers the World Indoor Championships in March a "potential target."

According to Robbie Savage's BBC Sport column, Liverpool are a long way from repeating their previous season's title challenge. He attributes this to several factors: the sale of Luis Suarez and the injury to Daniel Sturridge have significantly reduced their goal-scoring ability, and the new strikers (Balotelli, Lambert, Borini) are not good enough replacements in terms of goals or work-rate. This has led to a drop in intensity and a failure to score early goals as they did the previous season.

Defensively, despite spending significant money, Liverpool have not improved and still lack a leader at the back. Savage also discusses Steven Gerrard, stating that while he faces a physical and mental battle at age 34, he is not finished and remains one of Liverpool's most important players. Savage suggests a specific lineup for the upcoming Chelsea match, dropping the expensive signing Dejan Lovren, but predicts a Chelsea win as they are on "a different planet".

A new Â£45m facility is being built at Sutherland Drive in Kilmarnock, which will house primary and secondary schools, a Gaelic school, and a childcare centre. East Ayrshire Council plans to ask the McIlvanney family for permission to name the campus after the writer William McIlvanney, who was born and educated in Kilmarnock. McIlvanney, who died on December 5th at his Glasgow home, was an English teacher before becoming a full-time writer in 1975. He was known as the "Godfather of Tartan Noir" and wrote works such as the Laidlaw trilogy, Docherty, and The Big Man. He was also a poet, journalist, and broadcaster.

An area of a town near the swimming pool was evacuated after a sea mine, thought to be a British mine from the 1940s or 1950s, was spotted on Monday. The evacuation affected three streets, with residents within 500m advised to stay indoors. An exclusion zone was also in force on the river and at sea, causing some disruption to ferry services. The local area commander stated the evacuation was a precautionary measure with no immediate danger. A Royal Navy officer said the mine's deterioration made it impossible to know how much explosive material it contained, so it was moved to a safer place.

A total of Â£345m will be invested in 31 Olympic and Paralympic sports for the Tokyo Games, which is Â£2m less than the amount allocated for the Rio Games. As a result, UK Sport has set a target of 51-85 Olympic medals and 115-162 Paralympic medals.

Several sports, including archery, fencing, weightlifting, and wheelchair rugby, have missed out on funding. Badminton is the only sport to have its funding removed entirely despite winning a bronze medal in Rio. Cycling's funding has been cut by over Â£4m to Â£25.98m. In contrast, judo, which also won a bronze medal, had its funding slightly increased.

UK Sport's CEO, Liz Nicholl, stated that the decisions were made to prioritise and protect medal potential. However, the chief executive of Badminton England called the decision "incomprehensible" and "catastrophic." British Basketball, volleyball, and handball also issued a joint statement suggesting UK Sport has no interest in funding team sports.

Investment in five new Olympic sports (baseball/softball, karate, skateboard, sports climbing, surfing) and two new Paralympic sports (Para-taekwondo, Para-badminton) is yet to be confirmed, with Â£9m of the total funding still to be allocated pending further exploration of medal potential.

Three Victorian hotels in East Cliff, BournemouthâBay View Court, The Cottonwood, and the Ocean Viewâare set to be demolished. They will be replaced by a six-storey, 90-room, four-star hotel and two assisted-living apartment blocks of nine and seven storeys, containing 122 apartments. Councillors voted seven to three in favour of the development, stating it would help tourism and improve living for older people. English Heritage and the Ancient Monuments Society objected, citing the "severe harm" the development's scale would cause to the designated conservation area and the loss of the historic character of the area. The council received 246 letters of support and 49 objections from residents.

Pte Matthew Boyd, a 20-year-old soldier with the Royal Gibraltar Regiment, was punched and beaten by Jake Vallely while off-duty on a night out in Brecon. Vallely, 24, was found guilty of the attack and will be sentenced on 8 December. Pte Boyd's unconscious body was found by police in the early hours of 8 May. CCTV footage showed Vallely punching the soldier, beating him on the ground, and then dragging his body away. Vallely's friend, Aaeron Evans, was cleared of manslaughter as he was not present during the attack. The trial revealed that Vallely had been on a seven-hour drinking binge and had boasted about being the "hardest man in Brecon" before the attack.

Andrew Travers, the chief executive of Barnet Council, left his position by "mutual agreement" following an error where voters were turned away from all 155 polling stations because their names were missing from the poll list. Mr. Travers blamed electoral registration lists for the problems. An independent investigation has been launched by the council, with its findings to be presented publicly by the end of May. Deputy chief executive John Hooton will take over temporarily. The council apologized for the issues and offered emergency proxy votes to affected residents.

In a football match, Gateshead beat Wrexham 2-1. Josh Gillies scored the first goal for Gateshead with a free-kick. Wrexham equalized before half-time with a set-piece from Sean Newton. The winning goal was a header by Gateshead's Ryan Bowman, from a cross by Craig Baxter.

Gateshead manager Malcolm Crosby stated that beating Wrexham showed they have a "decent side" and that his team's improved passing in the second half made the "big difference." Wrexham manager Gary Mills expressed disappointment, noting his team's second-half performance was not as good as the first and that they failed to convert their chances.

The Global AgeWatch Index 2014 measures the social and economic welfare of people over 60 in 96 countries. According to the index, Norway is the top-ranked country, while Afghanistan is the worst, followed by Mozambique.

The OneWeb project aims to create a satellite network to deliver global broadband, with a specific goal of connecting every school. The network will start with at least 600 spacecraft, potentially expanding to over 2,000. To achieve this, Airbus and OneWeb have developed a new, high-volume, low-cost assembly line method, similar to car manufacturing, to produce satellites for under a million dollars each. The first assembly line is in Toulouse, France, with two more planned for Florida. The project requires a massive launch campaign, using over 20 Soyuz rockets to place the satellites into a 1,200km orbit. While other companies like SpaceX and Boeing are also planning similar "mega-constellations," OneWeb believes it has a first-mover advantage, having already raised $1.7 billion in equity. The company is registered in the UK's Channel Islands and is working with the UK Space Agency on licensing. To address concerns about space debris, OneWeb has committed to de-orbiting old satellites within two years and including an adapter on each spacecraft for potential removal by a "chase vehicle."

Mr. Swinney stated that the UK government's spending review has put "unprecedented pressure" on public expenditure in Scotland. He claims that the Scottish government's discretionary budget will be 12.5% lower in real terms by 2019-20 than it was in 2010-11 due to cuts imposed by the UK government. Despite this, Mr. Swinney said the Scottish government will protect key priorities like schools, hospitals, and the police service.

In response, the UK government said Scottish ministers would have Â£390m more in spending available next year. A spokesman for the UK government's Scotland Office stated that the block grant will be almost Â£30bn.

Labour's public services spokeswoman, Jackie Baillie, called on John Swinney to back up his "anti-austerity posturing with something real" and for the Scottish government to spend less time "congratulating itself on its spin".

For many people with severe disabilities and their carers, standard accessible toilets are inadequate, leading to feelings of isolation and stress. These individuals may require a hoist, a changing bench, and the assistance of two carers, which standard facilities do not accommodate.

Changing Places toilets are larger (12 square metres) and have extra features to meet these needs. There are currently 893 in the UK, but campaigners, including mother Lorna Fillingham, are calling for them to be made compulsory in new, large public buildings like shopping centres and stadiums.

While recommendations for Changing Places have been in building guidelines since 2009, they are not mandatory, which architects say allows them to be ignored. For existing buildings, logistical and financial barriers can be a challenge, but campaigners are focusing on making them a requirement for new builds. Arsenal Football Club is an example of a venue that successfully retrofitted a Changing Places toilet, receiving a very positive reaction.

A group of Italian consumers' organisations, supported by the Service Employees International Union (SEIU) and European unions, has made a formal complaint to the European Commission against McDonald's. They accuse McDonald's of abusing its dominant market position by forcing franchisees to pay excessive rents and high fees, and by using longer-than-average contracts that prevent them from switching to competitors. The complaint claims this leads to poorer consumer choice and higher prices. McDonald's stated that it shares risks and rewards with its franchisees and is committed to supporting them. The European Commission will study the submission and may launch an investigation. Franchisees operate 73% of McDonald's restaurants in Europe, and in 2014, McDonald's received $9.27bn in revenues from its franchised restaurants worldwide.

A poster with the phrase #prayforjosh appeared in Holywood as part of a social media campaign for 13-year-old Joshua Martin from Donaghadee, County Down. Joshua was diagnosed with cancer on Christmas Eve when doctors, intending to operate on his appendix, instead discovered and removed a large primary cancer and five smaller growths. The campaign began as a hashtag on Facebook and Instagram by Bangor Elim Church, where Joshua's father is on the pastoral staff, and has since gone viral, reaching over 79,000 people worldwide. A mystery donor paid for the large poster to be erected.

Brecon Barracks is set to close as part of a shake-up of UK military buildings. Conservative MP Chris Davies condemned the decision, highlighting the barracks' history since 1805, including its connection to the battle at Rorke's Drift. He stated the decision shows a "blatant lack of respect for that history" and that he would be fighting it, launching a petition. Davies also expressed concern about the impact on local unemployment and the town's military tourism. The barracks has about 85 civilian and 90 military staff, but it is not thought jobs are at risk. The nearby Sennybridge training ground and infantry school at Dering Lines are not expected to be affected.

As part of the reorganisation in Wales, a specialist light infantry centre will be created at St Athan. Cawdor Barracks will close in 2024, and a storage depot at Sennybridge will close in 2025. Shadow Defence Secretary Nia Griffith said the ministry was "right to restructure its estate" but warned that closing bases would affect livelihoods.

A House of Lords report warns that the UK fishing industry, which largely supported Brexit, risks being marginalised in wider negotiations. The report notes that while Brexit offers the chance to regain control over UK waters, the industry's small contribution to GDP (half of one percent) and workforce (12,000 fishers) might make it a low government priority. A key challenge is that the UK exports most of its fish to the EU and imports a significant amount of the fish it consumes from the EU. Therefore, continued access to the EU market is crucial, but this may require allowing EU boats to fish in UK waters as a trade-off. The report also suggests retaining elements of the EU's Common Fisheries Policy (CFP), like basing quotas on scientific advice, and highlights the UK's international obligation to cooperate with neighbouring states. A potential complication is that leaving the CFP framework could lead to four different fisheries management systems within the UK. Despite these warnings, many in the fishing industry remain optimistic, viewing Brexit as an opportunity for fairer shares and better management of UK waters.

Ed Snowden, a former CIA technical worker, revealed himself as the source of leaks detailing US surveillance programs. According to the leaked documents, the US National Security Agency (NSA) has massive-scale access to individuals' chat logs, stored data, voice traffic, file transfers, and social networking data. One program, Prism, allegedly provided "backdoor" access to the servers of nine major tech companies, including Google, Facebook, and Apple, though the companies deny involvement.

US officials, such as Director of National Intelligence James Clapper, described the leaks as "extremely damaging," while NSA Director Keith Alexander stated the operations helped keep Americans secure. Snowden said he acted because he found the extent of the surveillance "horrifying." The US government confirmed it requested millions of phone records from Verizon.

The passage also notes that data protection laws often regulate companies rather than government activity and that user data is frequently stored in the US, making it subject to US laws like the Patriot Act. It is unknown if other governments, such as the UK's GCHQ, were involved.

OpenAI is a research venture backed by figures like Elon Musk and Peter Thiel, as well as companies like Infosys and Amazon Web Services. Its goal is to advance digital intelligence for the benefit of humanity, free from the need to generate financial returns. The venture acknowledges both the potential benefits of human-level AI and the potential for damage if it is built or used incorrectly. Scientists like Elon Musk and Stephen Hawking have warned that AI could threaten humanity, while other experts believe this risk is remote. OpenAI states that AI should be an extension of human will and distributed broadly and safely. Only a small portion of the $1 billion pledged will be spent in the initial years.

L/Bdr Parkinson, who was seriously injured in a bomb attack in Afghanistan in 2006, carried the Olympic torch on 26 June. His nomination noted that despite a brain injury that initially took his speech, he has fought back, now speaks unaided, and his personality remains unchanged. He spends 12 hours a day in rehab and fundraising for military charities. Since carrying the torch, he has received thousands of Facebook friend requests, exceeding the 5,000 limit for a personal page. His mother described the public response as "phenomenal," with increased website traffic for the Pilgrim Bandits charity, numerous emails, and requests for him to visit with the torch. Facebook's guidance suggests he could switch to a public figure page or use the subscribe feature to manage the requests.

In 2011, the poverty rate was 15%, affecting 46.2 million Americans, and remained unchanged after three years of increases. The poverty threshold for a family of four was $23,021. Real median household income fell by 1.5%, while income inequality, measured by the Gini index, rose by 1.6%, the first annual increase since 1993. The percentage of people without health insurance decreased from 16.3% to 15.7%. The poverty rate in 2010 was 15.1%.

Jos Buttler, a 25-year-old short-format specialist, has signed a new deal to stay with Lancashire until 2019. Buttler, who moved from Somerset in 2013, holds the record for England's three fastest ODI centuries. Cricket director and head coach Ashley Giles stated that Buttler is one of the most talented cricketers, a factor in their T20 Blast final win, and a great presence in the dressing room. After playing in the Indian Premier League, Buttler will return to Lancashire for the T20 Blast home game against Durham.

Four decommissioned Type 22 frigates, HMS Cumberland, HMS Campbeltown, HMS Chatham, and HMS Cornwall, are moored in Portsmouth Harbour and are up for sale. Bidders registered their interest by January 23rd, with viewings scheduled for late February and March, and a final decision expected in the spring. The government's Disposal Services Authority intends to award at least one frigate to a UK ship recycler to assess the industry's capacity. Penny Mordaunt, MP for Portsmouth North, supports giving UK recyclers a chance but also hopes to see at least one ship saved, suggesting it could be turned into a reef and diving attraction to generate tourism income. The Ministry of Defence aims to achieve the "best financial return for the taxpayer." The Type 22 frigates were originally anti-submarine ships that evolved into powerful surface combatants, serving as ideal flagships with a crew of about 280.

Since 1987, Fiji has experienced significant racial and political instability, marked by a series of coups. A 1987 coup by indigenous Fijians overthrew an Indian-dominated coalition. Another coup in 2000, led by George Speight, saw the ethnic Indian prime minister taken hostage. These events, along with a bloodless military takeover in 2006, harmed Fiji's economy, particularly tourism, and its international reputation, leading to its suspension from the Commonwealth in 2009. After holding free elections in 2014, Fiji was reinstated. The population is divided between indigenous Fijians, who are now the majority, and Indo-Fijians, with minimal mixing between the groups. The economy relies on sugar and tourism but is diverse, including mining and a strong services sector. However, it has been hampered by trade and budget deficits, making it a large recipient of aid.

Syrian Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad stated that Syria is "doing its best" to comply with the timetable for destroying its chemical weapons, despite missing a deadline. He attributed the delay to attacks on weapons shipments by "terrorist groups." The US expressed concern over the slow progress, with only about 4% of the stockpile having left the country. Russia has set a new deadline of March 1 for the transfer.

Mr. Mekdad also denied government forces have used barrel bombs on civilians in Aleppo, despite claims from the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights and the Aleppo Media Centre that hundreds have been killed in such attacks. He insisted the government is defending its people from "terrorist attacks."

Additionally, Syrian state media denied reports from the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights and other groups that rebels had seized control of Aleppo's central prison, stating that the attack was "thwarted."

The passage discusses the shortlist for the 46th Booker Prize. Mukherjee's *The Lives Of Others* is the 5/2 favourite to win. This is the first year the prize is open to all authors writing in English, regardless of nationality. The shortlist includes three British writers (Howard Jacobson, Ali Smith), two Americans (Joshua Ferris, Karen Joy Fowler), and one Australian (Richard Flanagan). The winner will be announced at London's Guildhall.

The article provides brief descriptions of each shortlisted novel:
*   **Mukherjee's *The Lives Of Others***: A story of family secrets in 1960s Calcutta.
*   **Jacobson's *J***: A futuristic love story where the past is not spoken of.
*   **Smith's *How To Be Both***: Two interlinking stories about a Renaissance artist and a 1960s child.
*   **Ferris's *To Rise Again at a Decent Hour***: Explores atheism through a New York dentist.
*   **Fowler's *We Are All Completely Beside Ourselves***: Narrated by a college student, it tells her family's story. It is the best-selling book on the list.
*   **Flanagan's *The Narrow Road to the Deep North***: A love story set during the construction of the Thailand-Burma Death Railway.

The judging panel is chaired by AC Grayling. Last year's winner was Eleanor Catton for *The Luminaries*. Shortlisted authors receive Â£2,500 and a special edition of their book.

A man, referred to as PJS, is appealing a court ruling that would lift a ban on him being named in the media in England and Wales. The Supreme Court will hear arguments on whether to grant the appeal. An interim injunction preventing his identification will remain in place until the hearing concludes.

The case concerns The Sun on Sunday's desire to publish an account of PJS's alleged extra-marital activities, including a three-way sexual encounter. PJS argues he has a right to privacy.

Initially, a High Court judge refused an injunction, but two appeal court judges later granted one. News Group Newspapers, publishers of The Sun on Sunday, then asked for the ban to be lifted, arguing that the story had already been published in other countries and spread online. On Monday, Court of Appeal judges agreed, stating that details were so widespread that confidentiality had "probably been lost," and it was a "hopeless task" to remove online stories. They gave PJS until Tuesday to apply to the Supreme Court.

Fosse Park, located near junction 21 of the M1, was opened in 1989 and purchased in August for Â£345.5m. The new owners are preparing plans to improve parking, traffic congestion, and the appearance of the units. Ernie White, leader of Blaby District Council, stated the new owners see it as an investment they can improve, particularly the view from the city. Paul Clarke, director of investments at Crown Estates, said they want to address parking and congestion issues, the "tired" appearance of the park, and the quality of common areas where people walk and park.

A film, set for release in Malaysia, sparked controversy due to a "gay moment." Disney held the release for a content "review." The Malaysian Censorship Board (LPF) approved the film's screening with "a minor edit concerning a gay moment" and gave it a "P13 parental guidance classification." Homosexual activity is illegal in Malaysia. The LPF Chairman stated that the board only approves content and does not control screening dates. A new release date has not been announced, and local cinemas are offering refunds for advance ticket purchases. The "exclusively gay moment" involves the character LeFou and his feelings for Gaston. The decision to review the film was criticized by many netizens.

Landlords who let properties to more than three unrelated people need to apply for a House of Multiple Occupation (HMO) licence, which can cost Â£1,000. Southampton City Council estimates there are 1,500 unlicensed HMOs in the area, with landlords facing fines of up to Â£20,000 for non-compliance. Shelter helpline adviser Nadeem Khan stated that tenants in these properties often fear eviction and live in poorly maintained homes. The council has introduced licensing in specific areas (Designations 1 and 2) and has prosecuted one firm and 13 individuals for not complying.

Following an election almost two months ago, Acting Taoiseach Enda Kenny of Fine Gael and MicheÃ¡l Martin of Fianna FÃ¡il are trying to avoid a second election. No party was able to form a majority government. Mr Martin has stated that Fianna FÃ¡il will facilitate a minority government but will not support a programme for government. Water charges are a major point of disagreement, with Fianna FÃ¡il wanting their immediate removal and Fine Gael seeing a role for them. A commission to examine the future of Irish Water is a proposal being considered. The election results were: Fine Gael 50 seats, Fianna FÃ¡il 44, Sinn FÃ©in 23, and the Labour Party seven.

A fire broke out on the Sorrento ferry, which was travelling to Valencia. The fire started on a car deck and became uncontrollable, leading to a full evacuation of passengers and crew onto lifeboats.

The ship was 27km from Mallorca when the incident occurred. Passengers were rescued by another ferry, the Puglia, and were being taken back to Palma de Mallorca. At least three people were injured and taken to hospital by helicopter, with one reported to be seriously hurt. The cause of the fire is unclear, and the Balearic Islands port authority stated that the Sorrento may sink.

The Electoral Commission reported that 38 MPs highlighted instances of people, including students, allegedly voting twice, which is a criminal offence. A record 46.8 million people were registered for the 8 June election, with a turnout of 68.7%, the highest since 1997. There was a surge in registration applications, with 2.9 million received in the six weeks after the snap poll was called. However, a significant proportion of these were likely duplicates due to the lack of a unified system. The online registration service and the individual electoral registers run by councils use different, unconnected databases. This issue caused administrative and financial burdens. The Commission suggests better joining up of electoral registers to identify duplicates and reduce the risk of double voting. It also recommends a verification function on registration sites, similar to those in Australia, New Zealand, and the Republic of Ireland. While some people, like students, can lawfully register in two constituencies, voting twice in a general election is an offence. Labour's Cat Smith warned against making it harder for young people to register to vote.

Officials believe that Lawrence Phillips, a 40-year-old former NFL player, killed himself in prison on a Wednesday. Phillips was a star player at the University of Nebraska in the 1990s and played for the St Louis Rams, Miami Dolphins, and San Francisco 49ers until 1999. He had a history of trouble on and off the field, which continued after his NFL career. He was serving a prison sentence of over 30 years for convictions including assault for driving his car into a group of teenagers and assaulting a former girlfriend. At the time of his death, he was in a cell alone after being accused of killing his former cellmate, Damion Soward. A judge had recently found there was enough evidence to try him for Soward's death. His former coach, Tom Osborne, described him as intelligent with good qualities but also having anger issues and "demons" he couldn't overcome.

Private Derby XXX, a Swaledale ram and mascot for the Mercian Regiment, was promoted to lance corporal for "good behaviour". The promotion was awarded by Brigadier Andrew Williams at an event in Chester. He is the 30th mascot in a line dating back to 1858. Officially a soldier, he has an army number, is paid for rations, and takes holidays on the Chatsworth Estate. During his career, he has met Prince William and helped switch on the Ashbourne Christmas lights.

In a dramatic football match, Liverpool secured a 4-3 victory over Borussia Dortmund with an injury-time goal from Dejan Lovren. The win moves Liverpool into the last four of what some consider Europe's second-rate pot, a label dismissed after this classic encounter.

Manager Jurgen Klopp's priority to "turn doubters into believers" was central to the victory. Despite being down 2-0 within nine minutes, Klopp invoked the spirit of the 2005 Istanbul Champions League final to inspire his team. Liverpool needed three goals twice during the match, with goals from Divock Origi, Philippe Coutinho, Mamadou Sakho, and finally Lovren completing the comeback.

The atmosphere at Anfield was described as a "cauldron of emotions," with a perfectly observed minute's silence for the Hillsborough disaster anniversary. Klopp was a key figure on the touchline, demanding more noise from the fans, which created a soundtrack for the momentous night. In six months, Klopp has imprinted his identity on the players and fans.

Following a meeting of the EU Negotiation Joint Ministerial Committee in London, Mr. Davis stated the UK government would keep Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland updated on negotiations. He proposed a monthly meeting for a "two-way information flow" to allow devolved administrations to voice their views. Mr. Russell, however, said that transparency about UK government plans was needed and that more than four months after the referendum, the UK government's strategic intentions were still not clear. He emphasized that membership of the single market is "essential for the economic prosperity of Scotland". The Scottish government also intends to oppose the UK government in the Supreme Court during the appeal regarding the triggering of Article 50.

A flock of 13 cloned sheep, including four identical sisters of Dolly the sheep, are living on a farm owned by the University of Nottingham. They are undergoing extensive physical examinations and tests to determine if cloned animals age normally and are healthy. This research, led by Professor Kevin Sinclair, addresses concerns that cloning from an adult cell might transfer "age-memory," causing premature aging and related diseases. The original Dolly died at six-and-a-half and had osteoarthritis, raising these concerns. The study focuses on cardiovascular disease, diabetes, and osteoarthritis. The results of the study, which could have significant implications for the future of cloning, are due to be published.

Shutter Speed, the 4-7 favourite trained by John Gosden and ridden by Frankie Dettori, won the Musidora Stakes, beating Vintage Folly by a length and three quarters. This was the fifth Musidora win for both Gosden and Dettori. Dettori commented that the ground was very soft and she would be a better horse on better ground. Shutter Speed will go to Chantilly next for the French Oaks, while stablemates Enable and Coronet are contenders for the Oaks at Epsom. In other results, Tasleet won the Duke of York Stakes. Gosden is also concerned about the ground for his colt Cracksman in the Dante Stakes and will walk the course before deciding if he runs.

The pound experienced volatility, initially slipping against the dollar and euro before a brief recovery and subsequent fall. The "volatility index" reached levels not seen since the 2008 financial crisis. The pound was down 0.2% against the dollar at $1.4226, 0.6% against the euro at â¬1.2605, and 1% against the Japanese yen. Investor uncertainty has been influenced by data showing a decrease in the chances of a Remain vote, with two polls putting the Leave camp ahead. The implied probability of a Remain vote fell from almost 80% to 68.5% in a week, according to Betfair. This uncertainty also impacted stock markets, with Japan's Nikkei index closing down 3.5%, Hong Kong's index sliding 2.5%, and London's FTSE 100 ending the day down 1.1%. The Leave campaign argued that the pound had simply retreated to March levels and that a weaker pound benefits UK exporters.

The Iron are sixth in the National League, one point outside the play-off spots. After a recent loss to Barrow, which extended their losing run to three games, Cowley from The Iron stated it was a tough game, especially after conceding a goal five minutes in following a long journey. Despite the loss, Cowley remains positive, calling their journey so far "remarkable" and acknowledging the challenge for his part-time team.

From April 2015, responsibility for most planning decisions in Northern Ireland will shift from the central Planning Service to local councils, meaning elected politicians will make these decisions. This move is seen by some, like Michael Corr of PLACE, as a "huge opportunity" for councils to develop their own communities. However, others express concern. The environmental group Friends of the Earth warns of potential discrimination and unfairness, referencing issues from the 1960s where councils were accused of discrimination in housing allocation. James Orr, from the group, highlights the "tradition of close relationships between developers and political parties" as a potential problem and calls for a strictly enforced code of conduct and transparency. The issue of revealing political donations is also raised, with some politicians opposing it due to security concerns for donors, while others argue the donation limits are largely irrelevant. The Northern Ireland Secretary will decide when to implement more transparency on political donations.

A one-year-old cat named Teenie was shot three times with what is believed to be a powerful air gun.
*   **What were the injuries?** The cat was shot twice in the shoulder and once in the left back leg, which had to be amputated.
*   **Who found the cat?** Her owner, Sarah Nisbett, found her injured in NiddryView, Winchburgh, on Friday 14 March and took her to the Scottish SPCA.
*   **What is the context?** The Scottish SPCA is using this incident to highlight why the Scottish government should implement the licensing of airguns. Last year, the government held a consultation on this, but 87% of respondents opposed the plan.

Christian Benteke has signed for Liverpool on a "long-term contract," becoming the club's second most expensive signing and their seventh of the summer. Liverpool triggered a release clause in his contract with Aston Villa, where he scored 49 goals in 101 games after joining from Genk for Â£7m in 2012. Benteke stated he joined Liverpool to win trophies and be part of the manager's project.

This signing follows Liverpool's struggle for goals last season after selling Luis Suarez and dealing with injuries to Daniel Sturridge. To address this, manager Brendan Rodgers has also brought in forwards Danny Ings and Roberto Firmino. Former Villa manager Paul Lambert and former Liverpool striker John Aldridge both expressed their belief that Benteke will be a successful signing for the club.

A study commissioned by the charity Tablets for Schools found that tablet use is widespread and growing in UK schools, with 68% of primary and 69% of secondary schools using them to some extent. The number of tablets in schools is expected to rise from 430,000 to almost 900,000 between 2014 and 2016. However, the study found no clear evidence that tablets lead to academic improvement, as researchers cannot isolate technology's impact on results. Despite this, head teachers reported a positive impact, noting that tablets can motivate disengaged pupils and increase family involvement. The study also highlighted how immersed young people are in technology, with many taking internet-connected devices to bed for social media. A separate study suggested touch-screen computers were particularly useful for helping boys and poorer pupils learn to read.

The exhibition "Growing Up in the City" at the Museum of Liverpool features 25 photographs capturing the life of children over more than 100 years, from the 1880s to the 1990s. The images provide a social history of Liverpool, showing how childhood has changed and how special occasions were marked. The oldest image is from 1887, showing the Rollo children in fancy dress. Another photograph from around 1900 depicts a young maid, highlighting that some children had to work. The exhibition was curated by Kay Jones, who selected the final 25 images from the National Museums Liverpool's collections to show both the good and bad experiences of childhood. The exhibition runs until 25 September.

Centre-back Anderson, 27, has cancelled his contract with Barrow to join a National League rival. He previously played for Aldershot, Exeter, and in Italy, and may play against his former club on 18 February. Striker Ruairi Keating, 21, has also joined the Gulls, having previously played for Sligo Rovers, Galway United, and Finn Harps. His move is subject to international clearance. Gulls boss Kevin Nicholson described Anderson as a "leader-type" and Keating as "young" and "incredibly hungry." The Gulls are four points above the relegation zone.

Bolivia has enacted a new law, signed by Vice-President Alvaro Garcia Linera, that permits 12-year-olds to be contracted for work with parental authorization. Mr. Garcia stated the legislation reflects the needs of Bolivia, one of South America's poorest countries, and aims to balance reality with international treaties. The law also increases punishments for violence against children, setting a 30-year jail sentence for child homicide. According to UNICEF, over 500,000 children already work in Bolivia to supplement family income, some in extreme conditions. The government hopes the law will help eradicate extreme poverty. The International Labour Organisation (ILO), which sets a minimum working age of 14 for developing countries, is studying the new legislation to see if it breaches international regulations.

Rosie O'Donnell, a 50-year-old actress, had a heart attack after falling ill at home. After helping a woman get out of her car, O'Donnell experienced an aching chest, nausea, and fever. She looked up "women's heart attack symptoms" online, which included sudden nausea and aches, and took some aspirin. She did not call emergency services. The next day, a cardiologist inserted a stent into an artery that was 99% blocked. The type of heart attack was known as the "widow maker." O'Donnell warned her readers to know the symptoms and call 911. Her show, "The Rosie Show," was recently cancelled due to low ratings.

Che Labastide-Wellington was stabbed in an alleyway in Kenton at about 00:30 GMT on a Saturday evening after attending a party. He was pronounced dead about an hour later. Police believe he was targeted in a later scuffle, separate from an earlier fight where a group of youths tried to gain entry to the party. A 16-year-old boy was also stabbed and is in stable condition. A 21-year-old man has been arrested on suspicion of murder. Two boys, aged 15 and 16, were also arrested on suspicion of murder and have been bailed. A 14-year-old is being held on suspicion of possession of an offensive weapon.

A team from Wales visited Aarhus, Denmark, to learn about a new approach to diagnosing cancer, which was implemented after Denmark experienced poor cancer survival statistics over 15 years ago. The problem was long waiting times for diagnosis, particularly for patients with vague or difficult-to-diagnose symptoms.

The new Danish model has three routes for patients:
1.  A fast-track route for patients with "alarm" symptoms of specific cancers.
2.  Diagnostic centres for patients with symptoms that GPs cannot diagnose, where they receive a range of tests and scans quickly.
3.  "Yes-no" centres for patients with minor symptoms, offering a simple test or scan to quickly rule out or identify serious disease.

According to Professor Frede Olesen, these changes have led to better organization, improved cancer survival rates, and have helped Denmark catch up with other Scandinavian countries without "flooding the system" with more GP referrals.

Powys council will take over the service previously handled by the Office of Fair Trading (OFT), which has been disbanded. Powys will receive Â£170,000 a year to issue warning and banning orders against estate agents who act dishonestly or breach laws. People will still complain to their local authority trading standards, who will prosecute if necessary but will refer cases to Powys if the Estate Agents Act has been breached. James Munro will lead the new team.

NHS Employers has approved a plan to train NHS staff, such as nurses, to perform additional tasks to address doctor shortages. A review by the Nuffield Trust found existing examples of nurses filling in for hospital doctors and pharmacists for GPs. The report suggests these changes are beneficial due to the increasing need to manage long-term conditions. However, unions and the British Medical Association have expressed concerns, warning that this should not be a "quick fix" for staff shortages or a substitute for the expertise and training of doctors. They also highlighted that a lack of funding for training is a significant obstacle.

At 03:00 GMT, a crash on Lower Bristol Road in Bath at Rackfield Place led Avon and Somerset Police to close the A36 road. The closure, which was lifted at 14:00 GMT, caused disruption to commuters and bus services. Investigations into the collision are ongoing. First bus services stated that while some services had resumed, it would take a few hours for all to return to normal, with hopes of a full service for the evening commute.

Natural Resources Wales (NRW) and Tidal Lagoon Power (TLP) are in disagreement over the environmental impact of a proposed tidal lagoon project. NRW estimated the lagoon would kill 21% of salmon and 25% of sea trout annually, based on what it calls the "best available evidence." TLP disputes these figures, calling them "unrealistic and grossly misleading" and claiming they lack a "clear scientific basis." TLP's own computer modelling estimates a "worst case scenario" of a 2% fish mortality rate.

The Â£1.3bn Swansea project is considered a test for larger versions. UK government ministers are reviewing the scheme's viability, and the Welsh Government, which is "very supportive," is seeking clarity on the UK government's position. NRW stated it strongly disagrees with TLP's criticism, is "very surprised and disappointed by" it, and has shared its data and methodology with the developer over a year-and-a-half.

A new industry-led agri-food marketing body is being established in Northern Ireland.
*   **Who announced it?** Enterprise, Trade and Investment (DETI) Minister Arlene Foster.
*   **Who will develop it?** The Agri-Food Strategy Board (AFSB).
*   **What is its purpose?** To provide strategic leadership and direction for marketing activities in the agri-food industry, similar to Scotland Food and Drink, and to better coordinate current marketing efforts.
*   **Why is it important?** The agri-food industry is "hugely important" to Northern Ireland, supporting almost 100,000 jobs and being a key sector for export-led economic growth.
*   **Who else commented?** Agriculture Minister Michelle O'Neill welcomed the announcement but noted the plans could have "implications for the work of other organisations," including her own department.

On Saturday afternoon, the public is invited to plant thousands of new trees at Brackfield Wood in the Faughan Valley. The project, organised by the Woodland Trust, is part of a UK-wide initiative to plant millions of native trees to commemorate those who died in WW1. The goal for Brackfield Wood is to plant 40,000 trees as a tribute to the estimated 40,000 people from the island of Ireland who died in the conflict. The charity is providing saplings and advises volunteers to wear suitable footwear. The wood is located about seven miles outside Derry city, off the Glenshane Road, with limited parking available.

Hilary won the Theakstons Old Peculier Crime Novel of the Year Award for the book "Someone Else's Skin," the first in a series featuring Det Insp Marnie Rome. The book, which deals with domestic violence and honour crime, was described by judge Alison Graham as "an emotionally exhausting and powerful story." The awards were given at the start of the annual crime writing festival in Harrogate. At the same event, US author Sara Paretsky received an outstanding contribution honour for her 23-year career writing about the female private investigator, VI Warshawski. Paretsky also founded Sisters In Crime, an organization supporting female crime writers.

Mitchell Santner, a 24-year-old left-arm batsman and spinner, will rejoin Worcestershire Rapids after the ICC Trophy in June. In 2016, he broke his finger in his second game for the county, which director of cricket Steve Rhodes described as a "massive blow" to their qualification hopes. Santner stated he enjoyed his previous time at Worcester and is looking forward to making an impact with both bat and ball. Worcestershire has also signed Australian bowler John Hastings as their main overseas player for the 2017 season.

In 2008, Barry Pring, 47, was killed by a speeding car on a dual carriageway in Kiev. The coroner, Dr Elizabeth Earland, recorded a verdict of unlawful killing, stating she was satisfied beyond a reasonable doubt. The car had stolen licence plates, did not brake or stop, and was travelling at 75mph with no lights on. Pring's wife, Ganna Ziuzina, who was 19 years younger, had returned to a restaurant for a missing glove at the time of the incident. Pring's family believes he was murdered in a staged hit-and-run, and his mother stated they were sure Ziuzina was involved in his death to inherit his money. The inquest heard that Ziuzina, a former lap dancer, tried to claim Pring's assets within days of his death, sold his Range Rover, and moved funds from his bank account. She was also reportedly having an affair. A Ukrainian police inquiry into the death was relaunched in 2011 as a murder investigation, which is still active but not actively pursued.

Charlie Fearns, from Merseyside, needs to fly to Seattle, America, for experimental T-Cell Therapy that is unavailable in the UK. This is necessary after his last transplant failed and he suffered a third relapse. An anonymous donor has paid for the treatment at Seattle Children's Hospital. Charlie's parents, Sophie and Rob Fearns, expressed that they were "overwhelmed" and "extremely grateful" for the donation, which was confirmed via an email from the hospital. The treatment will start as soon as possible now that financial clearance has been given.

Following the online posting of stolen celebrity photos from iCloud, Apple has implemented a two-step verification system for its back-up service. This system, which remains an opt-in choice, requires users to enter a four-digit code sent to a trusted device when logging in from a new device. This action is intended to block third-party software, like Elcomsoft's Phone Password Breaker, which was reportedly used in the hacks. If a user loses their trusted device, a 14-character recovery key is needed to regain access. While one expert believes this implementation is secure, he also raised concerns about the recovery key being easily lost or stolen. Another expert suggested that two-factor authentication should be the default setting, not just for Apple but for other major tech companies as well. Apple's CEO stated the company plans to more aggressively encourage users to enable the feature.

Dan Groves stated that the "finer points" of a deal for Wright to buy 20% of the club are yet to be released. The Sun reported that the 30-year-old will become a club director. Billericay, who are eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, were recently taken over by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who said he was "comfortable" investing Â£10,000 a week. The club also signed former England international Paul Konchesky. Wright was the runner-up in I'm A Celebrity Get Me Out Of Here in 2011 and has played non-league football for several clubs.

Mr Ashley has been asked to give evidence about the treatment of his workers following a BBC investigation into his Derbyshire company's warehouse working practices. Iain Wright, an MP who chairs the Business, Innovation and Skills (BIS) select committee, sent a letter inviting Mr Ashley to a public meeting at Westminster. Mr Ashley had previously invited the committee to the company's base in Shirebrook, but the committee declined, stating their meetings are normally held in public at Westminster. Mr Ashley has not accepted any of the alternative dates offered and has until 21 March to respond. The letter warns that if he fails to agree to attend, the committee may take the matter further, including a potential complaint of contempt to the House of Commons. Sports Direct has not commented to the BBC but has previously pledged to review worker rights.

A report titled "Putin. War," initiated by a murdered opposition politician and completed by his colleagues led by Ilya Yashin, accuses President Vladimir Putin of waging war in Ukraine for his own ends. The report, based on previously published facts, compiles evidence to describe the human and economic cost of the conflict. It asserts that Russian soldiers and equipment were decisive in all major victories for pro-Russian rebels, with Russian generals directing the main battles. The report also claims that Russian "volunteers" are paid salaries up to $3,000 a month and estimates Russia's spending on the conflict at 53 billion roubles. The opposition faces challenges in publishing and distributing the report, and it is uncertain how many people will be interested in its findings.

Craig Nelson, also known as Craig Preston, was found at the Woodhead Tunnels in Derbyshire on Monday at 11:00 BST. A post-mortem revealed the 34-year-old from Rotherham died from head injuries. A 41-year-old man and a 23-year-old woman were arrested in Sheffield and are in custody.

Carwyn Jones, the First Minister of Wales, complained that he was not shown the Article 50 letter before it was published, nor was he invited to contribute to its drafting. He called this "unacceptable" and a culmination of a process where devolved administrations have been treated with a "lack of respect." In response, Welsh Secretary Alun Cairns stated that the Prime Minister had been in Wales three times in the last six weeks and that the letter's contents had been discussed for months.

In the letter, Mrs. May told Donald Tusk that there would be full consultation on which powers returning from the EU should be devolved to Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland, with the expectation of a "significant increase in the decision-making power of each devolved administration." However, the passage notes it is a mystery which specific powers will be devolved, whether money will follow these powers, and that Alun Cairns would not answer these questions. Carwyn Jones expressed fears that no money would accompany the powers after 2020. More details might be revealed in a future white paper on the Great Repeal Bill.

Two cars were damaged in an incident in the Nursery Drive and Parkhead area of Newry on Friday night. Assistant Chief Constable Stephen Martin described the event as "mindless attacks on PSNI officers and the Newry community." A PSNI Newry & Mourne Facebook post stated that police were "carrying out duties" when they were attacked and appealed to parents to know where their children are.

Mr. Charney, the company's founder, was ousted last year due to employee complaints and accusations of misusing company funds.
