The company's board filed court documents, in response to Mr. Charney's defamation lawsuit, which they say contain evidence of illicit emails and racially derogatory taunts by him. The board stated that Mr. Charney repeatedly violated the company's sexual harassment and anti-discrimination policy and that they do not expect him to return to the firm. Mr. Charney's lawyer, Keith Fink, said many of the statements were false and accused the company of invading Mr. Charney's privacy in an attempt to extort him. American Apparel was also granted a restraining order to prevent Mr. Charney from making negative statements about the company or trying to remove board members.

Great Britain's basketball team is set to play a home game against Greece at the Copper Box in London. This is their only home game before competing at FIBA EuroBasket 2017. In their previous match in Patras, Greece, Greece won 92-64. However, three members of the Greek team will be missing for the upcoming game. GB guard Teddy Okereafor, who is from Stratford, expressed excitement about playing at the Copper Box and noted the game is crucial preparation for EuroBasket. After the Greece game, the team will travel to a tournament in Poland for their final warm-up games. The game will be available to watch on BBC iPlayer and the BBC Sport website and app.

The passage recounts the author's experience covering the launch of the first iPhone. Initially, obtaining the phone for a news piece seemed impossible as it was not yet available. However, the author managed to borrow one from Apple's marketing chief, Phil Schiller, for a segment on the Ten O'Clock News. This coverage drew some criticism for giving "undue prominence to a product launch," which the author defended by comparing its potential impact to the Model T Ford. The author reflects that this comparison, which seemed outlandish at the time, now appears apt. The passage argues that the iPhone was a transformative technology, primarily due to its user interface, which made it easier for people to do more than just talk and text. It revolutionized activities like photography, as illustrated by a comparison between a poor-quality photo of Steve Jobs taken by the author on a digital SLR camera and a better-quality, instantly shareable photo taken ten years later on an iPhone. The author concludes that despite initial skepticism, the iPhone's launch marked the beginning of the "mobile connected era."

Tests have confirmed that multiple cats near Victor Avenue in Melton Mowbray, Leicestershire, have died after ingesting a toxic substance, identified as antifreeze in one case. Five cats have died in total: one seven-month-old named Meereen died on Monday, three others died in the last seven days, and another died two weeks ago. The RSPCA is unsure if the poisonings were accidental or deliberate and is appealing for residents to store chemicals safely and clean up any antifreeze spills.

Despite the Syriza government's impending agreement to implement more austerity and liberalisation measures, including VAT increases and pension cuts, there are no street protests in Athens. This lack of protest may be the calm before the details of the new â¬86bn bailout are revealed. The government, led by the still-popular Alexis Tsipras, appears to have accepted there is no alternative after the near-death economic experience in July, which led to bank closures. Greece is now suffering from both fiscal and monetary austerity, with banks having no money to lend, which could impact businesses' ability to order stock. For the new bailout to lead to recovery, creditors may need to ease Greece's debt burden. Meanwhile, tourism is booming, with Athens airport expecting 25 million arrivals, possibly because Greece is seen as a safer holiday destination compared to areas near territory controlled by the so-called Islamic State.

Ross Kemp, who plays Grant Mitchell, will make a brief return to EastEnders for the final episodes of Barbara Windsor's character, Peggy Mitchell. Dame Barbara's character, who recently returned to the show, will be killed off from cancer in scenes to be screened in the spring. Kemp, who played Grant from 1990-1999 and again in 2005-2006, is returning to reunite the Mitchell brothers with their mother for the last time. EastEnders' executive producer stated that Grant's return will see him say goodbye to his mother and be reunited with his brother, Phil.

Lance Corporal Trimaan "Harry" Dhillon stalked and fatally attacked 24-year-old Alice Ruggles. When police informed her parents, Sue Hills and Clive Ruggles, of her death, they immediately knew Dhillon was responsible. The trial heard that Dhillon had become obsessed with her. Dr Hills expressed guilt for reassuring her daughter that everything would be alright and for dismissing her other daughter Emma's warning that Dhillon would kill Alice. Professor Ruggles stated that they did not realize how serious the situation was. Dhillon, 26, was found guilty of murder and sentenced to a minimum of 22 years. Alice's parents have set up the Alice Ruggles Trust to raise awareness about the dangers of stalking.

French firm EDF approved funding for the Â£18bn Hinkley Point project in Somerset, with one-third of the cost provided by Chinese investors. However, the UK government, under Business Secretary Greg Clark, announced it would "consider carefully" before backing the project, launching a further review. This delay surprised EDF, whose chief executive cancelled a trip to the site.

Critics have raised concerns about environmental damage, escalating costs, and the involvement of foreign governments. An EDF board member, Gerard Magnin, resigned, calling the project "very risky" financially. The project is expected to provide 7% of the UK's total electricity, and supporters like the Nuclear Industry Association urge a quick decision to avoid future energy supply problems.

A new divorce application form in England and Wales asks for the name of the person a spouse has committed adultery with. Family lawyers express concern that this will add "conflict and complexity" to proceedings. While the Ministry of Justice and the form's guidance state there is "no obligation" to name a third party, lawyers believe the design of the form encourages it. Naming a third party makes them part of the court case, which can lead to delays and increased costs. The previous version of the form left a space for "co-respondents" to be named where appropriate, but the new form "flatly asks" for the name. In 2015, adultery was the reason for 12,148 of the just over 100,000 divorces in England and Wales.

Confor, a forestry industry promoter, warns that at least 16,000 hectares of commercial forest have been lost in Wales since 2001 and need replanting. The industry, worth over Â£450m annually to the Welsh economy, faces conflict with environmental policies that favour native broadleaf trees and recreational access. Britain is the world's third-largest wood importer, and while ministers say they encourage investment in woodland creation, Confor argues the current system is too bureaucratic and focuses more on environmental aspects than commercial forestry. Martin Bishop of Confor states that 20,000 hectares need to be planted annually to meet long-term targets, compared to the 90 hectares planted last year, and that there is a "huge market" for timber. The Welsh government aims for a balance between environmental, economic, and social factors in forestry development, pointing to its Glastir scheme and its "Woodlands for Wales" strategy.

A boy was badly injured after being struck in an incident on Bank Street in Coatbridge, near Langloan Primary School, at about 16:40. He was taken to Queen Elizabeth University Hospital in Glasgow, where his condition is believed to be serious.

Defence attachÃ© Capt Oleg Kornienko presented Ushakov medals to British veterans of the Arctic Convoys for their role in resupplying the Soviet Union during World War II. The convoys, described by Winston Churchill as "the worst journey on earth," faced threats from German U-boats, aircraft, severe cold, and ice, resulting in the loss of 104 merchant and 16 military vessels and thousands of Allied lives.

The Foreign Office initially blocked Russia from awarding the medals, citing a rule against receiving foreign medals for events that occurred more than five years prior. However, after a campaign and the creation of the British Arctic Star medal in 2012, the Foreign Office made an exception. The Russian embassy stated the convoys were a material expression of the wartime alliance, providing weapons that helped defeat the Germans on the Eastern Front. The first Ushakov medals were presented by President Vladimir Putin in June 2013.

A report by HM Inspectorate of Probation found delays in offenders starting their unpaid work and that too many were let off for non-attendance. In one case, an offender completed only 16 hours in 17 months. Unpaid work, or "community payback," can be given for offences like shoplifting or theft, with 70,000 offenders ordered to do it in 2014. Inspectors looked at 100 cases and interviewed 86 offenders, making 15 recommendations for improvement.

The report noted that organising people with chaotic lives is a challenge. While inspectors praised some high-quality work and instances where offenders gained skills and viewed their sentences positively, they also found much of the delivery was "not good enough." The chief inspector, Paul Wilson, stated that unpaid work was often viewed simply as a punishment, which was a "wasted opportunity," and called for "urgent remedial action." The Ministry of Justice accepted the report's recommendations and said it was taking action to ensure offenders turn up on time and face consequences if they do not.

A paper has labeled a comedian, Brand, a "hypocrite" for advocating for economic and political "revolution" to help the poor while living in a luxury home. This is a frequent accusation against the star. When questioned by a TV reporter about his own rent while supporting a housing campaign, Brand called the journalist "a snide" and walked off. He has also been tweeting about The Sun's accusations using the hashtag #TheSunLogic.

In the past, Brand has addressed the hypocrisy charge by acknowledging his wealth and fame, stating he knows they are not the answer and that he, like everyone, needs to change. He believes in personal change, including sharing wealth, but sees it as a "sweet, futile gesture" without systemic change. He admits to doing "daft things" and calls himself a "right twerp," but argues that his personal flaws do not detract from the reality of economic disparity and ecological disaster. He suggests that the accusations of hypocrisy are a way to avoid discussing the real issue of inequality.

Dr. J. Craig Venter is a biologist and entrepreneur known for turning the mapping of the human genome into a competitive race, which sped up the process but also drew criticism from the scientific community. His early life included a period of surfing before being drafted into the Vietnam conflict, where his experience as a hospital orderly inspired him to become a doctor and gave him a sense of urgency.

In the 1980s, he worked at the US National Institute of Health (NIH) and pioneered faster methods for decoding genes, including using an automated machine and focusing on messenger RNA. After failing to secure further public funding, he left the NIH in 1992 to set up a private institute. In 1998, he formed Celera Genomics to sequence the human genome, competing with the public project and publishing results in 2001.

Following the human genome project, Dr. Venter's institute created a synthetic life form called Synthia. He has also used his yacht to collect and sequence the genomes of marine microbes. His work has been controversial but has also made him wealthy, allowing him to fund his own research. He believes synthetic microbes could lead to a new industrial revolution.

A survey of about 1,000 parents in England, commissioned by the School Food Trust, found that four out of five children who ate school lunches had tried new foods at school. Half of the parents questioned said their children had asked for foods eaten at school to be cooked at home. The most popular vegetables were carrots, sweetcorn, and peas, while aubergine, chickpeas, and spinach were among the least popular. The research was commissioned after a Mumsnet survey suggested some parents used packed lunches for fussy eaters. Both the Trust chairman and Mumsnet co-founder noted that school meals can help children try new foods, partly due to peer pressure and the healthier, more varied options now available under strict nutritional guidelines. About four in 10 primary school children in England eat school lunches.

Ãlvaro Morata, a 23-year-old striker playing for Spain at Euro 2016, joined Juventus in 2014 from Real Madrid. His transfer included a buy-back option for Real for a reported fee of up to 30m euros (Â£23m). In his two years at Juventus, he scored 27 goals and won two Serie A titles and two Coppa Italias. He has also been a reported target for Arsenal and Chelsea. Morata played in two consecutive Champions League finals, for Real in 2014 and for Juventus in 2015. He originally came through the ranks at Real, making his debut at 18 and scoring 10 goals for them.

Wilson, a 30-year-old footballer, has been without a team since being released in May. He rejoined Championship side Forest from Celtic for Â£2.5m in August 2013 and made 51 appearances in his second spell at the club. He previously spent four seasons at Forest before signing for Celtic and has also had spells with Preston North End and Notts County.

Tesco, the world's third-largest retailer, is disposing of its loss-making US food chain, Fresh & Easy. As part of an "orderly and efficient exit from the US market," Tesco is selling the chain to Yucaipa, a Los Angeles-based private equity company. Around 4,000 of Fresh & Easy's 5,000 employees will transfer to the new business. Tesco will loan the new business Â£80m and the disposal will cost Tesco Â£150m, part of which is the loan that may be repaid. Fresh & Easy, which has 200 stores across California, Nevada, and Arizona, has lost money since 2007. It is understood that 50 stores will be closed. Tesco has the option to buy a stake in the new business if it becomes profitable. In April, Tesco reported its first fall in annual profits in 20 years.

Based on the text provided, an individual experienced racial abuse, which he overcame. He considered representing France but is now aiming for a medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics. The passage also mentions a special guide on how to get into martial arts.

A study presented at the American Geophysical Union (AGU) Fall Meeting found that the ice fields in the French Alps, including Mont Blanc, decreased from approximately 375 sq km in the late 1960s/early 1970s to about 275 sq km by the late 2000s. This represents an average loss of 26% over 40 years. The research, led by Marie Gardent from the University of Savoie, assessed roughly 600 glaciers using map archives, satellite imagery, and aerial photographs, with manual inspection to ensure accuracy. The retreat is not uniform; the greatest losses have occurred in the southern sectors like the Belledonne and Ecrins massifs, which is attributed to lower elevations and different climatic conditions compared to the northern Alps. The largest French glacier, La Mer de Glace, saw its area decrease from 31.5 sq km to just over 30 sq km in the same period. These findings mirror similar glacier retreat occurring in other parts of the Alps.

The Scottish women's national football team, having won all five of their qualifiers, faces Iceland in a crucial match. A victory would all but secure their place in the finals. Player Lisa Evans expresses that missing out again after previous play-off losses would be "devastating" and "heartbreak." Iceland is also unbeaten, and the two matches between the teams will likely decide the group winner. Evans, who plays for Bayern Munich, notes that reaching the finals has been a long-term goal for the squad. She also highlights the strength of the Iceland team but believes Scotland has a good chance of winning, especially with home crowd support. The passage mentions that 12 of the 20 players in the squad play for clubs outside Scotland, which Evans believes benefits the national team by bringing different experiences and a new way of playing from competitive leagues like Germany's Bundesliga.

Stuart Campbell was arrested in the west of England on Friday following a complaint of online harassment made by a woman in south London. The alleged harassment took place over a two-year period. Mr Campbell was released on bail until mid-September. He stated the issue concerned some tweets which he insisted were not threatening and accused the media of "innuendo" to encourage "speculations". The Metropolitan Police confirmed they are investigating an allegation of online harassment.

Peta (People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals) wants to replace the Jolly Fisherman mascot of Skegness, stating it "evokes images of cruelty to animals." They have suggested a fish mascot with the slogan "Skegness - A Happy Plaice" to rebrand the resort as a progressive, animal-friendly destination. The original Jolly Fisherman poster was commissioned in 1908 by the Great Northern Railway. The mayor of Skegness, Carl Macey, said that while all suggestions are welcome, he doesn't believe there would be much support for replacing the mascot, which he described as loved, happy, and friendly.

In a rugby match, Scotland defeated Georgia. Georgia scored first with an early try by Vasil Lobzhanidze. Scotland then took a commanding lead with tries from Tommy Seymour, a penalty try, Sean Maitland, and Stuart Hogg before halftime. Hamish Watson scored another try for Scotland after the break. Lobzhanidze scored a second try for Georgia from a scrum. Hogg then scored his second try, finishing a counter-attack. Scotland's head coach, Vern Cotter, was pleased with the first half, where Scotland dominated possession and scored quickly. He noted the second half was more open and less neat due to the wet conditions.

Tries from Macgraff Leuluai, Ah Van, Chris Bridge, Lloyd White (2), and Joe Mellor secured a 38-12 victory for Widnes over Castleford. Castleford's Paddy Flynn scored a hat-trick against his parent club, with Larne Patrick and Luke Gale also scoring tries, but Widnes held on for the win. The result means Widnes moved up to seventh place, one point behind Castleford who remain in sixth.

Fawzi al-Odah, 37, was released from the US facility in Cuba after a review panel determined he was not a "continuing significant threat". He had been held since 2002 after being arrested in Pakistan on suspicion of links to al-Qaeda and the Taliban, a charge he denies. He boarded a Kuwaiti government plane and will spend at least a year at a militant rehabilitation centre in Kuwait as a condition of his release. His release brings the total number of inmates at the US naval base to 148.

The song 'PPAP' (Pen-Pineapple-Apple-Pen) is performed by DJ Piko-Taro, a fictional character played by Japanese entertainer Kazuhiko Kosaka. The song's lyrics describe fusing a pen with an apple and a pineapple. According to a tweet from the character's account, the song was created while "making this music with play."

The viral video features an addictive beat, silly lyrics, and a simple dance routine. The original YouTube video amassed over 4 million views, while a version on 9GAG's Facebook page surpassed 44 million views. The song has inspired hundreds of tributes and covers, including from Japanese stars and a heavy metal version. While widely picked up internationally and dubbed the next Psy, it had not trended significantly on Japanese social media or been covered by many mainstream Japanese news sites at the time of writing.

Anzac Day commemorates the first major battle involving Australian and New Zealand forces during World War One. Thousands attended an early morning service at Hyde Park Corner, and up to 400 people participated in a parade before a wreath-laying at the Cenotaph. A service was also held at Westminster Abbey, where the national anthems of New Zealand and Australia were sung. The first Anzac Day commemoration in the capital was in 1916. Alexander Downer, the Australian high commissioner to the UK, addressed the crowds at the dawn service and laid a wreath. The eight-month Gallipoli campaign in Turkey was one of the bloodiest of the war.

Clarkson, aged 30, has joined St Mirren and could make his debut against Alloa on Saturday. He scored nine goals for Dundee last season and has primarily been a substitute this term. Clarkson states he is fit and ready to play, having maintained his fitness with the U20s. Capped twice for Scotland in 2008 with one international goal, he has made almost 400 senior club appearances for teams including Bristol City, Brentford, and Bristol Rovers. St Mirren is currently eighth in the Championship.

A turkey firm was sold to food tycoon Ranjit Boparan. Following talks, guarantees were given that all current agreements, including the existing workers' pension scheme, would be honoured. The new owner plans to restore the business to profitability through investment, cost savings, and using spare capacity to process chicken in addition to turkey.

A new chain ferry has experienced numerous problems since its launch, including breaking down, running aground, being suspended by the Maritime and Coastguard Agency for "training issues," and causing damage to cars. In response, the council leader, Dave Stewart, announced the crossing at Cowes would be free until 2 July and that auditors would review the project. A local shopkeeper, Angie Booth, expressed concern about the survival of her business due to the loss of trade. Transport councillor Ian Ward stated that compensation for businesses was "up for discussion" and described the vessel as a "prototype" with "teething problems." He mentioned that electrical issues had been rectified, ramp extensions were authorized to prevent vehicle damage, and grounding issues were related to seamanship which had been resolved.

A House of Lords report examines the risks and opportunities for the UK fishing industry post-Brexit. While the industry, which largely supported leaving the EU, sees an opportunity to regain control over UK waters, the report warns it might be a low priority for the government as it only accounts for half a percent of GDP. The report highlights that continued access to EU markets for UK fish exports may require allowing EU boats to fish in UK waters. It also suggests retaining some elements of the EU's Common Fisheries Policy (CFP), like basing quotas on scientific advice, and notes the UK will still have international obligations to cooperate with neighbouring states. A potential complication is the possibility of four different fisheries management regimes emerging in England, Wales, Northern Ireland, and Scotland. Despite these concerns, many in the fishing industry remain optimistic about the future.

Timothy Geaney admitted to taking or permitting indecent images of children to be taken between April 2004 and February 2014. He was sentenced to a community payback order, placed on the sex offenders register, and ordered to participate in a special programme for sex offenders. Following a General Teaching Council Scotland hearing, he was found unfit to teach and removed from the professional register. The panel noted the offending occurred over a lengthy period, his conduct was "fundamentally incompatible" with being a teacher, and there was a strong likelihood of recurrence. Geaney is prohibited from applying to re-register for two years.

A fire occurred at a site in Duncan Street on 2 March, leading to several days of firefighter presence, reduced train services, and travel delays. The Environment Agency (EA) suspended Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited from accepting waste after the fire and has since decided to revoke the company's environmental permit, effective 7 August, unless an appeal is made. The company is still required to remove all waste from the site. The fire service had visited the site, run by Asset and Land Group, nine times in the last 12 months and stated the firm was "broadly compliant" with fire safety law. In February, the fire service raised concerns with the EA about the potential impact of a fire, which led to joint visits and EA enforcement action. The cause of the fire is undetermined.

Syria's Deputy Foreign Minister, Faisal al-Mekdad, stated that Syria is "doing its best" to comply with the timetable for destroying its chemical weapons, despite missing a deadline. He attributed the delay to attacks by "terrorist groups" on a shipment en route to the port of Latakia. The US has expressed concern over the delay, with only about 4% of the 1,300-tonne stockpile having left the country. Russia has set a new deadline of March 1st for the transfer.

Mr. Mekdad also denied government forces have used barrel bombs on civilians in Aleppo, despite claims from the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights and the Aleppo Media Centre that such attacks have killed hundreds. He insisted the government is defending its people from "terrorist attacks."

Additionally, Syrian state media denied reports from the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights and rebel groups that rebels had seized control of Aleppo's central prison, stating that an attack by "terrorist groups" had been thwarted.

England won the cricket match against Pakistan at Old Trafford, leveling the series. England declared on 589-8 and 173-1, securing their second-biggest run victory over Pakistan. Joe Root was named man of the match for scoring 254 and an unbeaten 71, as well as taking four catches and one wicket. Captain Alastair Cook also scored 105 and 76 not out. Pakistan's captain, Misbah-ul-Haq, expressed disappointment, citing a lack of confidence and poor shot selection as reasons for their defeat. The third Test will begin on August 3rd at Edgbaston.

Older People's Commissioner for Wales, Sarah Rochira, is conducting a review into the quality of life and care for older people in residential care in Wales. She will gather evidence from pensioners, their friends, and families to develop recommendations for care providers and public bodies. The review will examine factors like physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment. While the review aims to highlight good care, it also addresses concerns about "unacceptable variations" in care quality across Wales. Care Forum Wales supports the review's aims but expressed disappointment that the main advisory panel does not include a provider expert or anyone with direct experience of living in, working in, managing, or owning a care home.

Paul Sheerin, aged 39, has been appointed to a position at Pittodrie, replacing Neil Cooper. Sheerin, a former Dons midfielder, has been the player-manager at Arbroath since 2010. During his time there, Arbroath were relegated to Scottish League Two after the 2013-14 season, but he also led them to their first national trophy by winning the Scottish Third Division title in 2011. Aberdeen's chief executive, Duncan Fraser, stated that manager Derek McInnes selected Sheerin after a "comprehensive process". Sheerin's career includes playing for several Scottish clubs, Ãstersunds in Sweden, and winning a Scotland Under-21 cap.

Following the sacking of manager Bob Bradley, Curtis and assistant manager Paul Williams will take charge of the upcoming match against Bournemouth. Swansea aims to appoint a new manager quickly, with ex-Derby manager Paul Clement being the first choice. Curtis expressed concern about the possibility of relegation, stating it would be tough to get back into the Premier League if they go down. He believes the club has lost its "Swansea Way" since Michael Laudrup's departure in 2014, due to frequent management changes and not adequately replacing key players. Despite this, Curtis thinks the current squad is good enough to avoid relegation and reminds new players of the club's history to emphasize the importance of staying in the top flight.

Dr. Craig Venter is a biologist and entrepreneur known for turning the mapping of the human genome into a competitive race, which sped up the process but also drew criticism from the scientific community. After the human genome was published, he focused on creating a synthetic life form, an organism called Synthia, at his J Craig Venter Institute. His early life included a period of surfing before being drafted into the Vietnam War, an experience that gave him a sense of urgency and a desire to become a doctor. He excelled in research, developing faster methods for decoding genes, which led to conflict with figures like James Watson and a lack of public funding. This prompted him to establish private research institutes. In 1998, his company Celera Genomics challenged the public project to sequence the human genome, with both publishing results in 2001. Venter has also used his yacht to collect and sequence marine microbes and believes his work on synthetic life could lead to a "new industrial revolution."

According to a report by the Sutton Trust, many apprenticeships in England are low quality and too short compared to other European countries. The report, carried out by the Boston Consulting Group, states that fewer than 200,000 of the 520,000 annual apprenticeships are at level three (A-level equivalent). It highlights that only 20% of English employers offer apprenticeships, compared to 51% in Germany, and that since 2010, three-quarters of apprenticeships have been for those over 25. The report calls for a radical expansion of up to 300,000 new, high-quality apprenticeships each year, primarily at level three or higher, to boost the economy and improve job prospects for young people. The Department for Education responded that it is already reforming apprenticeships to raise standards.

The Briton, Storey, finished over two minutes ahead of Poland's Anna Harkowska in Nottwil, Switzerland. The 37-year-old expressed relief at the win and is targeting further success at the Rio de Janeiro Paralympics. Storey is Britain's most decorated female Paralympian, with 22 medals (11 gold, eight silver, three bronze) across six Paralympics in both cycling and swimming. She has won 21 world titles in both sports and began her career in the pool, winning six medals at the 1992 Paralympics before switching to cycling in 2005.

Hereford United, also known as the Bulls, have been expelled from the Football Conference due to financial issues. Their place has been taken by Chester, the team Hereford had sent down on the final day of the season. The Conference had extended a payment deadline for Hereford three times, with the final deadline being Thursday, 12 June. The club's debt to football creditors, including former manager Martin Foyle and current players, amounted to Â£148,000. Despite a recent takeover by London businessman Tommy Agombar, the club failed to meet the deadline. The club also faced debts of approximately Â£225,000 at the end of the season and still owes over Â£70,000 in taxes to HMRC. An offer from the Hereford United Supporters' Trust to buy the club for Â£1 and clear its debts was not the preferred option for chairman David Keyte. The club's financial problems have been worsened by falling attendance, which dropped to an average of 1,758 in the 2013-14 season.

The former Manchester City man, 30, won 61 caps for England after his 2009 senior debut and was a squad member at two World Cups and two European Championships. He holds the record for the most England Under-21 caps with 46. His only international goal was scored in a 5-0 victory over Moldova during the 2014 Fifa World Cup qualifiers.

Christopher Hogwood died at his home in Cambridge after an illness that lasted several months. His funeral will be private, with a memorial service to be held later. Hogwood was a conductor who founded the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973, directing it for about 30 years and recording over 200 CDs, including the first complete cycle of Mozart symphonies on period instruments. He was considered an influential figure in the early-music movement. He studied keyboard at Cambridge University and held positions as artistic director of the King's Lynn Festival and Boston's Handel and Haydn Society, as well as professorships at several universities.

A boy from Northern Ireland was removed from mainstream schooling in June because he was not coping. His family requested a place for him at a special school but were told in September that all special schools in the South Eastern Education Board area were full. The boy's mother, who had to give up her job to care for him, expressed concern that her son feels isolated. The family has now been told that an extra classroom assistant has been employed at a local special school, and they hope their son can start there in the next few weeks. The Education Authority stated it could not comment on individual cases but is currently reviewing the need for special school places in Northern Ireland, with work ongoing to assist with placements from 2016.

Newport Gwent Dragons are the subject of a takeover bid by the Welsh Rugby Union (WRU), who view Rodney Parade as a "rugby venue." Newport County has a lease to use the ground until 2023, which gives them primacy of fixtures as long as they remain in the Football League. The WRU's takeover will be voted on by Newport Rugby shareholders on Tuesday, 9 May. Newport RFC chairman Will Godfrey has stated that both Newport County and Newport Squash Club are protected under their current agreements. The WRU intends to install an artificial surface, which is against Football League rules. On the pitch, Newport County are two points clear of relegation from League Two with two games remaining.

A man who was kidnapped at 15 by RUF rebels during the civil war (which started in 1991) describes being forced to use drugs and commit atrocities. After escaping, he was jailed and met a preacher, Richard Cole, who founded a project called Lifeline Nehemiah. This project gave him a home, encouraged him to go to school, and inspired him to rebuild the nation.

When the Ebola crisis began in 2014, he and his group considered it a "common enemy." They developed a clinic and undertook three key activities:
1.  Educating over 10,000 people about the reality of Ebola in their local languages.
2.  Supporting 11,000 people with food and other items.
3.  Teaming up with other agencies to create an Ebola treatment unit that saved many lives.

The country was recently declared free of the virus, which had killed almost 4,000 people there over 18 months.

A collection of 80,000 works of art, ceramics, manuscripts, letters, and photographs from the Wedgwood Museum was at risk of being auctioned to pay off the pottery firm's pension debt. A public fundraising campaign launched in September successfully raised the necessary funds in one month. The collection will be gifted to the Victoria and Albert Museum by The Art Fund, which led the campaign, and then loaned back to the Wedgwood Museum, where it will remain on display in Barlaston, Staffordshire. The sale prevents the collection from being "sold and scattered around the globe."

Dan Groves stated that the "finer points" of a deal for Wright to buy 20% of the club are yet to be released. The Sun reported that the 30-year-old will become a club director. Billericay, who are eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, were recently taken over by Glenn Tamplin and signed former England international Paul Konchesky. Wright, a runner-up in I'm A Celebrity Get Me Out Of Here in 2011, previously played non-league football for several clubs.

Mark Carney, the Governor of the Bank of England, announced he would extend his term by one year, rather than leaving in 2018 as originally planned or staying until 2021. This decision was a surprise to many. The primary reason for the one-year extension was personal and family-related, specifically timed around his daughters' education and the family's plan to return to Canada. Carney stated that leaving in 2018 would be difficult as it would be in the middle of Britain's exit negotiations. The one-year extension allows him to see the Article 50 process through to completion. The decision was described as "entirely personal" and not influenced by political pressure or criticism of the Bank's economic forecasts.

The football match between Blackpool and Colchester United ended in a 1-1 draw. Blackpool scored first after 12 minutes when Jamille Matt turned the ball home from three yards, following a chip into the area from Nathan Delfouneso. Colchester equalised five minutes later when Kurtis Guthrie scored from close range after a corner. Both teams had chances to win, with Blackpool's Tom Aldred heading wide from eight yards and Colchester's Kurtis Guthrie heading against the bar from two yards. Colchester finished the game with 10 men after substitute Sean Murray received a straight red card for a bad tackle on Jim McAlister in injury time.

A Northern Ireland charity, Action Mental Health, has developed a programme called "Healthy Me" for P6 and P7 pupils. Its chief executive, David Babington, stated it will help prepare them for the stresses of the transfer test and the transition to secondary school.

The programme, which was piloted in five schools, consists of interactive workshops that teach children about emotional wellbeing, encourage them to seek help, and help them identify sources of support. The workshops also provide teachers with basic training.

Helen Hamilton, a P7 teacher at Carrick Primary School where the initiative was launched, said the programme has helped pupils and parents with the move to secondary school. She noted that children are taught breathing exercises and how to relax.

The chief inspector of schools, Noelle Buick, has identified strengthening the resilience of young people as a key challenge for Northern Ireland's education system.

Developers Fawley Waterside plan to turn the disused Fawley power station chimney into a major attraction, which would be the tallest south of London's Shard. The chimney is the centrepiece of a Â£1bn "merchant city" development that will also include a marina, housing, restaurants, and fast ferry links to Southampton and Portsmouth. The oil-fired power station, commissioned in 1971, closed in 2013 and the site was sold to the developers in 2016. An application for outline planning permission was due later in the year the article was written, with building potentially starting in 2018.

At the Hong Kong championships, 23-year-old Latham won Great Britain's second medal, a bronze in the men's scratch race. Poland's Adrian Teklinski won gold, and Germany's Lucass Liss took silver. This followed Elinor Barker's silver medal in the women's scratch race on Wednesday.

In other events, the GB men's team pursuit team was beaten by Italy for the bronze medal. Joe Truman was eliminated in the men's keirin semi-final, and the women's team pursuit finished fifth, failing to make the bronze-medal ride. Katy Marchant was eliminated in the first round of the women's sprint.

Kemp, who last portrayed Grant Mitchell in 2006, is set for a "brief return" to EastEnders. He agreed to come back for the final episodes of Barbara Windsor's character, Peggy Mitchell, stating he "could not turn down" the offer. Dame Barbara's character, who recently returned to the show, will be killed off from cancer in the spring. Kemp's return as Grant will reunite the Mitchell brothers, Phil and Grant, with their mother for the last time. EastEnders' executive producer, Dominic Treadwell-Collins, stated that Grant Mitchell is an "EastEnders legend" and his return will see him reunited with old loves and his brother to say goodbye to his mother.

Sadio Mane scored two goals in 138 seconds, leading to a defeat for second-placed Spurs at Anfield. Manager Pochettino stated it is "difficult to fight for the Premier League" with such a lack of desire and that his team is "not ready to fight for the Premier League" if they cannot cope with the pressure. Spurs have won only twice on the road since September 24th and have only one win in their last 17 away meetings against other top-six sides. Former player Danny Murphy noted that Spurs, who have the joint-best defensive record, were "all over the place" and suggested they should have used a back three instead of a back four.

In Nigeria's recent elections, the All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 of the 28 governor posts, marking the biggest defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since 1999. The PDP, which also lost the presidential poll last month, won eight governorships, mostly in the south-east. The APC's victory includes key northern states like Katsina and Kaduna, and the commercial hub of Lagos. However, the APC did not win in any of the five oil-producing states, which remains a concern for President-elect Muhammadu Buhari. The PDP's decline is attributed to factors including defections, allegations of corruption, and a perceived failure to end the Boko Haram insurgency. The election in Imo state was declared inconclusive, and the result for Taraba is still outstanding. Elections were not held in seven states.

Visitors to the Hebridean Celtic Festival (HebCelt) can use an app to access online information, such as videos and band interviews, from signs and posters on the site. The festival takes place in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis from 19 to 22 July and features acts including The Waterboys, Imelda May, and Lucy Spraggan. According to director Caroline Maclennan, this augmented reality experience is an extra feature for visitors and also allows people worldwide to interact with the festival. The app will be updated before and during the event, enabling users to access information, buy tickets, and experience the festival's atmosphere from anywhere.

Based on the text provided, here is a concise summary:

Two Birmingham academies, Park View and Nansen Primary, will have their funding agreements terminated after being rated inadequate by Ofsted. Two other schools, Oldknow Academy and Golden Hillock, were also rated inadequate and warned they could lose funding unless they address concerns. These concerns include ending the segregation of boys and girls, stopping less favorable treatment of non-Muslims, and ensuring a balanced curriculum.

Ofsted's chief stated that "a culture of fear and intimidation has taken grip" in some schools. One anonymous head teacher described feeling undermined by parents and isolated before the "Trojan Horse" letter became public. The Park View Educational Trust, which may be removed from running the schools, said it would challenge the Ofsted report. Parents at the schools have criticized the reports, accusing inspectors of bias.

Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe was sentenced to five years in jail for allegedly plotting to topple the government in Tehran. Her appeal is being held in secret in Tehran. She was arrested at Tehran Airport in April with her two-year-old daughter, Gabriella. Mrs Zaghari-Ratcliffe has spent time in solitary confinement, and her daughter's passport was confiscated, leaving the child in Iran with her grandparents. Her husband, Richard Ratcliffe, believes she is being used as a bargaining chip and has criticised the UK government for a lack of action. He communicates with his daughter via Skype and is trying to get a visa to visit. Amnesty International UK considers her a "prisoner of conscience".

Vincent Barker, known as Vinnie, died in July 2012, five months after a routine eye test. Eye specialist Honey Rose is on trial, denying a charge of gross negligence manslaughter. The prosecution alleges that Ms Rose failed to detect Vinnie's swollen optic discs during the test, which was caused by a build-up of fluid in his brain. They claim this failure was "criminal" and that Vinnie's death was preventable if he had been referred for further investigation.

Clive Weatherhogg, 42, was found guilty of coercing a woman to engage in sexual activity with another man, whom he found through an adult website, and filming them. He was also convicted of sending a sexually explicit clip to the victim's sister on Christmas Day and causing her sister and father to look at sexual images. Weatherhogg, who denied the charges, was placed on the sex offenders register. The case was remitted to the High Court in Edinburgh due to its greater sentencing powers.

In a T20 match in Greater Noida, Afghanistan defeated Ireland. Ireland scored 165-5, with key contributions from Stuart Thompson (56), Gary Wilson (41 no), and captain William Porterfield (39). Afghanistan reached 171-4 with two overs remaining, thanks to performances by Samiullah Shenwari (56) and Mohammad Shahzad (47). Afghan spinner Amir Hamza was the only bowler to take more than one wicket. The teams will play a second T20 at the same venue on Friday. Ireland was also set back by the loss of paceman Boyd Rankin due to a back problem, though he is expected to return for the upcoming ODIs.

Barcelona paid Â£48.6m for Santos striker Neymar, with his parents receiving Â£34m of that fee. The total cost of the player to the club, including fees, wages, and a recent tax payment, is estimated at Â£106.8m. Following accusations of misappropriating money related to the transfer, Sandro Rosell resigned as Barcelona's president, though he denies wrongdoing. A judge in Spain ruled there was sufficient evidence to continue investigations into the transfer. In response, FC Barcelona made a "complimentary tax declaration" of 13,550,830.56 euros to cover any potential interpretations of the contracts, while insisting they had not committed any offence and that their original tax payment was correct. It is not yet confirmed if the case will be dropped following this payment.

The bodies of David Miller, 24, and Hannah Witheridge, 23, were found on a beach in Koh Tao on September 15th. Two Burmese migrant workers, Zaw Lin and Win Zaw Htun, both 21, are being held by Thai police and are charged with conspiracy to murder, conspiracy to rape, and robbery. They are alleged to have confessed, though there are reports they later withdrew these confessions, which Thai police deny.

UK detectives visited Thailand to review the investigation and will now return to the UK to compile a report and update the families. The UK Foreign Office had previously expressed concerns about the Thai police investigation, specifically regarding the verification of DNA samples and allegations of the suspects' mistreatment.

Post-mortem examinations found that Mr. Miller died from drowning and a blow to the head, while Miss Witheridge died from head wounds. Thai police have stated that DNA found on Ms. Witheridge matched samples taken from the suspects.

Virtual reality (VR) is being used as a tool by journalists, teachers, healthcare workers, and retailers to help people better understand the world.

*   **Health and Awareness:** The National Autistic Society and Alzheimer's Research UK have created VR films to simulate the experience of living with autism and dementia, respectively, to foster public understanding. In healthcare, VR is used as a teaching aid, with one surgeon live-streaming an operation in VR. It is also used to treat phobias and PTSD.
*   **Retail:** Retailers like Ikea are using VR apps to allow customers to visualize products, such as a virtual kitchen where users could even interact with virtual meatballs.
*   **Education:** Google's Expeditions program takes students on virtual field trips. Other VR apps are being developed to teach language skills, like Mandarin, by immersing users in virtual conversations and locations. Proponents believe VR can make learning more engaging, though cost remains a hurdle for schools.

The "black box" from a Russian Su-24 jet was opened in Moscow in front of journalists and diplomats. According to Nikolai Primak, the head of the Russian investigation, flight information appeared to be missing. An analysis is expected next week. The jet was shot down by F-16 fighters on November 24th, an event which has plunged relations between Russia and Turkey into crisis. Turkey insists the jet was in its airspace, while Russia claims it was in Syrian airspace. Both crew members ejected; the pilot was killed by militants on the ground, and the navigator was rescued. A Russian marine involved in the rescue was also killed. In response, Russia has imposed sanctions on Turkey, including a ban on package holidays.

The Scottish women's national football team has won all five of its qualifiers and is preparing to play Iceland, who are also unbeaten. A victory would almost secure their place in next summer's finals in the Netherlands. Player Lisa Evans expressed that missing out again after previous play-off losses would be "devastating" and "heartbreak." Evans, who plays for Bayern Munich, is one of 12 players in the 20-strong squad who play for clubs outside of Scotland. She believes that having players in top leagues abroad, such as in Germany, Sweden, and the US, benefits the national team by bringing different cultures and new ways of playing.

A review for the Commission on Local Tax Reform, which was set up by the Scottish government and Cosla, found no "magic bullet" to fix the current system. The review, conducted by Prof Kenneth Gibb, noted that the council tax has had problems "from day one" and a failure to modify it has created more difficulties.

Prof Gibb's review of global tax systems found:
*   A tax on property is common in OECD countries and is considered a "good tax" by academics because it is stable and hard to avoid. However, it can be seen as unfair as it isn't linked to current income and causes confusion over whether it's a wealth tax or a service charge.
*   A local income tax is often seen as fairer but creates fluctuating income for local authorities and offers little opportunity to vary rates for local priorities.

The commission will hold a public consultation before reporting back in the autumn. A Scottish government spokesman stated that ministers consider the current council tax system "unfair" and await the commission's report on fairer alternatives.

Following the online posting of stolen celebrity photos from iCloud, Apple has implemented a two-step verification system for its back-up service. This security measure, which remains an opt-in choice, requires users to enter a four-digit code sent to a trusted device when logging in from a new device. This action is intended to block third-party software, like Elcomsoft's Phone Password Breaker, which was previously able to bypass security and download complete data back-ups. The owner of Elcomsoft confirmed that Apple's changes guard against his software's technique. Additionally, Apple now sends an email notification whenever a back-up starts downloading. Some experts suggest this two-factor authentication should be the default setting, not just for Apple but for other major tech companies as well. Apple's CEO has stated the company plans to more aggressively encourage users to enable this feature.

During the campaign period from 23 January to 22 May, the Conservatives were the highest spenders at Â£2,980,815, followed by UKIP, which won the election, at Â£2,956,737. The Liberal Democrats spent Â£1,580,575, Labour spent Â£1,027,339, the Green Party spent Â£534,249, and the SNP spent Â£267,372. The total spending for these six parties was Â£9,347,087. The cost per vote was 79p for the Conservatives, 68p for UKIP, Â£1.45 for the Lib Dems, 26p for Labour, and 43p for the Green Party. All parties except Labour spent more than they did in the 2009 European election campaign.

Centre-back Anderson, 27, has left Barrow by mutual consent to join a National League rival and could play against his former club on 18 February. Striker Ruairi Keating, 21, has also joined the club, with the move being subject to international clearance. Manager Kevin Nicholson described Anderson as a "leader-type" and Keating as "young" and "incredibly hungry." The Gulls are currently four points above the relegation zone.

Many Clouds, a 10-year-old Irish-bred horse, collapsed and died after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day. The British Horseracing Authority (BHA) confirmed the cause of death was a "severe pulmonary haemorrhage," which an acting chief veterinary officer for the BHA described as a rare occurrence. The horse had previously shown symptoms of post-race ataxia, where he would "over-heat" and "wobble," but he had never collapsed before and showed no such symptoms on the day he died. Many Clouds had previously won the Gold Cup trial in 2015 and the Hennessy Gold Cup in 2014.

Presiding Officer Tricia Marwick became emotional during the farewell speeches of veteran Labour MSP Duncan McNeil and former First Minister Alex Salmond, who are both standing down. Mr Salmond stated his belief that Scotland is "not divided, but diverse" and that there is a broad consensus for the parliament to have greater responsibility. He also joked about the Cheltenham racecourse and wished election candidates luck "with varying degrees of enthusiasm". Mr McNeil, in his final speech, warned that Holyrood needs to learn from Westminster, particularly regarding its committee system, to ensure accountability and scrutiny. Former Scottish Conservative MSP Annabel Goldie is also standing down.

The film, set for release in US cinemas on March 17, 2017, has cast an Oscar-winner as Mrs. Potts and Kevin Kline as Maurice, Belle's father. Emma Watson will star as Belle, Dan Stevens as the Beast, Luke Evans as Gaston, and Josh Gad as LeFou. The movie, directed by Bill Condon, will begin filming at Shepperton Studios in May.

The Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) is set to reveal its intentions regarding the 1989 Hillsborough stadium disaster, where 96 football fans were fatally injured. The announcement will be made at a private meeting in Warrington with the victims' relatives at 11:00 BST. This follows new inquests last year which concluded the fans were unlawfully killed. In January, evidence files concerning 23 suspects were sent to the CPS. Fifteen of these suspects relate to the investigation into the disaster's causes, while the other eight relate to a probe into the conduct of South Yorkshire Police and West Midlands Police afterwards. Margaret Aspinall, whose son died in the disaster, stated that the families want accountability.

Chelmsford Prison has experienced "numerous incidents" of packages being thrown over its wall. A former inmate described the jail as "flooded" with mobile phones and synthetic cannabis, claiming drones were used, though the Ministry of Justice (MoJ) stated there was no evidence of drones at the Chelmsford site. A local resident witnessed packages being thrown over four times in two weeks. The MoJ acknowledged that more must be done to stop contraband and noted that new laws mean smugglers could face up to two years in jail.

Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old lollipop lady, suffered serious head injuries after being struck by a car outside Bedford Road Lower School in Kempston last December. The driver, Brian Wright, 55, told Luton Crown Court he was blinded by the setting sun. He accepts he hit Mrs Blackburn but denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving. The court heard that Mr Wright's VW Golf failed to stop for a red light as Mrs Blackburn, who had been a lollipop lady for 20 years, was escorting a woman and child across the road. Mr Wright stated he could not remember the light's color due to the sun and expressed his sorrow for the incident. Mrs Blackburn is now in residential care, and the trial is ongoing.

Laura Muir will not compete in the Commonwealth Games on Australia's Gold Coast next year due to her veterinary medicine studies. Her final exams are in May, while the games are in April. Muir, who recently finished fourth in the 1500m and sixth in the 5,000m at the World Athletics Championships, is "gutted" to miss the event but prioritizes completing her degree. She set a new outdoor personal best in the 5,000m with a time of 14 minutes 52.07 seconds. Despite her busy study schedule, she says the World Indoor Championships in March are "potentially a target."

Trevor Deely, 22, was last seen in December 2000 walking home from a Christmas party. A search involving excavations has begun at a three-acre site in Chapelizod, Dublin, and is expected to take weeks. A review of his disappearance led to enhanced CCTV footage from the night he went missing. The footage shows Mr. Deely talking to a man in black outside his workplace on Baggot Street, believed to be when he returned for an umbrella. This same man was later seen on CCTV following Mr. Deely. GardaÃ­ have appealed for this unidentified man to come forward.

Juan Martin Del Potro, ranked 165th after over two years of injury problems, defeated the Swiss player Wawrinka with a score of 3-6 6-3 7-6 (7-2) 6-3. This is Del Potro's first Grand Slam since the 2014 Australian Open, following three wrist operations. He will next play either Lucas Pouille or Donald Young and is in the same half of the draw as Andy Murray.

Other results from the same half of the draw include:
*   Nick Kyrgios defeated Dustin Brown 6-7 (3-7) 6-1 2-6 6-4 6-4 and will face Feliciano Lopez next.
*   Feliciano Lopez beat Fabio Fognini 3-6 6-7 6-3 6-3 6-3.
*   Tomas Berdych won against Benjamin Becker 6-4 6-1 6-2.
*   Jo-Wilfried Tsonga triumphed over Juan Monaco 6-1 6-4 6-3.

Tunisia faced expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations after complaining to the Confederation of African Football (Caf) about a controversial penalty in their 2015 quarter-final loss to Equatorial Guinea. After a meeting between the Tunisian federation and Caf president Issa Hayatou, Tunisia apologised and their participation was confirmed.

Morocco was also able to enter the 2017 qualifying draw after the Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas) overturned a ban. The ban was imposed after Morocco refused to host the 2015 tournament due to fears over the Ebola virus. Cas also reduced their fine from $1m to $50,000.

For the 2017 qualifiers, Tunisia will be in Group A with Togo, Liberia, and Djibouti, while Morocco is in Group F with Cape Verde, Libya, and Sao Tome.

The McLaren team, despite its history of 182 grand prix wins, 12 drivers' world championships, and eight constructors' titles, is currently in a slump. Their current goals are modest, aiming for the third or fourth row of the grid and some points. The team's problems began in 2013 with chassis design issues, but now the primary issue lies with the Honda power-unit.

This is a stark contrast to their past successes, particularly the dominant era with Honda in 1988 when drivers Ayrton Senna and Alain Prost won 15 of 16 races. The team's last constructors' title was in 1998. McLaren's history is cyclical, with periods of triumph and decline. After their first titles in 1974 and 1976, the team slipped until Ron Dennis took control, leading them to domination in 1984-5 and through the Honda and Mercedes partnerships.

Despite having two world champions, including Fernando Alonso, the team's recent return to a partnership with Honda has not yet brought success. Dennis, who returned to control the team after the 2013 season, insists that McLaren will be the team to break Mercedes' current dominance and that success is only a matter of time. The team believes their car is among the best and that Honda's engine will improve, but for now, this belief is all they have.

Paramedics were called to a sudden death at Joe's Bar in Dungiven on 6 October 2014. Police found people still at the bar, and till receipts showed alcohol was served as late as 04:49 BST. License holder Colleen O'Neill was charged with two counts of allowing liquor consumption outside licensing hours, and James Thomas faced one count of the same charge. The judge ordered the bar to close for three months, fined Ms O'Neill Â£3,000, and fined Mr Thomas Â£1,000. The judge noted Ms O'Neill had "an appalling record" and that the licensing laws in Dungiven "were not strictly adhered to".

Stephen Curry broke his own NBA record for most 3-pointers in a season, scoring 45 points in the Golden State Warriors' 116-105 victory over the Portland Trail Blazers. Curry hit eight 3-pointers, surpassing his previous record of 272. Klay Thompson added 26 points for the Warriors. For the Trail Blazers, LaMarcus Aldridge had 27 points and Damian Lillard scored 20.

In another game, the Chicago Bulls defeated the Miami Heat 89-78. Pau Gasol contributed 16 points and 15 rebounds for the Bulls, while Hassan Whiteside had 19 points and 16 rebounds for the Heat.

Liverpool players Mario Balotelli, Fabio Borini, Rickie Lambert, and Lazar Markovic were led to believe they were giving a free-kick masterclass to a competition winner at Melwood. The "winner" was actually YouTube star and free-kick specialist Bas van Velzen. After initially pretending he wasn't very good, van Velzen showcased his skills, surprising the players. Van Velzen stated that the experience was amazing and that he enjoyed seeing the players' faces when he revealed his talent.

A study found that women diagnosed with breast cancer who carry the BRCA1 gene mutation can reduce their risk of dying from the disease by over 60% if they have their ovaries removed (an oophorectomy). This procedure was associated with a 62% drop in breast cancer deaths for women with a BRCA1 mutation, but not for those with a BRCA2 mutation. The study, which analyzed 676 breast cancer patients with one of the mutated genes, also found a 65% reduction in death from all causes associated with oophorectomy. The protective effect was apparent immediately after diagnosis and lasted for 15 years. For BRCA1 carriers who had the surgery within two years of diagnosis, the reduction in death was 73%. The journal editor stated the results were compelling and that oophorectomy should be part of the treatment discussion for BRCA mutation carriers with early-stage breast cancer.

On Easter Sunday in Durham, North Carolina, a married couple, Derek Lowe, 38, and Tina Lowe, 33, were struck and killed by an Amtrak train. The incident occurred shortly before 10 am on property owned by Norfolk-Southern. The train, the Carolinian, was traveling from Charlotte to New York City with 166 passengers, none of whom were injured. The train was delayed for about two hours and 45 minutes before continuing its route. A man who knew the couple stated they may have lived in a homeless camp.

Carlos Toro, a 66-year-old former mid-level member of the Medellin cartel, worked as an undercover informant for the DEA for 27 years. He was promised US citizenship in exchange for his work, but he was never paid. His work as an informant helped in the prosecution of figures like Carlos Lehder Rivas and Manuel Noriega. Now retired due to declining health, Toro is living in the US illegally as his last temporary visa expired on January 1. The DEA has refused to help with his citizenship after he went public with his situation. Toro fears he will be killed if deported to Colombia.

The US internet address regulator, ICANN, is investigating a Canadian company, Vox Populi Registry Ltd., for its use of the new '.sucks' domain name. The company is accused of extracting large sums of money from celebrities like Kevin Spacey and major companies such as YouTube, Bing, and Visa, who are purchasing their respective '.sucks' domains to protect their reputations. ICANN has contacted the U.S. Federal Trade Commission and Canada's Office of Consumer Affairs to determine if Vox Populi's actions, which have been called a "shakedown scheme," are illegal. While Vox Populi's CEO maintains their business is lawful, ICANN could declare the company in breach of its contract if regulators find its actions illegal.

A baby boy's body was found in a village pond in 1988. The case remained unsolved for 27 years until police exhumed the body and used DNA to trace the mother. The woman was arrested on suspicion of infanticide but explained that the baby had been stillborn and she had concealed the pregnancy. Police ruled out foul play, and the charge was dropped. The baby, who was named Peter by villagers, has been reburied. The mother remains on bail while the Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) decides whether to charge her with failing to register a birth and preventing a lawful burial.

A taxi driver, Michael Young, has been ordered to pay compensation to a passenger, Kristopher Hicks, who suffered severe brain injuries after jumping from the moving taxi five years ago. Mr. Young mistakenly believed Mr. Hicks was going to avoid paying the fare and decided to drive him back to the taxi rank. Mr. Hicks jumped from the vehicle while it was travelling at over 20mph, resulting in devastating brain injuries, epilepsy, and the need for round-the-clock care. A High Court judge ruled that the driver had unlawfully imprisoned Mr. Hicks, entitling him to damages. The compensation amount is yet to be decided but is expected to be around 50 per cent of what the family requested, plus Â£250 for unlawful imprisonment.

On Wednesday night, tornado sirens were activated in Kansas due to several storms, with a reported tornado near Goddard, west of Wichita. Other tornado sightings occurred in southwestern Kansas near Aetna. The storms also affected Missouri, where a possible tornado touched down in Potosi, causing wind damage, flooding, and reports of baseball-sized hail in Farmington. More storms are predicted for Thursday in the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and near the southern Great Lakes.

Luke Rockhold is preparing for his middleweight fight against Lyoto Machida in New Jersey. Rockhold, seeking his fourth consecutive victory and a title shot, plans to be "the bull" by coming forward, cutting Machida off, and dominating the fight. He believes he is a true mixed martial artist with advantages in takedowns, kicks, and punches, and that Machida has a "very small avenue to win this fight on the feet." While Rockhold respects Machida's style and career, he is confident he will dominate. Machida is also confident, stating that if he applies his style and strategy, he can stop Rockhold and win. He believes the winner of the fight deserves a title shot and feels well-prepared after an eight-week training camp.

A light general aviation aircraft, an Aerostar plane, landed on its belly at the Aero Acres residential airpark in Fort Pierce, Florida, without its landing gear deployed.
*   **What was the immediate result?** The plane skidded along the runway, causing its propellers to hit the ground.
*   **What did the pilot do next?** The pilot, Chris Georgaklis, 85, re-engaged the engines and took off again.
*   **What happened after the take-off?** Despite the damaged propellers, the pilot flew 100 miles to Fort Lauderdale and landed safely. He was accompanied by his dog, Buddy.
*   **What is the status of the incident?** The FAA is investigating the incident. The most common cause for such a "gear-up landing" is human error.

Manuel Pellegrini has expressed his disappointment with Yaya Toure's performance this season, a sentiment he says the player shares. Despite this, Pellegrini has pledged to support the midfielder until the end of the season. The passage reveals that Manchester City will consider offers for Toure as they plan to overhaul their squad. Goalkeeper Joe Hart stated that the players, including himself, have been disappointed in their own performances and have let the manager down, though he affirmed that Pellegrini still has the team's support. The article also mentions that Manchester City is interested in West Ham's Aaron Cresswell, but West Ham manager Sam Allardyce has cautioned Cresswell against a move, citing other English players who struggled for playing time after joining City.

Domenico Rancadore, a Sicilian mafia fugitive known as the "godfather of Uxbridge," will be allowed to remain in the UK after his seven-year Italian prison sentence was dropped. Rancadore, who has lived in Britain for over 20 years, was convicted in absentia in Italy in 1999 for being a member of the Cosa Nostra. Although he lost an extradition battle in February, his sentence expired in October 2014 under an Italian law stating a sentence is extinguished if a period more than double the penalty has passed. Consequently, the European arrest warrant for him is to be withdrawn. Rancadore was first arrested in London in 2013, having lived under the name Marc Skinner. The case has drawn criticism from legal experts over the time and money spent on the extradition proceedings.

Mr Mole, ridden by AP McCoy, is one of three 7-2 co-favourites for the seven-runner Grade One Celebration Chase at Sandown on Saturday. This will be McCoy's final ride in a Grade One race. The other co-favourites are Special Tiara and Sprinter Sacre. McCoy's full book of rides for his last day as a professional jockey will be confirmed on Friday morning. It was after winning on Mr Mole in February that McCoy announced his intention to retire.

Virginia Trimble Ritter, the mother of a girl named Marcia who was murdered 40 years ago, recently saw the crime scene photos of her daughter's body for the first time. Marcia was raped and choked to death by Jerome Sydney Barrett in 1975. Her body was found 33 days after she disappeared. For decades, Ritter had followed her late husband's advice not to see the photos, but last year she asked the lead police investigator to show them to her. After seeing the photos, she expressed a desire for revenge. Barrett was convicted of second-degree murder in 2009, 33 years after the crime, after a DNA match linked him to the case. He was sentenced to 44 years in prison.

Rory McIlroy believes it is "unthinkable" that he will not win the Masters at some point in his career to complete the career grand slam. He is aiming to become the sixth player to win all four major titles. McIlroy considers his final-round collapse at Augusta in 2011 to be the most important day of his career, as he learned a great deal from it, which helped him win his first major title two months later. Despite having only one top-10 finish in six Masters appearances, he feels Augusta is a course he can win on multiple times. He also mentioned that the golf course serves as his "sanctuary" from pressure and hype.

This week's trending stories included a quadruple rainbow in the New York area, China's crackdown on hiring exotic dancers for wakes, and an agitated RDJ during an interview about his private life. A new trend, the #kyliejennerchallenge, involves lip plumping by sucking on a jar to look like Kylie Jenner. Other trending topics were a 102-year-old woman named Alice Barker going back in time with filmmakers, a controversial prom-posal referencing bombs, Ewan McGregor being cast as Lumiere in "Beauty and the Beast," and Johnny Depp's appearance in the "Black Mass" trailer. A pregnancy announcement referencing "The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air" and a military dad photobombing his son also trended.

According to data from the official health and social care information centre, 272 children were hospitalized in England over the past 12 months due to foetal alcohol syndrome caused by alcohol exposure in the womb. Experts warn the actual number could be much higher, with World Health Organisation research suggesting one in 100 babies in the UK could be affected, equating to about 7,500 annually. The passage highlights the case of a 15-year-old with the syndrome who needs help with daily tasks and will never live independently. Other medical issues linked to alcohol consumption during pregnancy include problems with the liver, kidneys, and heart, as well as cerebral palsy, sight loss, and epilepsy. The government advises pregnant women not to drink, with a recommended maximum of up to two units no more than twice a week if they do choose to drink. However, Elizabeth Mitchell of the national organisation for foetal alchol syndrome believes the guidance should advise against any alcohol consumption during pregnancy.

Shaun Andrew McKerry, a 31-year-old ex-juvenile offender, attempted to rob the Shildon Post Office and Stores with an axe on March 15. The store owner, Sab Dhillon, tackled him to the floor. As they wrestled, Mr. Dhillon's wife, Sam, hit McKerry twice with a baseball bat, disarming him. The police arrived and arrested McKerry, who later pleaded guilty to attempted robbery and was jailed for six years. McKerry, also known as "boomerang boy" or "homing pigeon boy," had a history of crime, including 80 arrests by the age of 15.

Four Royal Navy sailors have been charged with the gang rape of a young woman at a Canadian barracks. The men, identified as Joshua Finbow, 23, Craig Stoner, 24, Simon Radford, 31, and Darren Smalley, 35, were in Canada for an ice hockey tournament. They have been granted bail under the conditions that they remain in Nova Scotia, surrender their passports, and live at the Stadacona naval base. As part of a deal with the British government, they will continue to be employed by the Royal Navy. The alleged sexual assault took place on April 10 after a hockey game. The four are charged with sexual assault causing bodily harm and group sexual assault, which carry a potential sentence of up to 14 years in prison. They are due back in court on May 27.

Valerie Jackson's four-year-old son, RJ, is one of only 70 people in the world with Netherton's syndrome, a rare congenital skin disease that makes his skin appear red, scaly, and as if it's scalded. Due to his appearance, a stranger reported Mrs. Jackson for child abuse, leading to her being surrounded by armed police while shopping. The family faces frequent public ignorance, cruel taunts, and has even been denied entry to a playhouse. RJ requires constant care, including being covered in creams multiple times a day to ease his painful symptoms. Netherton's syndrome has no cure, but symptoms can improve over time.

A controversial Protein World advert asking "are you beach body ready?" is being taken down from the London Underground. Transport for London (TfL) stated the removal is because the three-week advertising period the company paid for has ended.

The campaign, featuring a bikini-clad model, sparked a significant backlash, including a Change.org petition with over 50,000 signatures, more than 200 complaints to the Advertising Standards Authority (ASA), and posters being defaced. Critics argued the advert promoted an unhealthy body image and was sexist.

Protein World defended its campaign, engaging with critics on social media and stating the ad was targeted at health-conscious individuals. The company's head of global marketing, Richard Staveley, revealed they had received a bomb threat which was reported to the police. Despite the controversy, he called it a "fantastic campaign" and said they would not change their advertising methods.

Rail firms are planning fare increases of up to 87 per cent just ten days after the general election, despite pledges from the main political parties to freeze prices. The Prime Minister, David Cameron, has written to First Great Western (FGW) asking them to "urgently review" their decision to almost double some fares on the London to Cotswolds route, which passes through his constituency. An off-peak return from Charlbury to London could rise from Â£33.30 to Â£62.40. FGW stated the change is to bring the route in line with other services and that cheaper advanced single tickets are available. Other companies, including London Midlands and Virgin, are also introducing sharp price hikes on various routes.

John Young, a 66-year-old former soldier, was blinded in his left eye after being hit by a brick thrown by thugs at his home in Oldham. The incident occurred when Mr. Young and his wife, Elaine, were at home writing thank you cards for their wedding gifts. After the attackers threw stones and a brick at their window, Mr. Young opened his front door to confront them and was struck in the face by another brick. Despite emergency surgery, doctors could not save his eyesight. Police are investigating the attack, which they believe may have had no motive other than "yobs 'messing around'". The couple, who had been married for just three weeks, now plan to move as they no longer feel safe in their home.

Derbyshire wicketkeeper Tom Poynton, 25, has signed a one-year contract extension, committing him to the county until the end of the 2016 season. This follows his successful return from leg injuries sustained in a road accident in April 2014, which caused him to miss the entire 2014 campaign and in which his father died. After undergoing an ankle operation, the former England under-19 international made his playing comeback during the pre-season tour of Abu Dhabi and will be available for the start of the season.

A five-year-old boy named Harley Renshaw, who was diagnosed with an aggressive form of cancer called neuroblastoma in his kidney, neck, lungs, and bones, has been given the all-clear by doctors. To help him through his radiotherapy treatment, Harley decorated the protective mask that held him still to look like a Ninja Turtle, which helped him feel stronger and brave. His story gained widespread attention, and he received presents from the children's TV channel Nickelodeon. After 80 days of intensive chemotherapy, surgery, a stem cell transplant, and radiotherapy, Harley is now cancer-free and has become the face of Cancer Research UK's Kids & Teens campaign.

According to Tim Sherwood, Jack Grealish, a 19-year-old Aston Villa player, must focus on his club career before deciding on his international future. Grealish, who impressed in the FA Cup semi-final against Liverpool, is at the center of a "tug of war" between the Republic of Ireland and England. Sherwood believes Grealish needs to continue establishing himself in the Villa first team, stating that the international decision is "purely up to him" and he should "go with your heart." Grealish's father, Kevin, agrees with Sherwood's advice that his son should concentrate on his club football first. Grealish is expected to make his choice between the two countries at the end of the season.

Landing fees for private jets can vary dramatically between airports, with some surprising hubs charging the highest fees. The private jet industry is a growing trend, worth trillions in the US and Europe, with the busiest times occurring during major sporting events like the Super Bowl and the Monaco Grand Prix. A list compiled by the website The Richest, based on a 767-400 aircraft, reveals that the three most expensive airports for landing fees are in Japan: Haneda Airport in Tokyo (Â£4,559), Narita International Airport in Tokyo (Â£3,728), and Kansai International Airport in Osaka (Â£3,594). Other airports in the top ten include Toronto Pearson, Darwin International, Bristol, ChÅ«bu Centrair International, Dublin, La Guardia, and Salzburg.
