A video shows Cooper the Labrador eating an ice cream cone from McDonald's in one bite, while his companion, Daisy, a small female pup, takes a few licks. The video, which has been watched over seven million times, was filmed by their owner, Katie Gallegos. Gallegos, who runs a dog resort, says Cooper always eats quickly, so she ensures Daisy gets her share first. While some viewers criticized her for feeding the dogs ice cream, Gallegos insists it is a weekly treat and that Cooper is in "amazing health." Another video shows the dogs getting a "pup-uccino" from Starbucks, which Gallegos clarifies is just whipped cream in a cup.

Gary Locke has been appointed as the permanent manager of Kilmarnock, signing a three-year contract. Previously the interim manager and assistant boss, Locke took control in February after Allan Johnston quit. He has lost only one of his seven games in charge.

A Florida mother, Jessica Kemp, has accused Seminole County Elementary of threatening to suspend her five-year-old autistic son, Logan. The school stated that the doTERRA essential oils he wears, with scents like lavender, chamomile, and sandalwood, are a distraction to other students. Kemp applies the oils to her son's head and neck to help keep him calm and focused. After a teacher's aide complained, Kemp received a letter from the school board stating the oils were a "problem." Despite the threat, Kemp intends to continue using the oils. The Lake County School District later informed a local station that they would not suspend Logan, classifying it as a "health issue."

A fire destroyed a 90-condo, beach-side apartment complex in Westhampton Beach on Wednesday at 3 pm. The blaze was so intense that smoke could be seen from three miles away, and it melted the paint off nearby buildings. Twelve fire crews were deployed but could not get inside the building, which eventually collapsed. The cause of the fire is unknown, but authorities are investigating claims it started near a parked car. The Sandpiper complex is used as a holiday home between May and November. The building manager, who lived and worked there, lost everything.

The Queen, aged 88, was seen riding her black Fell pony, Carltonlima Emma, in Windsor Great Park. She does not wear a helmet, preferring a silk scarf, reportedly due to her hair. The Queen has loved horses since she was four, when she received a Shetland pony named Peggy. Despite a knee injury reducing her riding time, she remains an enthusiastic equestrienne and breeds several types of horses and ponies, including Fell ponies at her Hampton Court stud and Highland ponies at Balmoral. Fell ponies, like the one she was riding, are an ancient breed from Cumbria, historically used as pack animals and for transporting materials, and became popular as riding ponies in the 1950s.

A noise-related argument between two Brisbane neighbours resulted in the death of one man, Leon Yeaman, 55, and a manslaughter charge for the other, Phillip Pama, 28. The incident occurred on a Thursday night when Mr. Yeaman was reportedly making a lot of noise in his yard. Mr. Pama, a shift worker who was sleeping at the time, confronted Mr. Yeaman. During the confrontation, Mr. Pama allegedly killed Mr. Yeaman with a single punch. Paramedics were unable to revive Mr. Yeaman, who was pronounced dead at the scene. Mr. Pama has been granted conditional bail and is due back in court on May 18.
DID NOT RECIEVE A STRING TYPE FROM OUTPUT

Chelsea football manager Jose Mourinho, aged 52, has revealed that he talks to God every day but never about football. He also does not discuss the game with his wife, as he tries to separate his professional and family life. Mourinho, a father-of-two, says he and his family have worked with the World Food Programme as ambassadors against hunger. He states that he has a strong faith, prays daily, and goes to church when he feels the need, always doing so when in Portugal. He only prays for his personal life, not for Chelsea. Despite his professional persona, he believes he is a good person, a good family man, and a good friend.

On the April 1st edition of "The Price is Right," Bob Barker, the show's host for 35 years, returned for the first time in eight years. The 91-year-old hosted the first game, "Lucky Seven," before turning the duties over to the current host, Drew Carey.

An off-duty Secret Service agent, Arthur Baldwin, was arrested in Washington D.C. at 12:30 am on Friday. He was charged with attempted burglary and destruction of property after allegedly trying to break into a house. Following the arrest, the Secret Service revoked Baldwin's security clearance and placed him on leave. Baldwin was assigned to the foreign missions branch of the service. His arrest is noted as one of several recent incidents involving the agency, including an investigation into a high-ranking supervisor for misconduct and a separate investigation into two officials who drove into a secure area at the White House.

Freelance photographer Atif Saeed, 38, from Lahore, Pakistan, got out of his car at the city's safari park to photograph a male lion. He crept to within 10 feet of the lion, armed only with a camera, and took a few frames. The clicking of the shutter alerted the lion, which jumped aggressively towards him. Mr. Saeed managed to retreat to the safety of his car. He stated that he was trying to capture the "character and status" of the lion and that it was a "pretty close encounter."

New York City police are seeking to identify a woman, believed to be between 25 and 45 years old, who was found dead on a Brooklyn street on March 22. She had no identification but has a distinctive tattoo on her right leg of a heart with a rose and a ribbon with the name 'Monique'. Police have released an image of the tattoo and are asking anyone with information to contact NYPD Crime Stoppers. The cause of death is pending a medical examiner's report.

After returning to New Zealand from the UK, a couple named Hannah and Alex built a home on the back of a 1986 Hino flatbed truck because they could not afford to buy property. The project took a year and a half and cost about $25,000. The resulting two-bedroom home is made of wood and steel, is mostly solar-powered, and uses water from a nearby spring, allowing the couple to live nearly self-sufficiently in Nelson, New Zealand. The home also features a wood-fired stove and stained glass windows.

According to research by Courtney Blackwell at Northwestern University, kindergarten children who shared iPads in class over an academic year scored significantly higher in early literacy tests than their peers. The study involved 352 students, and those who shared iPads scored about 30 points higher than both students who had their own device and those who had no iPads. Blackwell suggests that it is the "collaborative learning around the technology" that makes the difference. She is due to present her findings at the 65th annual conference of the International Communication Association in Puerto Rico.

A piglet born without its back legs has become an internet sensation after a video showed it learning to walk on its two front trotters. The piglet, nicknamed 'super pig', belongs to a farmer named Ms. Duan in Qionglai city, Sichuan province, China. Despite its unsteadiness, it manages to balance, forage for food, and mix with its four-legged siblings. Villagers have flocked to see the animal. This is not the first two-legged animal to gain attention in China; a rabbit at Liuzhou zoo also became a star for walking on its front paws.

During the IndyCar Grand Prix of Louisiana on Sunday, Todd Phillips, a pit crew member for Dayle Coyne Racing, was injured. He was struck by the car of Francesco Dracone, who spun while exiting his pit box on lap 25. Phillips received stitches for a cut on his leg at the infield care center and was released. Dracone did not finish the race, placing 23rd. Many cars struggled with traction due to rain before the race.

CCTV footage shows Milton Vieira Severiano, 32, smashing his wife Cicera Alves de Sena's head into concrete paving 11 times, punching her, and then shooting her in the face five times. Severiano confessed he was jealous of men looking at his wife, who was a 29-year-old dancer with the stage name Amanda Bueno and belonged to a dance troop called Jaula das Gostozuedas. A neighbour heard Severiano yelling at her, calling her a "slut" just four days after they were married. After the murder, Severiano stole a car but was caught by police after crashing it. In the car, police found four handguns, a shotgun, and a bulletproof vest. He faces life in jail.

Journalist and author Sarah Wilson, 41, revealed in a candid interview that she came close to taking her own life due to a personal battle with mental illness. She explained that anxiety, combined with stress, her thyroid disease, distant family, and feelings of isolation, drove her to a point where she "couldn't see the point of continuing." Wilson, who now accepts she is an "anxious person," believes depression and anxiety are intrinsically linked and that anxiety is becoming the "new depression." She advocates for acknowledging this link to better tackle the rising rates of stress and anxiety among Australian women. According to Beyond Blue, one in three Australian women will experience anxiety in their lifetime.

Elena Curtin, a 23-year-old pregnant woman from Portland, Oregon, will no longer face prosecution for second-degree assault. The charge stemmed from a November 2014 incident where she came home to find her boyfriend's ex-girlfriend using heroin in her bathroom. When the woman refused to leave, Curtin struck her in the head and arm with a crowbar. Prosecutors dropped the charge, stating Curtin was "completely justified in her outrage," and Oregon law permits physical force against an intruder who refuses to leave a residence. If convicted, Curtin would have faced a mandatory prison sentence of almost six years.

Gemma, a pit bull in California, was being fed treats by her owner when a broccoli spear was thrown into the mix as a trick. Gemma pulled a look of disgust, chomped on the vegetable, and then spit it out on the floor. Other videos show Gemma sleeping and hanging out with her human family, which includes two children.

A link on HSBC's official website directed visitors to a pornographic page. The link was for the bank's young entrepreneur awards, which were scrapped in 2011. After the awards ended, the organisers allowed the registration for the address on hsbc.com.hk to retire, and a porn site took over the address. HSBC has since removed the hyperlink, apologised to the public, and denied any association with the external site, insisting its website remained secure.

A 13-year-old Maryland boy named Marcus called 911 after a fire broke out on the first floor of his home in Clinton on Sunday morning, trapping him and his nine-year-old sister, Aaliyah, in a second-floor bedroom. During the 11-minute call, Marcus remained calm, provided instructions to firefighters, and soothed his sister. Firefighters entered the room by going through the home and breaking a window. The siblings were rescued and taken to a children's hospital with non-life-threatening injuries. Three other family members escaped on their own and were taken to Medstar hospital.

Blue fluorescent algae, caused by millions of light-emitting plankton, has been photographed lighting up Australia's east coast, specifically in Jervis Bay, NSW. An oceanography expert, Iain Suthers, explained that the glow is caused by a single-celled phytoplankton called *Noctiluca scintillans*, which blossoms in spring and autumn. This luminous glow is a defense mechanism. A similar event occurred at Manly Beach in August 2014.

New genetic tests, such as EndoPredict, can analyze a patient's tumour after surgery to determine its aggressiveness and the risk of the cancer returning. This allows some women to be accurately told their risk is as low as five per cent, potentially sparing them from undergoing chemotherapy. While most of these tests are currently available privately at a cost of about Â£2,500, experts believe they could be cost-effective for the NHS by saving on chemotherapy expenses. The tests enable patients to make a more informed choice about their treatment.

Based on the text provided, over 25 women have been airlifted from Royal Navy ships due to pregnancy. One ship, HMS Ocean, had five such emergency evacuations over nine years. Eighteen other ships, including HMS Dragon and HMS Enterprise, also had emergency evacuations. A Ministry of Defence spokesman noted a strict "no touching" rule at sea, suggesting the women conceived before boarding or during leave.

Additionally, 99 female British soldiers were sent home from Afghanistan between January 2006 and December 2013 after discovering they were pregnant, and 102 women were evacuated from Iraq for the same reason. Strict military rules prohibit mothers-to-be from serving in war zones.

A drone carrying traces of radioactive material, believed to be cesium, was found on the rooftop of the Japanese Prime Minister's residence. The drone, which was 50 centimeters wide, also had a small camera, smoke flares, and a plastic bottle. The amount of radioactive material was not immediately harmful to humans. This discovery has raised concerns in Japan about the potential for terrorism involving drones, especially with the upcoming Olympics and G7 summit. The incident occurred on the same day a court approved the restart of two reactors at the Sendai nuclear power plant. Currently, Japanese law does not restrict drone flights over most of Tokyo, including the Prime Minister's residence.

Lu Xincai, a security guard in Zhejiang province, China, takes his 84-year-old mother, who has Alzheimer's, to work with him every day on his motorbike. He ties a sash around both of them to ensure she doesn't fall off during the four-kilometre journey, which takes an hour. He started doing this after his father passed away, as his wife works in another city and his son is in school, leaving no one else to care for her. His employers, a bank, have provided a room for his mother at his workplace. Lu Xincai feels it is his duty to care for his mother, who he says devoted her life to her children.

A study by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation at the University of Washington found that heavy drinking among Americans rose by 17.2 percent between 2005 and 2012, with a significant increase in binge-drinking as well. This rise is largely driven by women's drinking habits, with the rate of binge drinking among women increasing more than seven times the rate among men nationwide over the decade. In 2012, 8 percent of Americans were considered heavy drinkers and 18 percent were binge drinkers. The study, which was the first to track adult drinking patterns at the county level, also noted that while excessive drinking increased, the percentage of people who drink any alcohol remained relatively unchanged. Public health experts attribute the increase to factors such as changing social norms making it more acceptable for women to drink, cheaper alcohol prices in real dollars, increased alcohol advertising, and weakened alcohol control policies.

According to UN officials from the World Health Organisation (WHO), doctors are putting the health of women and their babies at risk by performing caesarean sections too readily. The WHO states that the procedure should only be carried out when "medically necessary" as it can lead to infections, complications, disability, or death.

In England, just over a quarter of women giving birth now have a caesarean, a rate that has more than doubled since the early 1990s. The WHO suggests the ideal rate should be between 10 and 15 per cent. This contradicts current NHS guidelines, which allow the procedure for women who are very anxious about childbirth (tokophobia), even without medical justification. A planned caesarean costs the NHS Â£2,369, compared to Â£1,665 for a natural birth. Previous research found that one in ten caesareans cause infections.

Michelle Filkins, 44, was arrested after allegedly breaking into a home on Martha's Vineyard, living there for at least a week, and selling the owner's belongings in a yard sale. The owner, Mark Conklin, discovered her in the home on April 17 and called the police. Filkins was arrested several hours later when she tried to return to the property. She has been charged with breaking and entering, larceny over $250, and malicious destruction of property. Police are asking anyone who received items from the home, such as furniture, a grill, and a painting, to return them to the Edgartown Police Department.

After a lost iPhone belonging to Bella Crooke was handed into the Albury police station, officers, finding the phone unlocked, posted a series of bizarre photos and selfies to her Facebook page to track her down. The posts, which included puns and photos of the phone in a holding "cell," advised her to put a password on her phone and informed her it was at the station ready for collection. Bella, who had lost the phone at a friend's birthday party, was unaware of the posts until she arrived to collect it. The officers, who had been waiting for her, recognized her from her Facebook page. Bella found the situation humorous and has since put a password on her phone.

A five-day-old baby hippo was killed after getting caught in a fight between two adult hippos. One of the adults grabbed the calf in its jaws, threw it into the air, and dragged it along the water's surface. The incident occurred in the iSimangaliso Wetland Park in eastern South Africa, as the calf's mother and a tour operator watched. The calf died from its injuries hours later.

A three-bedroom, unmodernised maisonette in Knightsbridge, London, is on the market for Â£575,000. The property's low price for the area is due to a catch: it only has three years remaining on its lease. The cost is comparable to renting a similar flat in the area. If a buyer were to extend the lease, which could cost between Â£3.35 and Â£4.5 million for 90 years, the modernised property could be worth upwards of Â£6 million. A second, larger maisonette is also for sale for Â£595,000 with the same three-year lease. Both properties are described as needing renovation.

A computer outage affected 8,000 Starbucks stores in the US and Canada, disrupting sales registers. The outage was caused by a failure during a daily system refresh.

*   **What was the result?** The glitch prompted baristas at some locations to give away free drinks and baked goods, while other stores closed early to avoid giving away products.

*   **How was it resolved?** Starbucks announced the issue was resolved and that stores were expected to open for "business as usual" the following day.

According to Detective Constable Gareth Jones from the Wales Extremism and Counter Terrorism Unit, terrorists are undergoing training and radicalizing Muslims in rural areas of West Wales, specifically in Ceredigion, Powys, and Pembrokeshire. He stated that those involved participate in "seemingly ordinary activities" but have an "ulterior motive."

The passage provides several examples of extremist activity in Wales:
*   In 1998, Abu Hamza allegedly sent extremists to train in the Brecon Beacons.
*   In 2005, two of the 7/7 bombers were photographed white water rafting in North Wales.
*   In 2010, three would-be terrorists from Cardiff held secret meetings in a Welsh country park.
*   Michael Adebowale, one of Lee Rigby's murderers, is said to have studied at the former European Institute of Human Sciences near Llanybydder.

DC Jones emphasized that terrorism is not confined to large cities and that community intelligence is vital for authorities.

An Omura's whale, a species previously thought to be extinct, was found washed up on a remote Exmouth beach in West Australia after Tropical Cyclone Olwyn. This is the first sighting of the species in WA and only the second in Australia. The 5.68m juvenile female was identified using DNA profiling. Environment Minister Albert Jacob called the find "highly significant" for scientists as very little is known about the species, which was first described in 2003. The whale's skeleton will be recovered in a few years for further scientific investigation and possible museum display. Omura's whales are typically found in tropical and subtropical waters like those of Indonesia, the Philippines, and the Sea of Japan, and have unique skeletal features, including 53 vertebrae.

A Texas businesswoman, Cheryl Rios, stated that Hillary Clinton should not be president because her hormones could make her irrational. The passage counters this by pointing out that male hormones have historically impaired male leaders' decision-making, and studies show women leaders take fewer unnecessary risks. The author argues that the debate over hormones is a symptom of a larger, more serious issue: gender bias against women in the workplace and leadership roles. This bias is described as both overt, such as the lack of women on corporate boards, and covert, like how female professors are rated differently than male ones. The passage concludes that gender equality benefits everyoneâcompanies, children, and marriagesâand that overcoming this bias is a steeper challenge for female candidates like Clinton. It also notes that Rios, who threatened to move to Canada if a woman were elected, was seemingly unaware that Canada had a female prime minister, Kim Campbell, in 1993.

Veteran actor Robert Hardy, 89, is selling his collection of over 200 antiques in an auction valued at Â£100,000 because he is downsizing his home. Known for his roles in "All Creatures Great and Small" and as Winston Churchill, Hardy is also a military historian and an expert on the medieval longbow. The items for sale include a diorama of the Battle of Agincourt, furniture, paintings, swords, books, and a longbow. The auction, consisting of 238 lots, will be held by Dominic Winter Auctioneers in Gloucestershire.

Michael Scott Shemansky is a suspect in the murder of his mother, Sandra Shemansky, and has been on the run from police since Saturday. He failed to appear for a supervised visit with his son on the same day his mother was found dead in the Winter Garden home they shared. Shemansky has a history of bipolar mental illness, is on parole for battery on law enforcement, and was previously involuntarily committed. His mother was helping him through a divorce, and neighbors believe the stress of the divorce proceedings may have pushed him over the edge. Authorities have the murder weapon but have not identified it or the cause of death. Shemansky was last seen fleeing on foot without provisions or medication.

The city of Eugene in the United States has been awarded the rights to host the 2021 IAAF World Championships. The International Association of Athletics Federations (IAAF) Council bypassed the usual bidding process, viewing it as a "unique strategic opportunity" to hold the event in the USA for the first time. Eugene had previously failed in its bid for the 2019 event, which was awarded to Doha. The 2007 World Championships in Osaka, Japan were also awarded without a bidding process.

Leonie Granger, an aspiring model, was jailed for 16 years for the manslaughter of professional gambler Mehmet Hassan. Granger set a "honey trap" for Hassan, who she met at a London casino, by befriending him to learn where he kept his winnings. She then went back to his flat, left the door unlocked for her boyfriend, Kyrron Jackson, and an accomplice, Nicholas Chandler, who tied up and kicked Hassan to death. They ransacked his home, stealing cash and other items. Granger was found guilty of manslaughter, while Jackson and Chandler were convicted of murder and jailed for life with a minimum term of 36 years.

Chelsea midfielder Cesc Fabregas is experiencing a dip in form during the second half of the season, a trend that was also noted by his former club, Barcelona. After a strong start to the season, where he looked set to break the Premier League assist record, his performance has declined. He struggled in Spain's 2-0 defeat to Holland and his assist rate for Chelsea has slowed significantly since mid-January. Despite this, Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho hopes for a resurgence from Fabregas to help secure the Premier League title.

West Ham are in discussions to sign 17-year-old Jamaican forward Deshane Beckford from Montego Bay United after he impressed during a two-week trial with the club's academy. Beckford, who is considered a top prospect from the Caribbean, also has offers from clubs in Belgium. Separately, West Ham has announced that season tickets at the Olympic Stadium for the 2016-17 season will start at Â£289, making them the cheapest in the Barclays Premier League.

Police have dropped an investigation into a vicious assault on a huntsman, Mike Lane, 40, who is the joint master of the Tedworth Hunt. The attack occurred during a confrontation with hunt saboteurs, even though the hunt was chasing an artificial scent. Mr. Lane was beaten by balaclava-clad protesters with iron bars on ropes, kicked in the head, and hospitalized with concussion, broken teeth, and memory loss.

Despite being provided with a video of the incident, a dossier of evidence including names of saboteurs and their car registration numbers, and a photograph of the main suspect, Wiltshire Police have stopped the investigation due to "insufficient evidence." The case is now recorded as "undetected" unless new evidence emerges. The victim and hunt supporters have condemned the decision as "pathetic" and "disgraceful," expressing a loss of trust in the police.

Adam Gadahn, known as the American mouthpiece for al Qaeda, was killed in a U.S. counterterrorism operation in January. Gadahn, who was not specifically targeted, was one of al Qaeda's most prominent members and its chief English-language propagandist. Born in California in 1978, he converted to Islam, moved to Pakistan in 1998, and rose through the ranks of al Qaeda. He appeared in numerous propaganda videos, threatening attacks, urging lone-wolf operations in the U.S., and was indicted for treason in 2006. Another U.S. citizen and al Qaeda operative, Ahmed Farouq, was killed in what was likely a separate operation that also resulted in the deaths of two hostages, Warren Weinstein and Giovanni Lo Porto.

A viral video in China features a five-year-old boy named Mai Zizhuo, who has been playing basketball since he was two and a half. The video shows him scoring hoops and dribbling two basketballs at once without losing rhythm. His skills have gained him many fans across China, with netizens leaving thousands of comments expressing disbelief and praise for his potential.

Tom O'Carroll, a leading member of the Paedophile Information Exchange (PIE), has joined the supporters of the media pressure group Hacked Off. O'Carroll attended a Hacked Off rally at the Houses of Parliament on February 25, which was chaired by John Cleese, to lobby MPs for state involvement in media regulation. PIE, which was formed in 1974, campaigned to legalise child sex in the 1970s and 80s. O'Carroll was jailed in 1981 for "corrupting public morals." A Hacked Off spokesman stated that the meeting was open to the public.

On Thursday, the Bondi Icebergs club pool was drained to be used as a catwalk for the Ten Pieces presentation during Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Australia. The label, headed by Maurice Terzini and Lucy Hinckfuss, produces capsule collections of ten unisex pieces designed to be worn in 20 different ways. Models walked through the empty concrete pool and along the break wall, showcasing a monochrome collection to guests on the club's balcony.

Bolton-born boxer Amir Khan, along with his wife Faryal Makhdoom Khan and daughter Lamysa, spent a Friday on a family trip to a safari park in northern California. At the Six Flags Discovery Kingdom, Khan posed with and fed a rare white tiger, and also posed with giraffes and sea lions. Earlier in the week, Khan announced his next fight will be against former light-welterweight world champion Chris Algieri on May 30. This announcement ended speculation about a potential fight against British rival Kell Brook.

The name of a Palestinian teenager, Mohammed Abu Khdeir, will be removed from an Israeli memorial for fallen soldiers and terror victims at Mount Herzl. Abu Khdeir, 16, was beaten and burned alive by three Israelis. His inclusion on the memorial was opposed by his family, with his father stating he refused to have his son's name listed with "soldiers of the occupation." An organization for terror victims, Almagor, also opposed it, describing the death as a rogue attack and not an act of terrorism. Following the complaints, the National Insurance Institute of Israel, which maintains the site, agreed to remove the name from the memorial wall and has already removed it from the memorial's website.

A young boy, filmed by YouTube user Lionel Hutz, repeatedly tries to use the family cat as a pillow in the garden. Each time the boy rests his head on the cat, the feline gets up and moves to a new spot. This sequence happens multiple times until the cat goes indoors. A later video shows the two have made up, with the boy feeding the cat treats.

Robert Kushner, a witness in a Philadelphia police corruption trial, lost his job as a varsity coach at the Jack M. Barrack Hebrew Academy after testifying about his past as a marijuana dealer. Kushner, who is one of over a dozen former drug dealers testifying for the government, told jurors that undercover officers on trial had stolen $81,000 and marijuana from him during a 2007 arrest. School officials were unaware of his history, as the 2007 charges were expunged. Kushner was also arrested again in 2011, sentenced to four years of probation, and pleaded guilty to a DUI in 2008. He stated he never meant to deceive the school and that the 2007 events were from a "bad phase" of his life.

An explosion at a chemical plant in China's southeastern Fujian province sparked a huge fire, injuring six people. The plant, located in Zhangzhou city, produces paraxylene (px), a chemical used to make polyester films and fabrics. The blast occurred at an oil storage facility following an oil leak. More than 600 firefighters were sent to control the blaze. This plant was previously hit by an explosion in July 2013. The plant was originally planned for Xiamen but was relocated to its current, more remote location in 2007 due to protests over pollution concerns.

Jack Grealish, an Aston Villa teenager, has a superstition of wearing his socks low, just above his children's-sized shinpads, and says he will not change this despite referees telling him to pull them up. He made his first Premier League start for Aston Villa in a 3-3 draw against QPR. Grealish was pleased to get his first start and hopes for more before the end of the season.

According to her grandmother, Cissy Houston, Bobbi Kristina Brown has "global and irreversible brain damage" and remains unresponsive, though she is no longer in a medically induced coma. A source confirmed she has been in the same neurological state for nearly three months, does not respond to visitors, and has a tracheostomy. In contrast, her father, Bobby Brown, stated she was "awake" and "watching me," and his attorney mentioned she has started a rehabilitation process and is expected to have a long life, though the quality of that life is unknown. Bobby Brown's wife clarified that he was in an "emotional state" when he made his remarks and that Bobbi Kristina has moved out of the ICU and opened her eyes.

Russia is leading Germany 2-0 in the Fed Cup final after Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova defeated Sabine Lisicki and Svetlana Kuznetsova beat Julia Goerges. Pavlyuchenkova saved a match point in the second set to win her match 4-6, 7-6 (4), 6-3. Kuznetsova won her match in straight sets. Russia now needs one win from the three matches on Sunday to secure the Fed Cup title.

Residents of New South Wales are being warned to prepare for more floods and damage, as another storm is predicted to hit later this week. Meteorologists indicate that an east coast low, the same weather system as last week, could bring heavy rain from Thursday. The State Emergency Service (SES) is concerned that more storms will hinder clean-up efforts, with over 4,000 jobs still outstanding from the previous storm. The SES is particularly worried about the Hunter region, which was severely affected last week. While one meteorologist suggests the new system might be different and less focused on Sydney, the Bureau of Meteorology warns that the main impacts could be on the state's northeast coast, with further rainfall likely for already flooded areas.

Nina Moric, a model who appeared in a Ricky Martin video, was hospitalized after collapsing at home due to what she described as "low blood pressure," resulting in heavy bruising. Italian media reported that she had attempted to take her own life and was found by her mother, a claim supported by her boyfriend, Luigi Mario Favoloso. However, Ms. Moric denied these claims on her Instagram account, stating she was shocked by them and that her boyfriend was in Naples at the time of the incident. She reassured her fans that she was recovering at home. The passage also notes that Italian media had previously claimed she attempted suicide in 2009. Additionally, it mentions she was once married to paparazzi snapper Fabrizio Corona, with whom she has a son.

A YouGov poll for the Sunday Times reveals public preferences for the name of Kate and William's second child. For a girl, Diana is the top choice with 12% of the vote, followed by Alice and Charlotte with 9% each. For a boy, James is the preferred name for 13% of people, with Alexander as the second favourite. The poll of 2,200 people also showed that a quarter want the couple to have a girl, while only 3% hope for a boy. Additionally, 68% of people support William's decision to take six weeks of paternity leave.

A suicide bomber detonated explosives near protesters in eastern Afghanistan.
*   **Where did it happen?** The city of Khost.
*   **When did it happen?** Thursday around 10 a.m. local time.
*   **What were the casualties?** 17 people were killed and 64 were wounded.
*   **Who was wounded?** An Afghan lawmaker, Humayoon Humayoon, was among the wounded.
*   **Who claimed responsibility?** The Taliban denied responsibility, and no other group has claimed it.

Dani Alves is set to leave Barcelona this summer after his representative, Dinorah Santana, confirmed he had rejected the club's final contract offer. The offer was for a three-year extension, dependent on Alves playing in 60% of the club's matches. Santana stated that negotiations are now over.

Pablo Osvaldo has urged Italian legends Andrea Pirlo and Francesco Totti to join him at the Argentinian team Boca Juniors. Osvaldo, who is on loan from Southampton, has scored three goals in six games for Boca. He believes Pirlo and Totti would be a "perfect" fit for the team due to their "South-American style" and that the fans at La Bombonera would go "absolutely crazy" for them.

Amateur jockey Lewis Ferguson, an 18-year-old who works at Paul Nicholls's yard, became an internet sensation after a spectacular double somersault fall from the horse Merrion Square at Wincanton. The fall has been watched hundreds of thousands of times online. Ferguson was left with only a cut on his nose and was back to mucking out stables and riding the next morning, undeterred from getting back in the saddle. He described the fall as a "blur" and stated he was lucky it wasn't a bad one.

With the release of the new "Avengers: Age of Ultron" movie, England flanker and London Wasps captain James Haskell posted a photo on Instagram dressed as Iron Man. Haskell, who returned to the Wasps in 2012, has played in France, Japan, and New Zealand. Since his return, he has surpassed 100 appearances for the club and has earned 57 caps for the England squad.

The wide-leg trouser is a prominent SS15 trend, available in denim, cropped, printed, or striped styles. It offers an alternative to skinny jeans, which have been popular for years. Louise Redknapp notes that while skinny jeans are timeless, the wide-leg provides a different look.

To wear the trend successfully, especially for those who are shorter, pairing the trousers with high heels is key to elongating the leg and avoiding being "drowned by too much fabric." Keeping the top half simple with a knit, shirt, or tee helps maintain proportion. For longer-length trousers, a high-waisted, very long style is recommended to give extra leg length.

Denim is cited as the easiest way to adopt the trend. The wide-leg trouser was featured on several SS15 catwalks, including Gucci, who showcased a denim version, and Celine, who presented colourful, billowing bottoms. Topshop offers a high-street version called the "Miller" jean.

The University of Michigan will proceed with a screening of the film "American Sniper" after initially canceling it. The cancellation followed a petition signed by over 200 students who felt the movie's depiction of the Iraq War reflected negatively on people from the Middle East. However, a counter-petition and backlash led the university to reverse its decision. E. Royster Harper, the university's vice president for student life, stated that canceling the movie was a "mistake" and inconsistent with the university's value of freedom of expression. For those who do not wish to see "American Sniper," a screening of "Paddington" will be offered as an alternative.

On April 3rd on Rottnest Island, two French male tourists, aged 18 and 24, allegedly ignited an aerosol spray with a lighter, causing a large flame to make contact with a quokka. The animal survived but was singed. Detectives questioned the men, seized video evidence, and evicted them from the island. Both men have been charged with animal cruelty and are scheduled to appear in Fremantle Magistrates Court on April 17. Quokkas are described as being the size of a domestic cat and are found on small islands off the West Australian coast, particularly Rottnest Island and Bald Island.

Alice Barker, a 102-year-old woman who was a dancer in New York nightspots like the Cotton Club in the 1930s and 1940s, was shown videos of herself dancing for the first time. Barker, who had danced alongside notables like Frank Sinatra, had never seen the motion pictures made of her and had lost all her photos. Mark Cantor of jazz-on-film.com and some volunteers compiled a video of "soundies" (early music videos) and showed them to her at her nursing home. Barker was delighted, calling it "fabulous."

A study of 1,100 adults by vehicle leasing firm OSV found that the practice of washing one's own car is declining in Britain. The study revealed that a third of men and three-quarters of women have never washed their own car. Reasons for this decline include shops opening on Sundays, more live football on TV, the rise of hand car washes, and vehicles like 4x4s being too large to clean. Only 5% of those surveyed had ever asked their children to wash the car for pocket money. The survey also found that Audis, Toyotas, and BMWs are the most likely cars to be washed by their owners, while Range Rovers, Peugeots, and Mercedes are the least likely.

Martin Skrtel has praised Steven Gerrard, calling him one of the best players in the world and synonymous with Liverpool. Skrtel credits Gerrard with helping him settle at the club when he arrived in 2008. While he believes Liverpool will be different without Gerrard, he thinks the team has players who can replace him. Gerrard is set to play in the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa, with the final on his birthday being a potential end to his Liverpool career before he moves to LA Galaxy. Both Skrtel and Gerrard could return for the Villa match after serving three-match bans.

At the age of 75, Jack Nicklaus hit a hole-in-one on the 130-yard fourth hole during the par-3 contest at Augusta National. He was playing alongside Gary Player and Ben Crenshaw. This was Nicklaus' first ace at Augusta, but it was one of five hole-in-ones on the day, a record previously set in 2002. Camilo Villegas also had two aces, on the fourth and eighth holes, but lost the contest to Kevin Streelman in a play-off. The passage also notes that Nicklaus became the youngest person to win a green jacket in 1963, won his sixth in 1986, and is one of five men to have completed the career grand slam.

On Wednesday night, tornado sirens were activated in Kansas due to several storms, with a reported tornado near Goddard. Other tornado sightings occurred in southwestern Kansas near Aetna. The storms also affected Missouri, where a possible tornado touched down in Potosi, causing wind damage, flooding, and damage to roofs. Baseball-sized hail was reported in Farmington. More storms are predicted for Thursday in the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and near the southern Great Lakes.

An Oklahoma reserve sheriff's deputy, Robert Bates, pleaded not guilty to a second-degree manslaughter charge for fatally shooting Eric Harris. Bates claims he intended to use a Taser but mistakenly used his gun. The judge granted Bates permission to take a family vacation to the Bahamas, a decision criticized by the victim's family as showing "apathy." Bates' preliminary hearing is set for July 2. The lawyer for Harris's family alleges Bates was unqualified and received preferential treatment due to donations and his friendship with the sheriff. The Tulsa County Sheriff's office denies allegations that supervisors were told to forge Bates' training records. Bates' lawyer has released training documents to prove he was properly trained.

Conor McGregor is preparing for a featherweight title challenge against Jose Aldo on July 11 in Las Vegas. Ahead of the fight, McGregor has unveiled a new tattoo of a tiger's face on his stomach, adding to the existing gorilla tattoo on his chest. McGregor claims he has greater motivation than Aldo, who will be making the eighth defense of his belt. During a promotional tour in Dublin, McGregor grabbed Aldo's belt and raised it in front of his home supporters.

Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott skolled a beer in about six seconds at an Australian rules function, which was met with cheers from players.
*   **What was the reaction?** The act drew criticism from anti-drinking campaigners, including cultural studies professor Julie Robert. They argued that Abbott was glorifying binge drinking and associating masculinity with alcohol consumption.
*   **What was the defense?** Health Minister Sussan Ley defended Abbott, stating there was "nothing wrong" with his actions and highlighting his fitness routine. Opposition leader Bill Shorten quipped that he was "pleased that tony abbottâs learning to drink beer without adding lemonade to it".
*   **What was the core concern?** Critics, like Dr. Robert, were concerned that the incident and the reactions to it perpetuate a culture where drinking is about speed and quantity rather than socializing, and reinforces the stereotype that heavy drinking is part of being an Australian male.

Indiana has experienced a significant increase in HIV cases, with 120 confirmed and 10 preliminary positive cases now tied to Scott County. This is an increase from 106 cases the previous week. The outbreak, which typically sees about five cases a year in the county, has occurred among intravenous drug users, primarily involving the painkiller Opana.

In response, Governor Mike Pence approved a short-term, 30-day needle exchange program on March 26. More than two weeks into the program, 5,322 clean syringes have been provided to 86 participants, and about 1,400 used syringes have been returned. Pence is currently reviewing whether to extend the program beyond its April 25 end date.

The future of the program and similar programs in other counties is uncertain. Governor Pence opposes needle exchanges as an anti-drug policy. Legislation that would allow other at-risk Indiana counties to establish their own needle-exchange programs has passed the House but its fate in the Senate is unclear. Federal law also bans public funding for such programs.

An Arsenal fan created a test for his girlfriend, Saskia, to quiz her on his favourite football club. Saskia scored 43.5 out of 50, or 87%, which her boyfriend graded as an 'A'. As a result, he commented that he would not be dumping her.

The test was formatted like a school exam and included questions such as naming the starting 11 squad, the score of the 2014 FA Cup final, and explaining why Alexis Sanchez is better than Eden Hazard. Saskia posted pictures of the test on her Twitter account. While some Twitter users felt the boyfriend had gone too far, others hailed him as a 'legend' and were impressed with Saskia's score.

Carlos Toro, a 66-year-old former informant for the DEA, is facing deportation to Colombia after retiring. Toro, a former mid-level member of the Medellin cartel, worked for the DEA for 27 years as an undercover operative in exchange for a promise of US citizenship. He was one of the DEA's most important assets, and his work helped in the prosecution of figures like Carlos Lehder and Manuel Noriega. Despite his service, he was never paid and did not receive the promised citizenship. Now retired due to declining health, his temporary visa has expired, and he is living in the US illegally. The DEA has refused to help with his citizenship after he went public with his story. Toro fears he will be killed if he is deported to Colombia.

A 14-year-old girl in Kosi Kalan, Uttar Pradesh, set herself on fire after allegedly being gang-raped by five men from her village. She is in a Delhi hospital with 70 per cent burns. The accused men have been arrested. The passage also mentions heightened sensitivity to sexual assault in India, referencing the ban of the documentary "India's Daughter," which was about the gang rape and murder of 23-year-old student Jyoti Singh. The text also describes incidents of vigilante justice, including a man accused of rape being beaten to death by a mob in Nagaland.

Manchester United manager Louis van Gaal has said he dreams of beating rivals Manchester City in the upcoming derby at Old Trafford. He has ruled out Robin van Persie and Luke Shaw from the match, stating that while they may be fit, they are not fit enough to play by his standards. Van Gaal believes a win would be a significant step up the table, potentially securing third place and a spot in the top four, which would be better than the pre-season goal. He also mentioned that his team needs to control their aggression, having learned from their 1-0 loss to City earlier in the season.

In a protest against rising ticket prices, a section of Arsenal and Liverpool fans left their seats empty for the first 10 minutes of their Premier League match at the Emirates Stadium. Supporters from both clubs, organized by groups like Arsenal's Black Scarf Movement and Liverpool's Spirit of Shankly, described the prices as "extortionate," particularly after the announcement of the Premier League's Â£5.14 billion TV deal. Tickets for the match started at Â£64, and fans displayed banners with messages such as "Â£5bn and what do we get? Â£64 a ticket" and "football without fans is nothing." The protest aimed to raise awareness of the struggles fans face with rising costs, with organizers warning that a generation of fans could be lost. Further protests were expected after the match.

A newborn baby named Star Reader was diagnosed with biliary atresia, a life-threatening liver condition where the bile ducts are blocked. After an initial operation to unblock the ducts was unsuccessful, her parents were told she needed a liver transplant to survive. Neither parent was a suitable match, but her mother's twin sister, Shanell Reader, was an ideal candidate and donated part of her liver. The transplant operation took place in November, and Star has since made a good recovery, though she will require lifelong medication.

Chelsea football players Eden Hazard, Nathan Ake, Loic Remy, and Willian participated in Audi's football challenge. The players were split into two teams: Hazard and Ake versus Remy and Willian. The challenge consisted of three rounds. In the first round, players aimed to fire balls into the boot of a car from close range, with Hazard and Ake winning 5-3. The second round involved playing football over an Audi R8 V10 plus, which acted as a net on a makeshift tennis court; Hazard and Ake won this round as well. The final round required the players to shoot from long range to sink footballs into a convertible Audi. Remy and Willian won this challenge, but during their victory, Willian accidentally smashed the wing mirror of one of the cars with a long-range shot.

Robert Dellinger, a 54-year-old former Fortune 500 executive, caused a highway crash in December 2013 that killed 24-year-old Amanda Murphy, her 29-year-old fiancÃ© Jason Timmons, and their unborn baby. During his sentencing, Dellinger stated he was not suicidal, contradicting what prosecutors said he previously told investigators. Dellinger pleaded guilty to negligent homicide and one count of assault. His defense attorneys claimed he was suffering from Ambien withdrawal, a psychiatric drug overdose, Prozac, and multiple sclerosis. He faces 12 to 24 years in prison and a wrongful death lawsuit.

Lacey Spears of Scottsville, Kentucky, was convicted of killing her five-year-old son, Garnett-Paul Spears, by poisoning him with salt through his feeding tube. She was sentenced to 20 years to life in prison, though she was spared the maximum of 25 years to life. The boy's father, Chris Hill, expressed his anger on Facebook following the sentencing. Prosecutors stated that Spears made her son ill for attention, documenting his supposed illnesses on social media, while her lawyer claimed she was innocent, blamed the hospital for negligence, and plans to appeal. The judge noted that Spears suffers from a mental illness and called the crime "unfathomable in its cruelty."

An improved influenza vaccine is arriving in Australia a month later than expected. This new vaccine includes protection against two new strains, influenza A strain H3N2 and influenza B strain B/Phuket, which caused a spike in deaths in Europe and the United States. The previous vaccine in the northern hemisphere was not a good match for these strains. High-risk groups, including the very young, very old, and most Indigenous Australians, can get free, government-funded flu shots from April 20. Experts, like Dr. Alan Hampson, state the modified vaccine is worth the wait and should be a good match for circulating global strains. Dr. Hampson also advises everyone to get the vaccine to protect themselves and those in high-risk groups.

Caretakers of Abraham Lincoln's tomb are facing challenges from an unflattering critique in National Geographic magazine and potential budget cuts. The magazine article described the tomb as having "all the historical character of an office lobby" and called it "a disappointment." Simultaneously, Illinois Governor Bruce Rauner has proposed eliminating the state historic preservation agency, which manages the site, and rolling it into another department. The tomb has already seen reduced hours and staffing due to previous budget cuts. Supporters defend the site, noting it has undergone over $2.5 million in recent repairs and renovations. The tomb was designed by Larkin Mead, dedicated in 1874, and reconstructed twice, most recently in 1930.

The passage discusses the comeback of nineties fashion trends, noting that while some, like chokers and Calvin Klein logos, are popular, the potential return of JNCO "rave" jeans has horrified many. The article then lists nine "worst offenders" from the nineties and noughties that it argues should be left in the past. These trends include bucket hats, camouflage print, "taking it to the max" with styles like double denim, Ugg boots, Daisy Dukes, Juicy Couture tracksuits, coloured sunglasses, corsets as outerwear, and harem trousers. For each trend, the text provides examples of celebrities who wore them in the past and those who are wearing them now.

This week's trending stories included a quadruple rainbow in the New York area, China's crackdown on hiring exotic dancers for wakes, and an agitated interview with RDJ. A new social media trend, the #kyliejennerchallenge, involves lip plumping by sucking on a jar. Other stories included a 102-year-old woman named Alice Barker going back in time with filmmakers, a controversial prom-posal involving a bomb reference, Ewan McGregor being cast as Lumiere in 'Beauty and the Beast,' and Johnny Depp's appearance in the 'Black Mass' trailer. Additionally, a pregnancy was announced with a "Fresh Prince of Bel-Air" reference, and a military dad photobombed his son.

Serena Williams received a large cake at the Miami Open to celebrate her 700th career victory after defeating Germany's Sabine Lisicki 7-6, 1-6, 6-3 to reach the semi-finals. This came a day after Andy Murray was also given a cake for his 500th win. Williams will now face Romania's Simona Halep, who beat Sloane Stephens 6-1, 7-5. A potential match between Serena and her sister Venus was prevented when Venus was defeated by Spain's Carla Suarez Navarro.

Sabeen Mahmud, a Pakistani figurehead for humanism, love, and tolerance, was shot and killed at point-blank range in Karachi. She ran a second-floor cafe, known as T2F, which was a space for discussions on technology, human rights, and women's entrepreneurship. Her killing occurred after she hosted a discussion on the volatile topic of disappearances in the province of Balochistan, a subject that had been shut down at a university. Mahmud had received death threats in the past for addressing this topic. Her mother was also shot in the attack but is expected to survive. No one has claimed responsibility for the shooting.

Mangu Ram, an 82-year-old Hindu healer, is a West Pakistan Refugee (WPR) who fled to Indian Kashmir during the 1947 partition. For nearly 70 years, he and approximately 100,000 other WPRs have been denied rights such as owning property or voting in state elections, effectively making them second-class citizens. This status is due to a pre-independence law and has trapped generations in poverty. The refugees, most of whom have never been to Pakistan, are hopeful for change after Prime Minister Narendra Modi's Hindu nationalist party (BJP) won a share of power in the Muslim-majority state and pledged to normalize their status. Activists state that granting them these rights is the only way to improve their condition.

FC Tokyo forward Yoshinori Muto is considering a potential transfer to Chelsea, who have reportedly made a Â£4 million offer for him. Muto is carefully thinking about the move, as his priority is to join a team where he can play regularly and develop. If he joins Chelsea, the plan is to loan him to their partner club, Vitesse Arnhem. Muto's former coach, Ranko Popovic, believes the "intelligent," "fast," and "strong" player has amazing potential. Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho acknowledged that while commercial interests, such as the club's sponsorship deal with Yokohama Rubber, are a factor in transfers, the club only pursues good players or prospects.

The author argues that England should follow Australia's lead and abandon its policy of not selecting players based overseas. The author believes this policy is "ridiculous" and "old-fashioned," preventing England from picking its best team for the World Cup. Several examples are given of players whose performance has improved since moving to France, including Matt Giteau and Drew Mitchell for Australia, and Steffon Armitage, Nick Abendanon, and Jonny Wilkinson for England. The author states that for a home World Cup, the coach must be free to pick the best players regardless of where they play, and that not doing so penalises players, demeans the tournament, and could leave the team, fans, and players wondering "what if."

Open Garden's FireChat app allows users to chat without needing the internet or a mobile signal by creating wireless mesh networks. To enhance these networks, Open Garden is developing Greenstone, a small, egg-shaped device that acts as a beacon or booster. Greenstone is designed to extend the range of these off-the-grid networks, which are currently limited to about 200ft (61 metres).

The FireChat app, downloaded over five million times, uses features like Apple's Multipeer Connectivity Framework (MCF) to connect phones directly via Bluetooth or Wi-Fi Direct. Each phone becomes a node, passing secure and anonymous messages to other nearby users.

The Greenstone device, still in development, will work with FireChat to strengthen these networks in areas with poor or no connectivity, such as festivals, protests, or hospitals. It has a one-year battery life and can store up to 1,000 recent messages, holding them until another FireChat user comes within range.

Lillian Bustle, a burlesque performer from New Jersey, is working to remove the negativity associated with the word 'fat' by embracing it as an honest descriptor of her body. In a TED Talk, she argued that 'fat' should not be a synonym for 'ugly' and is just another self-descriptor, similar to how she calls herself 'short' or 'wife'. Bustle highlights that size discrimination has risen and that many young girls wish to be thinner. However, she points to studies showing that increased exposure to body diversity leads to greater acceptance. This belief motivates her burlesque performances, where she exposes audiences to a 'fat' body in a positive way. Since starting in 2012, performing has been an empowering and body-positive experience for her. Her 2014 TED Talk, recently posted on YouTube, has received a mostly positive response.

Theo Walcott, an Arsenal winger who has been on the substitutes' bench for 17 of 33 Premier League games, was featured in a photoshoot for Lanvin, the club's official tailor since 2013. He posed for an official portrait alongside runway model Olga Sherer and six of his Arsenal teammates: Calum Chambers, Jack Wilshere, Mikel Arteta, David Ospina, Mathieu Flamini, and Mesut Ozil. The Arsenal first team will wear similar attire for their FA Cup final against Aston Villa on May 30. Walcott is hoping to make his first start since March 14 in the upcoming match against Hull.

A collection of props and puppets created by make-up effects artist Rick Baker is being auctioned. The auction will take place on May 29 at the Hilton Universal City in Los Angeles and on propstore.com. The collection, from Baker's Cinovation Studio, consists of 417 original items from over 50 productions and is estimated to be worth $746,100. Items for sale are from films such as *Men in Black*, *Batman Forever*, *How the Grinch Stole Christmas*, *Gremlins 2: The New Batch*, and Michael Jackson's *Moonwalker* film. Individual items have estimated values ranging from $1,500 for the Two-Face mask from *Batman Forever* to $40,000 for the Alien Edgar Bug from *Men in Black*.

A seven-year-old British boy, Carwyn Scott-Howell, was killed in the French Alps after falling over a 164ft drop. The incident occurred during a family ski holiday in the resort of Flaine. Carwyn became separated from his mother and sister on their last run of the day. It is believed he left the piste and entered dense woodland, possibly trying to get back to the resort which he could see through the trees. Police followed his footprints in the snow to find his body. His family described him as a "daring, outgoing and determined" youngster whose death has left a "vast void in their hearts."

Laura Scurr, a 15-year-old from Whitley Bay, developed anorexia at age 13 due to pressures to be a "size zero" and bullying about her weight. She survived on as little as one piece of fruit a day, hiding food from her mother. Her obsession with weight loss led to her body shutting down, and she collapsed and was hospitalized on a heart machine for a week. After her discharge, she received support from eating disorder organizations. Now recovered, with a healthier body image and newfound confidence, Laura has reached the semi-finals of Miss Teen GB, a competition that promotes positive experiences for young girls away from size zero stereotypes.

Liverpool supporters told Raheem Sterling they expect him to remain at the club during an event at Anfield to unveil the new home kit. Sterling, along with teammates Daniel Sturridge, Martin Skrtel, and Simon Mignolet, paraded the new gingham design kit. This is the first kit from New Balance, who have a record-breaking Â£300 million four-year deal with the club. The unveiling comes a week after Sterling rejected a Â£100,000-a-week contract and said he was flattered by links to Arsenal. Despite this, Liverpool is adamant he will not be leaving this summer. During the event, one fan shouted, "make sure we see you in that next season" at Sterling, which was met with applause. The players also discussed the upcoming FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa.

A team from the University of Manchester, led by Dr. Sarah Bridle, has produced the largest single high-definition map of dark matter. The map, which shows clumps of the mystery particles across 0.4 percent of the sky, was created using data from the Dark Energy Camera on the Victor M. Blanco telescope in Chile. It is the first in a series of maps from the five-year Dark Energy Survey (DES), which aims to eventually map 12.5 percent of the sky to create a 3D view of dark matter.

Dark matter is an invisible substance that makes up at least 80 percent of the matter in the universe. It cannot be observed directly, so the survey studies its gravitational effects on galaxies, a technique called gravitational lensing. The map was created by analyzing 130 million separate telescope images of galaxies. The findings so far support theories that galaxies form where there are large concentrations of dark matter. The ultimate goal of the survey is to understand the nature of dark energy, which is believed to be causing the expansion of the universe to accelerate.

Manchester United have made an official approach to sign 21-year-old PSV Eindhoven star Memphis Depay. United manager Louis van Gaal, who is familiar with Depay from the 2014 World Cup, is keen to make him a summer signing. PSV's technical director, Marcel Brands, confirmed contact with Manchester United, Paris Saint-Germain, and another big European club, noting that Depay is now worth more than the Â£15 million offered by Tottenham the previous summer.

Depay has scored 20 goals in 26 league games for PSV, helping them win their first Dutch championship in seven years. He is described as a pacy winger who loves to run at defenders, can shoot from a distance, and often plays on the left-wing, cutting inside. He was nominated for the 'Best Young Player' award at the 2014 World Cup.

In a football match between Chelsea and Manchester City's youth sides, Chelsea won 3-1. Tammy Abraham scored a double, and Dominic Solanke added a late goal for Chelsea. Isaac Buckley-Ricketts scored for Manchester City. The passage also provides brief performance reviews for each player from both teams.

Marco Rubio has stated that he believes people are "born with a sexual preference" and that it is not a choice for the "vast and enormous majority of people." Despite this, he does not believe same-sex marriage is a constitutional right and thinks the definition of marriage should be between one man and one woman. Rubio insists that state legislatures, not courts, should decide whether to allow gay marriage. He also said he would attend the same-sex wedding of a family member or staffer out of love and respect, even if he disagrees with the decision, similar to how he, as a Catholic, believes divorce is wrong but wouldn't stop loving someone for it. The Florida senator and presidential candidate has reportedly received monetary commitments exceeding $51 million for his campaign.

Pablo Mandado, 27, and Ilze Zebolde, 31, are on an open-ended cycling journey to "discover different parts of this planet a pedal at a time." In their first 356 days, they have traveled nearly 7,000 miles through 16 countries, starting in London and heading through Europe into Asia. They live on less than three euros each per day by camping, using hosting websites like Couchsurfing, and relying on the kindness of strangers for accommodation. Their main expense is food, which consists of simple items like pasta, bread, and rice, sometimes supplemented by dumpster diving or gifts. After traversing Turkey, Georgia, and Armenia, they plan to continue into Asia and then cycle the length of the American continent.

A Texas couple, who married in 2012, is suing photographer James Evans, owner of Premiere Photos. They allege that a photo booth rented for their wedding printed a racial slur, "poor n***** party," on the bottom of photo booth pictures. The couple was not aware of the incident until months later when the bride's sister informed them.

The couple's attorney, Cathy Hale, states that when the groom contacted Evans, Evans did not apologize and reportedly told him to "sue me." The couple is suing under the Texas Deceptive Trade Practices Act for negligence and breach of contract. Evans has denied all allegations, claiming there is no evidence linking his company to the caption and that the couple showed "no sign of any mental anguish." The couple's lawyer says they want an apology at the very least. Mediation is scheduled, and if no agreement is reached, the case will go to trial in July.

England full-back Mike Brown has stated he will take a "cautious" approach to recovering from his latest concussion setback and is unsure when he will return to play for Harlequins. He pulled out of a match against Saracens after not feeling "quite right" and having a headache following the game against France. Brown was previously knocked out cold during England's victory over Italy in February. He credits World Rugby online modules for increasing his awareness of concussion symptoms, which helped him decide to pull out of the Ireland game and not risk further injury. He also mentions other players like George North and Johnny Sexton who have had extended breaks due to concussions.

According to Professor David Spiegelhalter, a statistician at Cambridge University, smartphone use may be to blame for a drop in the number of times couples have sex each month. Research has shown that the frequency of sex among Britons has been declining since the emergence of the internet. A typical heterosexual couple now has sex three times a month, compared to four times in 2000 and five times in 1990. Professor Spiegelhalter suggests that because people are now better connected technologically and are always checking emails, the boundaries between public and private lives have eroded, squeezing out time that would have been spent with partners. Catherine Mercer, a researcher on the British National Survey, is quoted as saying that with competing demands on time, sex falls down the list of priorities, and dealing with work emails late in the evening can prevent people from focusing on their partners at bedtime.

Tibetan mastiffs, which can weigh up to 80 kg and once sold for as much as Â£1.2 million, have become so unpopular in China that they are being sent to slaughterhouses. Their meat is used in hotpots and their skin for leather belts.

The decline in their popularity is attributed to several factors:
*   A Chinese government anti-corruption crackdown has stopped the practice of giving the dogs as expensive gifts to officials.
*   Several major Chinese cities, including Beijing, have banned owning dogs over 50 kg.
*   Cross-breeding driven by profit has led to a deterioration in the breed's quality and a surplus of "imperfect" dogs.
*   Increased urbanization has made people realize the dogs are not suited for city living.

Animal-welfare workers recently rescued 20 mastiffs from cramped cages while they were being transported to a slaughterhouse. It is feared that hundreds of these dogs, including those stolen by gangs or offloaded by breeders, are facing this fate across China.

A survey of 600 women in the Paris area found that every woman surveyed claimed to have been a victim of sexual harassment on the city's public transport. Half of those interviewed stated they first experienced harassment before the age of 18. The harassment ranged from insults and intimidating behavior to sexual assault and rape. As a result, six out of ten women reported being afraid of being attacked on public transport, compared to three out of ten men. The report, handed to the French women's rights ministry, noted that these attacks limit women's freedom, forcing them to alter their daily lives and routes. The poll has led to calls for a campaign to address sexist or threatening behavior on buses and trains.

Leeds-based company Direct Line is running a competition called #everydayfix to find a solution for common daily problems.
    *   **The Process:** They surveyed 2,000 people to identify the top ten "everyday emergencies," then asked design groups from Makerversity to create prototype products to solve them.
    *   **The Shortlist:** Three products were shortlisted for a public vote on Twitter:
        *   **Snooze:** An alarm clock that connects to your phone and silences notifications to help with sleep.
        *   **Forget Me Lock:** A device that fastens to a key and turns red when the door is locked and green when it is open, providing reassurance.
        *   **Nipper:** Described as the world's smallest mobile phone charger, it uses any household battery to provide a power boost.
    *   **The Outcome:** The product with the most retweets will be funded through a Kickstarter campaign and made into an actual product.

Vera Baird, the police and crime commissioner for Northumbria, is under investigation by the Ministry of Justice. The investigation follows her decision to award over Â£500,000 of public money to Victims First Northumbria, a charity where she serves as a director. Northumbria's chief constable, Sue Sim, also sits on the charity's top table. Critics, including Keith Vaz, have called this an "inappropriate" conflict of interest and likened the situation to a "soap opera." Ms. Baird has defended her decision, stating that all Ministry of Justice procedures were followed. The Ministry of Justice confirmed it will investigate for any conflict of interest and has the power to cease funding if one is found.

Three people have been imprisoned and two are awaiting sentencing for assaulting a 53-year-old man, Greg Valecce. The ringleader, Corry 'Corey' Campbell, 21, believed Valecce had hurt his cat, Pebbles, and stolen money and weed. The assault took place over three days in the basement of Campbell's mother's house. Valecce was beaten, tied to a chair, and covered in offensive tattoos. He suffered three busted ribs, two broken wrists, and fractured facial bones.

Campbell and Carl Halin, 18, were each sentenced to 20 years in prison. Campbell's girlfriend, Sandra Ng, 19, was sentenced to 23 months. David Harrison (referred to as David Thomas in the text) and Jennifer Pratt are awaiting sentencing and trial, respectively. All three sentenced individuals pleaded guilty to charges including aggravated assault, conspiracy, and false imprisonment.

Manchester United has made an official approach to sign 21-year-old PSV Eindhoven star Memphis Depay. United manager Louis van Gaal, who is familiar with Depay from the 2014 World Cup, is keen to make him a summer signing. PSV's technical director, Marcel Brands, confirmed contact with Manchester United, Paris Saint-Germain, and another big European club. Depay has scored 20 goals in 26 league games for PSV this season and helped them win the Dutch championship. He is described as pacy, with neat close control, an explosive right foot, and a love for running at defenders.

In a football match between Chelsea and Manchester City's youth sides, Chelsea won 3-1. Tammy Abraham scored a double, and Dominic Solanke added a late goal for Chelsea. Isaac Buckley-Ricketts scored Manchester City's only goal. The passage also provides brief performance reviews for each player from both teams.

Marco Rubio, a presidential candidate and Florida senator, has stated that he believes people are "born with a sexual preference" and that it is not a choice for the "vast and enormous majority of people." Despite this belief, he does not think same-sex marriage is a constitutional right and maintains that the "definition of the institution of marriage should be between one man and one woman." He pulled out of a match against Saracens after not feeling "quite right" and having a headache following the England vs. France game. Tibetan Mastiffs, which can weigh up to 80 kg, were once highly prized in China, selling for as much as Â£1.2 million and given as gifts by wealthy businessmen to officials. Their popularity has dramatically declined, and they are now being sent to slaughterhouses for their meat and skin. This decline is attributed to several factors: the Chinese government's anti-corruption crackdown, which has stopped the practice of giving the dogs as gifts; bans on owning dogs over 50 kg in several major cities; and a realization that the breed is not suited for city living. Leeds-based company Direct Line is running a competition called #everydayfix to find a solution for common, everyday problems. They surveyed 2,000 people to identify the top ten "everyday emergencies," with not being able to sleep ranking as the top concern.

Groups from the design company Makerversity were asked to create prototype products to solve some of these issues. Three products were shortlisted for a public vote:

3.  **Nipper:** Described as the world's smallest mobile phone charger, it uses any household battery to provide a power boost to your phone.

The public can vote for their favourite product on Twitter. The winning prototype will be funded through a Kickstarter campaign and developed into an actual product.
The 2009 convention had over 512 guests and musical performers, including Patrick Stewart, William Shatner, Leonard Nimoy, Terry Gilliam, Bruce Boxleitner, James Marsters, and Mary McDonnell.
The 2009 convention had over 6000 guests and musical performers, including Patrick Stewart, William Shatner, Leonard Nimoy, Terry Gilliam, Bruce Boxleitner, James Marsters, and Mary McDonnell.
More than cases of COVID-19 have been reported in over 180 countries and 200 territories, leading to more than deaths.
